{{Location map many|Asia | width = 400 | float = right | caption = {{Numbered list|23 Jan - FALCON cable near Bandar Abbas, Iran |30 Jan - SEA-ME-WE-4 near Alexandria |30 Jan - FLAG cable near Alexandria |1 Feb - FALCON cable between Muscat and Dubai, UAE |3 Feb - DOHA-HALOUL between Qatar and UAE |4 Feb - SEA-ME-WE-4 near Penang, Malaysia}} | <!--first label/marker--> | label1 = 1 | lat1_deg = 27.18 | lon1_deg = 56.27 | <!--second label/marker--> | label2 = 2 | position2 = top | lat2_deg = 31.56 | lon2_deg = 29.09 | <!--third label/marker--> | label3 = 3 | position3 = right | lat3_deg = 31.89 | lon3_deg = 30.61 | <!--fourth label/marker--> | label4 = 4 | position4 = bottom | lat4_deg = 24.48 | lon4_deg = 57.08 | <!--fifth label/marker--> | label5 = 5 | position5 = left | lat5_deg = 24.52 | lon5_deg = 52.05 | <!--sixth label/marker--> | label6 = 6 | position6 = left | lat6_deg = 5.76 | lon6_deg = 100.07 }} The '''2008 submarine cable disruptions''' were three separate incidents of major damage to submarine optical communication cables around the world. The first incident caused damage involving up to five high-speed [[Internet]] [[submarine communications cable]]s in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and [[Middle East]] from 23 January to 4 February 2008, causing internet disruptions and slowdowns for users in the Middle East and [[India]].<ref name="Khaleej_Times">{{cite news|title=Cable damage hits one million Internet Users |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?section=theuae&xfile=data/theuae/2008/february/theuae_february121.xml |work=Khaleej News |date=2008-02-04 |accessdate=2008-02-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209140523/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?section=theuae&xfile=data%2Ftheuae%2F2008%2Ffebruary%2Ftheuae_february121.xml |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The incident called into doubt the safety of the undersea portion of the Internet cable system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/04/technology/cables.php |title=Ruptures call safety of Internet cables into question |work=International Herald Tribune |date=2008-02-05 |accessdate=5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206083645/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/04/technology/cables.php |archivedate=6 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In late February there was another outage, this time affecting a fiber optic connection between [[Singapore]] and [[Jakarta]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thejakartapost.com/news/2008/02/29/internet-capacity-down-10.html |title=Internet capacity down to 10% |work=The Jakarta Post |date=2008-02-29 |accessdate=1 March 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303185053/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/02/29/internet-capacity-down-10.html |archivedate=3 March 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
On 19 December, [[Fiber-Optic Link Around the Globe|FLAG FEA]], [[GO-1]], [[SEA-ME-WE 3]], and [[SEA-ME-WE 4]] were all cut.<ref>{{cite news|first=Malcolm |last=Fried |author2=Klemming, Lars |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=ayPbWf_7l17w |title=Severed Cables in Mediterranean Disrupt Communication (Update4) |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2008-12-19 |accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081219/local/go-submarine-cable-fault-part-of-wider-number-between-italy-and-egypt |title=GO submarine cable fault part of wider disruption between Italy and Egypt |publisher=timesofmalta.com |date=2008-12-19 |accessdate=2009-01-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081225171226/http://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081219/local/go-submarine-cable-fault-part-of-wider-number-between-italy-and-egypt| archivedate= 25 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Telecom_Paper" />
==Cables damaged==
===23 January=== Although it was not reported at the time, there was a cut off of [[FALCON (cable system)|FALCON]] on 23 January.<ref name="Khaleej_Times"/> The FALCON cable system connects several countries in the [[Persian Gulf]] and India.
===30 January=== On 30 January 2008, news agencies reported Internet services were widely disrupted in the Middle East and in the [[Indian subcontinent]] following damage to the [[SEA-ME-WE 4]] and FLAG Telecom cables in the Mediterranean Sea.<ref name="Khaleej_Times" /> The damage to the two systems occurred separately several kilometers apart near [[Alexandria]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Repairs begin on Middle East Web cable |work=[[The Associated Press]] |accessdate=2008-02-18 |date=2008-02-05 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.internet.ap/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209142307/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.internet.ap/index.html |archivedate=2008-02-09 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
While the respective contributions of the two cable systems to this [[Internet blackout|blackout]] is unclear, network outage graphs show anomalies at 0430 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] and again at 0800 UTC.<ref name="Renesys">{{cite web | url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2008/01/mediterranean_cable_break_1.shtml#more | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080203133228/http://www.renesys.com/blog/2008/01/mediterranean_cable_break_1.shtml#more | archivedate=2008-02-03 | title=Mediterranean Cable Break | accessdate=2008-01-31 | last=Zmijewski | first=Earl | date=2008-01-30 | work=Renesys Blog | publisher=Renesys}}</ref> The cause of the damage to SEA-ME-WE 4 or FLAG has not been declared by either cable operator.<ref name="khaleejnoships">{{cite news|title=Ships did not cause Internet cable damage |work=Khaleej Times Online |accessdate=2008-02-03 |date=2008-02-03 |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data/theworld/2008/February/theworld_February77.xml&section=theworld&col |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206083906/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data%2Ftheworld%2F2008%2FFebruary%2Ftheworld_February77.xml&section=theworld&col |archivedate=6 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A number of sources speculated these were caused by a dragging ship [[anchor]] near Alexandria. The Egyptian Maritime Transport Ministry reviewed one day of complete video footage beginning 12 hours before and through 12 hours after the service disruption, concluding the cause of damage was not surface craft as no ships were traced sailing through the area of the alleged wire damage.<ref name="TOI">{{cite news| title=Cable damage hits Internet connectivity | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | accessdate=2008-01-31 | date=2008-01-31 | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Cable_damage_hits_Internet_connectivity/articleshow/2745082.cms }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/02/04/2153455.htm |title=Ships did not cut internet cables: Egypt |date=2008-02-04 |work=ABC News |accessdate=5 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206081424/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/02/04/2153455.htm |archivedate=6 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="BBC_News" /> The Kuwaitis also do not directly charge seafaring vessels, instead referring to "weather conditions and maritime traffic."<ref name="AFP">{{cite news|author=Agence France Press |title=Indian outsourcing sector hit by Internet disruption |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gadarOY4frbM-XSyXS0_wMfxpHig |publisher=[[Google News]] |date=2008-01-31 |accessdate=2008-01-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080203184552/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gadarOY4frbM-XSyXS0_wMfxpHig |archivedate=3 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> [[The Economist]] reported that an earthquake may have caused the cable to fault.
====Effects==== Disruptions of 70 percent in [[Egypt]] and 60 percent in [[India]] were reported, along with problems in [[Afghanistan-AWCC]], [[Bahrain]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Kuwait]], [[Maldives]], [[Pakistan]], [[Qatar]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="BBC_News">{{cite news | title=Severed cables disrupt Internet | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7218008.stm | work=[[BBC News]] | date=2008-01-31 | accessdate=2008-01-31| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080131231934/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7218008.stm| archivedate= 31 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Cable Break Causes Wide Internet Outage | url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/technology/AP-Internet-Outages.html | date=2008-02-01 | author=Associated Press | author-link=Associated Press | work=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=2008-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Broken Submarine Cable Affects Raajje Online And Wataniya |url=http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=4103 |date=2008-02-04 |author=Minivannews.com |work=Minivannews.com |accessdate=2008-02-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205042500/http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=4103 |archivedate=2008-02-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
1.7 million Internet users in the [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]] were affected by the Internet disruption. Mahesh Jaishanker, an executive director for [[Du (telco)|Du]], said, “The submarine cable cuts in FLAG Europe-Asia cable 8.3 km away from Alexandria, Egypt and [[SEA-ME-WE 4]] affected at least 60 million users in India, 12 million in Pakistan, six million in Egypt and 4.7 million in Saudi Arabia.”<ref name="Khaleej_Times" /> A router for a university in [[Tehran]] was not responding, causing some reports of a total loss of connectivity for [[Iran]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=15a_1201978059 |title=Third Internet Cable cut — Tehran 100% Outage |date=2008-02-02 |accessdate=5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209163116/http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=15a_1201978059 |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internettrafficreport.com/asia.htm|title=Details for Asia /// Internet Traffic Report|accessdate=2008-02-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080208094725/http://www.internettrafficreport.com/asia.htm| archivedate= 8 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, the Iranian [[embassy]] in [[Abu Dhabi]] reported that "everything was fine."<ref>Dylan Bowman.[http://www.arabianbusiness.com/510232-flag-plays-down-net-blackout-conspiracy-theories?ln=en Flag plays down net blackout conspiracy theories], ArabianBusiness.com, 4 February 2008.</ref><ref name="albawaba" /> Additional reports and analysis showed that while Iran was affected, it "fared much better" than many other countries in the same geographic area.<ref name="disconnected1">{{cite web |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2008/02/attention_iran_is_not_disconne_1.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207031404/http://www.renesys.com/blog/2008/02/attention_iran_is_not_disconne_1.shtml |archivedate=2008-02-07|title=ATTENTION: Iran is not disconnected!}}</ref><ref name="mediterranean1">{{cite web|url=https://confluence.slac.stanford.edu/display/IEPM/Effects+of+Fibre+Outage+through+Mediterranean|title=Effects of Fibre Outage through Mediterranean| accessdate= 9 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
On 1 February 2008, [[Videsh Sanchar Nigam Limited|VSNL]], a leading communications solutions provider in [[India]], confirmed that the company restored a majority of its [[Internet Protocol|IP]] connectivity into the [[MENA]] region within 24 hours of the [[Egypt]] cable breakdown. Services were largely restored within 24 hours of the cable cut by diverting traffic through the TIC and [[SEA-ME-WE 3]] cables.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fibresystems.org/cws/article/yournews/32739 |title=VNSL restores services after cable break |date=2008-02-01 |accessdate=7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209125550/http://fibresystems.org/cws/article/yournews/32739 |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===1 February=== Two days after the initial break, it was reported that the FALCON cable was cut between [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Oman]] and [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]].<ref name="Khaleej_Times"/> This cut was between different landing points than the 23 January cut, FLAG Telecom issued a press release later, stating the "'''[[FALCON (cable system)|FALCON cable]]''' is reported cut at 0559 hrs [[GMT]] on 1 February 2008. Location of cut is at 56 km from Dubai, UAE on segment between UAE and Oman".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flagtelecom.com/index.cfm?channel=4328&NewsID=27492 |title=Flag Telecom cut cable update 1 |date=2008-02-06 |accessdate=5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204081719/http://www.flagtelecom.com/index.cfm?channel=4328&NewsID=27492 |archivedate=4 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> This cut was caused by an abandoned anchor weighing 5-6 tonnes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flagtelecom.com/index.cfm?channel=4328&NewsID=27493 |title=Flag Telecom cut cable update 2 |date=2008-02-07 |accessdate=8 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208124925/http://www.flagtelecom.com/index.cfm?channel=4328&NewsID=27493 |archivedate=8 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://government.zdnet.com/?p=3648 |title=Anchor found at cable cut site |work=CNET Networks |date=2008-02-06 |accessdate=8 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209122425/http://government.zdnet.com/?p=3648 |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===3 February=== On 3 February 2008, [[Qtel]] reported that a cable called '''[[DOHA-HALOUL]]''' connecting [[Qatar]] to the United Arab Emirates had been damaged, causing disruptions in already damaged Middle Eastern communication networks. It became the fourth cable to be damaged in 5 days.<ref name="khaleejnoships" /> The location of the break was between the [[Qatari]] island of [[Halul Island|Haloul]] and the UAE island of [[Das (island)|Das]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/510132-internet-problems-continue-with-fourth-cable-break?ln=en |title=Internet problems continue with fourth cable break |date=2008-02-03 |accessdate=5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211183123/http://www.arabianbusiness.com/510132-internet-problems-continue-with-fourth-cable-break?ln=en |archivedate=11 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The problem was said to be related to the power system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mathaba.net/news/?x=580660|title=4th Undersea Cable Break: Between Qatar and UAE| date=2008-02-04| accessdate= 5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
===4 February=== On 4 February 2008 the ''[[Khaleej Times]]'' reported that [[SEA-ME-WE 4]] had also been damaged at another location, near [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]]. The date of this damage was not given.<ref name="Khaleej_Times" />
===19 December=== On 19 December 2008 [[France Telecom]] issued a press release stating that the FLAG Telecom, [[SEA-ME-WE 4]], and [[SEA-ME-WE 3]] cables, linking [[Alexandria|Alexandria, Egypt]], [[Sicily]], and [[Malta]], had been cut by either bad weather conditions or a ship's [[anchor]], resulting in substantial slowdowns in communication traffic, with [[Egypt]] experiencing an overall 80% reduction in [[Internet]] capacity.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Three undersea cables cut: traffic greatly disturbed between Europe and Asia/Near East zone |date= 19 December 2008 |work= Press release |publisher= France Telecom |url= http://www.orange.com/en_EN/press/press_releases/cp081219en.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081221171256/http://www.orange.com/en_EN/press/press_releases/cp081219en.html |archivedate= 21 December 2008 |accessdate= 5 October 2013 }}</ref><ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/internetNews/idUSTRE4BJ0FV20081220|title=UPDATE<!--SIC--> 3-Undersea cable breaks cut Internet in Mideast, Asia|author=James Regan|publisher=Reuters|date=2008-12-20|accessdate=2008-01-23}}</ref> France Telecom expects SEA-ME-WE 4 will be repaired first, then SEA-ME-WE 3, then FLAG, and that repairs should be concluded by 31 December. The break disrupted 75% of communication between the [[Middle East]] and [[Asia]] and the rest of the world. The breaks caused companies including [[Vodafone]], [[Verizon Communications]], [[Portugal Telecom]], [[GO (Malta)|GO]] and [[France Telecom]] to experience disruption in their systems and forced them to reroute communications through different means. Others, such as [[AT&T]], also received reports of service disruption.<ref name=Reuters /> The rerouting of these communications caused large slowdowns in some areas. [[Interoute]] director Jonathan Wright stated that "You can reroute the data through other cables, but that increases traffic and can potentially create bottlenecks, so Internet connections may slow down and some phone calls could get disrupted."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=ayPbWf_7l17w&refer=europe|title=Severed Cables in Mediterranean Disrupt Communication|author=Fried, Malcolm|author2=Lars Klemming|last-author-amp=yes|publisher=[[Bloomberg Television|Bloomberg]]|date=2008-12-19|accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref> The [[GO-1]] cable connecting Malta and Sicily was also cut.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081219/local/go-submarine-cable-fault-part-of-wider-number-between-italy-and-egypt|title=GO submarine cable fault part of wider disruption between Italy and Egypt|publisher=[[The Times (Malta)|Times of Malta]]|date=2008-12-19|accessdate=2008-12-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081225171226/http://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081219/local/go-submarine-cable-fault-part-of-wider-number-between-italy-and-egypt| archivedate= 25 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Telecom_Paper">{{cite news |title= Mediterrean submarine cables are cut, affecting internet |work= Telecom Paper |url= http://www.telecompaper.com/news/article.aspx?cid=650982|date=19 December 2008 |accessdate= 20 December 2008 }}</ref>
==Cause of cable breaks==
===Anchors=== These disruptions are attributed by some officials to accidents involving ships' [[anchor]]s,<ref name="TOI"/><ref name="BBC_News" /> but reviews of surveillance footage of the area by [[Egypt]]ian [[government|authorities]] revealed no ships in the area.<ref name="khaleejnoships" /> However, FLAG Telecom indicated that the cut to the Falcon cable between the United Arab Emirates and Oman was caused by an abandoned anchor weighing five to six tons.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/infotech/view/20080207-117457/Ships-anchor-cut-Gulf-Internet-cable----company |title=Breaking News / Infotech |date=2008-02-07 |accessdate=7 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209022738/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/infotech/view/20080207-117457/Ships-anchor-cut-Gulf-Internet-cable----company |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In mid April two ships were impounded in connection with the FLAG Telecom outages near Dubai. They were charged with improperly dropping anchor in the area of the cuts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2008/Apr/13/ships_impounded_in_middle_east_cable_cuts.html|title=Ships Impounded in Middle East Cable Cuts|date=2008-04-13|accessdate=2008-04-14|author=Rich Miller|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417070508/http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2008/Apr/13/ships_impounded_in_middle_east_cable_cuts.html|archivedate=2008-04-17|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
The 19 December breaks were reported to be caused either by bad weather or a ship's anchor, though the bad weather was just a possibility and the anchor a much more likely occurrence.<ref name=Reuters />
===Common occurrence=== According to Stephen Beckert, a senior analyst at [[TeleGeography]], the events are far less exceptional than they seem because cable cuts happen all the time. Beckert argues that "only the first two cuts had any serious impact on the Internet," and this drew public attention to other cable cuts that would not normally have been newsworthy. According to Beckert, cable cuts happen "on average once every three days." He further noted that there are 25 large ships that do nothing but fix cable cuts and bends, and that such cuts are usually the result of cables rubbing against rocks on the sea floor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2008/02/who-cut-the-cab.html |title=Cable Cut Fever Grips the Web |work=Wired News |date=2008-02-06 |accessdate=7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208115949/http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2008/02/who-cut-the-cab.html |archivedate=8 February 2008 |deadurl=no |first=Ryan |last=Singel |df= }}</ref>
According to [[Global Marine Systems]], "Undersea cable damage is hardly rare—indeed, more than 50 repair operations were mounted in the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] alone last year". While a cut in a cable crossing the Atlantic has "no significant effect" due to the many alternate cables, only a handful of Internet cables serve the Middle East. These disruptions are only noticeable because of the small number of cables.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=4244474&page=1 |title=Analyzing the Internet Collapse |date=2008-02-05 |work=ABC News |accessdate=7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208125208/http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=4244474&page=1 |archivedate=8 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Conspiracy theories== Since [[Israel]] and [[Iraq]] were not affected<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mathaba.net/news/?x=580589|title=One Internet cut explained, but four others still a mystery|date=2008-02-07| accessdate= 7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> by the communications blackout, [[conspiracy theories]] have begun to spread throughout the Internet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iOI6IbGndscHLRd4lRiKCqGksCSg |author=Agence France Press |title=One Internet cut explained, but four others still a mystery |date=2008-02-08 |accessdate=7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080210044431/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iOI6IbGndscHLRd4lRiKCqGksCSg |archivedate=10 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="globalresearch">{{cite news|url=http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=7987 |title=Three Internet Cables Slashed in a Week: Has Iran lost all Internet Connectivity? |date=2008-02-03 |work=Global Research |accessdate=5 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306055555/http://globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=7987 |archivedate=6 March 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.engadget.com/2008/02/05/fourth-undersea-cable-cut-near-uae-suspicions-rise | title= Fourth undersea cable cut near UAE, suspicions rise |date = 2008-02-05 | accessdate = 2008-02-07 | work = Engadget| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080209202325/http://www.engadget.com/2008/02/05/fourth-undersea-cable-cut-near-uae-suspicions-rise| archivedate= 9 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.news.com/8301-10784_3-9865263-7.html |title=The newest Internet whodunnit? Who cut the cables?| date = 2008-02-05 | accessdate = 2008-02-07 | work = [[CNET.com]]}}</ref><ref name="albawaba">{{cite news| title = Who cuts undersea cables in the Middle East? | date = 2008-02-05 | accessdate = 2008-02-06 | work = Al Bawaba | url = http://www.albawaba.com/en/countries/UAE/221875| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080207171536/http://www.albawaba.com/en/countries/UAE/221875| archivedate= 7 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref>
On 6 February, theories that the disruption in these cables was related to an economic confrontation between the United States and Iran appeared in an opinion piece on Dow Jones Marketwatch.<ref name="interruption1">{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/middle-east-internet-interruption-looks/story.aspx?guid=%7B6FD0D324%2D8FF9%2D4900%2DBCA9%2D614914BA3E87%7D |title=Middle East Internet interruption looks fishy |date=2008-02-08 |accessdate=9 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209113151/http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/middle-east-internet-interruption-looks/story.aspx?guid=%7B6FD0D324-8FF9-4900-BCA9-614914BA3E87%7D |archivedate=9 February 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> This article points out that the disruption or damage to these cables preceded the intended launch of the [[Iranian oil bourse]] on Kish Island between 1 and 11 February. The launch of this bourse, which was intended to broker sales of oil denominated in euros (sometimes called "[[petroeuro]]s") had been interpreted by some as an attempt by Iran to inflict additional damage to the value of the dollar by reducing the volume of oil which is traded in "[[petrodollar]]s".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energybulletin.net/7707.html |title=Petrodollar Warfare: Dollars, Euros and the Upcoming Iranian Oil Bourse |date=2005-08-02 |accessdate=9 February 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080202025907/http://www.energybulletin.net/7707.html |archivedate=2 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Given the potential economic damage of euro-denominated oil sales in the context of on-going dollar inflation, as well as the large number of cables which appear to have been disrupted or damaged, Marketwatch's John Dvorak has written that the U.S. can expect to be blamed for the disruptions.<ref name="interruption1"/>
According to this sabotage theory, the damaged cables and the resulting Internet disruptions would destroy confidence in the ability of the [[Iranian Oil Bourse]] to execute trades, thereby thwarting the establishment of an alternative to dollar-denominated oil sales. In fact, Iran suffered very little from the outages, which primarily affected America's allies in the region (see 'Effects' above).<ref name="disconnected1"/><ref name="mediterranean1"/> Bloggers have also suggested that the cable disruptions were a cover for [[NSA]] installing taps on the lines for eavesdropping.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2008/02/who-cut-the-cab/ | work=Wired | first=Ryan | last=Singel | title=Cable Cut Fever Grips the Web | date=6 February 2008}}</ref>
On Monday, 18 February, the [[International Telecommunication Union]] said that the damage could have been an act of sabotage. The [[UN]] agency's head of development, [[Sami al-Murshed]] was quoted, "We do not want to preempt the results of ongoing investigations, but we do not rule out that a deliberate act of sabotage caused the damage to the undersea cables over two weeks ago."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/technology/saboteurs-may-have-cut-mideast-telecom-cables-un-agency-20080219-1sv3.html |title=Saboteurs may have cut Mideast telecom cables: UN agency |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald |date=2008-02-19 |accessdate=22 December 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231001343/http://news.smh.com.au/technology/saboteurs-may-have-cut-mideast-telecom-cables-un-agency-20080219-1sv3.html |archivedate=31 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> This was subsequently shown false, as on April 18, two ships parked in a restricted area during a storm, cutting the cables with their anchors. One sailor from each vessel was detained, as were both vessels. The vessels were subsequently released after restitution for the damaged cables was secured.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailytech.com/Two+Ships+Impounded+After+Investigation+into+Undersea+Cable+Cuts/article11480.htm |title=Two Ships Impounded After Investigation into Undersea Cable Cuts |last=McGlaun |first=Shane |date=2008-04-14 |website=[[DailyTech]]}}</ref>

"'''Alabama'''" is a composition written by [[John Coltrane]] that appears on his album ''[[Live at Birdland (1964 John Coltrane album)|Live at Birdland]]'' (1963). It was written in response to the [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]] on September 15, 1963, an attack by the [[Ku Klux Klan]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] that killed four [[African-American]] girls.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/library/livejazz7.htm |title=All About Jazz: "The Top Ten Best Live Jazz Recordings - #7" |access-date=2009-01-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918203256/http://www.allaboutjazz.com/library/livejazz7.htm |archive-date=2008-09-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.orjazzm.pl/muzyka/john-coltrane-alabama/707 |title=John Colrane - Alabama |access-date=2010-07-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308211155/http://www.orjazzm.pl/muzyka/john-coltrane-alabama/707 |archive-date=2012-03-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Coltrane's Quartet performed this piece on television for an episode of [[Jazz Casual]] in 1963.
"Alabama" was performed on the 2016 [[Jack DeJohnette]] album ''[[In Movement]]'' with two musicians whose fathers played on the original version--bassist [[Matthew Garrison]] and saxophonist [[Ravi Coltrane]].
==See also== * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement in popular culture]]

{{Infobox music festival | name = Amfiteatrof Music Festival | image = | image_size = | alt = 2017 edition official logo | caption = ''2017 edition official logo'' | genre = [[Classical music|Classical]]; [[chamber music]]; [[musical theatre]] | dates = June/July - September | location = [[Levanto, Liguria|Levanto]], [[Bonassola]], [[Framura]], [[Brugnato]] and other [[Liguria|ligurian ''Comuni'']] in the [[Province of La Spezia]], Italy | years_active = 1992 - present | founders = | attendance = | capacity = | website = www.festivalamfiteatrof.com | organizer = Associazione Massimo Amfiteatrof Levanto }} '''Amfiteatrof Music Festival''' (previously known as Festival Massimo Amfiteatrof) is a [[Classical music|classical]] and [[chamber music]] festival based in [[Levanto, Liguria|Levanto]], an Italian ''Comune'' in the [[ligurian Riviera]], between [[Genoa]] and [[La Spezia]], since 1992.
The festival pays tribute to [[Massimo Amfiteatrof]] (born Maksim Aleksandrovich Amfiteatrov), one of the greatest cellist of the 20th century, dubbed as the "Cellists' [[Enrico Caruso|Caruso]]" (Italian: "''il Caruso dei Violoncellisti''"), who moved from [[St. Petersburg]] to Italy in the early 1920s, settling first in Cavi, a ''frazione'' of [[Lavagna]], and then in Levanto, where he died in 1990. During his lifetime Amfiteatrof worked with [[Arturo Toscanini]] and [[Fabrizio De André]] and collaborated with [[EIAR]] and subsequently with [[RAI]].http://www.cellist.nl/database/showcellist.asp?id=1608 Massimo Amfitheatrof
The Festival has been being organized by Associazione Festival Massimo Amfiteatrof Levanto since its beginning and the administrative board is currently led by president Angela Fenwick {{cite web|url= http://www.festivalamfiteatrof.com/|title=Cariche dell'Associazione|work=festivalamfiteatrof.com|accessdate=11 July 2016}} == The Festival == Founded two years after Amfiteatrof's death, Amfiteatrof Music Festival offers every summer, from july to september, a considerable number of concerts and music performances. The festival is well known for the architectonic, historic and geographic hallmarks of the sites where they are held: old churches, castles, noble houses, small scenic squares (the so-called "''piazzettes''"), old towns and convents, gardens, parks and amazing heights and cliffs overlooking the [[Ligurian sea]]. Partly due to these features, a large number of tourists, including foreigners, regularly attend the concerts during the summer season in the Levanto area, near to the [[Cinque Terre]] towns.
[[File:Levanto-IMG_1295.JPG|thumb|right|0.3| Bell tower of St. Andrew's Church (''Chiesa di S. Andrea'') in [[Levanto, Liguria|Levanto]], the main location of the Festival.]] All the concerts are free entry with the exception of those requiring an early reservation, such as premieres, debuts, theatre shows and very famous musicians' recitals, often located in prestigious sites (for example, the gardens of Villa Agnelli in Levanto, which belonged to [[Gianni Agnelli]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.zenazone.it/genova/blog/2015/07/03/festival-massimo-amfiteatrof-a-levanto/|title=Festival Massimo Amfiteatrof a Levanto|work=www.zenazone.it|accessdate=11 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304142031/http://www.zenazone.it/genova/blog/2015/07/03/festival-massimo-amfiteatrof-a-levanto/|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}
[[File:Massimoamfi.jpg|thumb|left|0.3| The Festival is dedicated to [[Massimo Amfiteatrof]], known as the "''Cellists' [[Enrico Caruso|Caruso]]''"]] Amfiteatrof Music Festival features classical and chamber music performances by many internationally renowned soloists and ensembles. Formative and didactic workshops, cultural lectures, children theatre and contemporary experimental performances, which blend music with other arts, also make the event. Many musicians and orchestra conductors collaborated with Amfiteatrof during his lifetime or were tied with him from caring relationships and that's one of the main reasons why they frequently come back in Levanto to perform again. During the early years the major place of the Festival was the Convento della Santissima Annunziata in Levanto. Later on, it has been moved to the outside yard of St. Andrew's Church (Chiesa di Sant'Andrea). Nowadays there are more locations than before - both internal and external ones - in Levanto, but also in the nearby villages of the Province of La Spezia, such as [[Framura]], [[Bonassola]] (on the Riviera) and [[Brugnato]] (within the inner [[Province of La Spezia|Province]]) == Artists and performers == Popular and recurrent performers of the Festival are: Camerata RCO (soloists of the [[Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra]]), ensemble-in-residence from 2009 to 2015,{{cite web|url= http://www.gazzettadellaspezia.it/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=39130:festival-amfiteatrof,-nuova-esibizione-della-camerata-rco&Itemid=10038|title=Festival Amfiteatrof, nuova esibizione della Camerata RCO|work=www.gazzettadellaspezia.it|accessdate=11 July 2016}} [[Dynamis Ensemble]], [[Elena Denisova]], [[Moni Ovadia]],{{cite web|url=http://laspezia.mentelocale.it/32465-moni-ovadia-al-festival-amfiteatrof-2011-il-programma/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719050907/http://laspezia.mentelocale.it/32465-moni-ovadia-al-festival-amfiteatrof-2011-il-programma/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 July 2011|title=Moni Ovadia al Festival Amfiteatrof 2011: il programma|work=www.laspezia.mentelocale.it/|accessdate=11 July 2016}} [[Alexander Lonquich]],{{cite web|url= http://www.laspeziaoggi.it/2013/08/22/alexander-lonquich-a-levanto/|title=Alexander Lonquich a Levanto|work=www.laspeziaoggi.it|accessdate=11 July 2016}} the chamber musicians of [[Maggio Musicale Fiorentino]], [[Palo Alto Chamber Orchestra]], [[Andrea Bacchetti]], [[Mariangela Vacatello]], [[Domenico Nordio]], [[Bruno Canino]] - Antonio Ballista piano duo {{cite web|url= http://www.ligurianews.com/la-spezia/cultura/4595497/festival-massimo-amfiteatrof-tocca-al-duo-pianistico-ballista-e-canino|title=Festival Massimo Amfiteatrof, tocca al duo pianistico Ballista e Canino|work=www.ligurianews.com|accessdate=11 July 2016}} and many other popular artists == Main locations == Amfiteatrof Music Festival locations are in Levanto and in the nearby ''Comuni''. * in Levanto: St. Andrew's Church (''Chiesa di Sant'Andrea''), St. Jack's Oratory (''Oratorio di San Giacomo''), Clarisse's Convent (''Convento delle Clarisse''), the gardens outside Villa Agnelli, ''Piazzetta della Loggia'', ''Piazzetta della Compera'', ''Convento della Santissima Annunziata'' and ''frazioni'' of Montale and Chiesanuova * in [[Bonassola]]: St. Catherine of Alexandria's Church (''Chiesa di Santa Caterina d'Alessandria''), St. Erasmus's Oratory (''Oratorio di Sant'Erasmo'') * in [[Framura]]: St. Martin's Church (''Chiesa di San Martino'') in the ''frazione'' of Costa. Amfiteatrof Music Festival concerts or musical events also take place in the pedestrian paths and in the cliffs upon the Ligurian Sea, near to the aforementioned ''Comuni''. ==See also== * [[Massimo Amfiteatrof]] * [[Levanto, Liguria|Levanto]] * [[Liguria]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://festivalamfiteatrof.com festivalamfiteatrof.com] (Festival Massimo Amfiteatrof official website) {{Authority control}} [[Category:Liguria]] [[Category:Music of Liguria]] [[Category:Chamber music festivals]] [[Category:Classical music festivals in Italy]] [[Category:Cultural festivals in Italy]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 1992]]

{{Infobox Film Festival | name = Animation Block Party | image = Animation Block Logo.jpg | caption = | number = 100+ | location = [[New York City|New York, NY]] | founded = 2004 | language = International | website = [http://www.animationblock.com/ AnimationBlock.com] }}
'''Animation Block Party''' is an annual [[animation]] [[film festival]] in [[New York City]], usually held over three days in late July.
==History== ===Brooklyn=== On September 9, 2004, Casey Safron, the event's founder, curated the first Animation Block Party, held in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]]. The event was rated one of the top five smaller film festivals in the area.<ref>[http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/columns/topfive/9802/ "Top Five Smaller Film Festivals,"] ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'', May 21, 2005.</ref> The following year, Animation Block Party opened for international submissions, acquired corporate sponsorship and expanded to become an annual festival with juried awards and prizes for participating animators.<ref name="ackerman">McCarton Ackerman, [http://www.greenpointnews.com/entertainment/3601/animation-block-party-arrives-in-williamsburg "Animation Block Party Arrives in Williamsburg,"] ''Greenpoint Gazette'', July 28, 2011.</ref><ref>Sarah Baisley, [http://www.awn.com/news/events/nyc-animation-block-party-screening "NYC Animation Block Party Screening,"] [[Animation World Network]], December 1, 2005.</ref> In 2006, the festival expanded to its current multi-day format,<ref>Chermelle D. Edwards, [http://offmanhattan.com/2009/07/24/animation-film-festival-brooklyn/ "Get Animated About This Film Festival,"] offManhattan, July 24, 2009.</ref> drawing an average of over 2,500 attendees per summer.<ref name="ackerman"/><ref name="cbs">"Person Pinball," [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504784_162-20086837-10391705.html CBS News]</ref> Based in Brooklyn, the event shows animation from both U.S. and international filmmakers.<ref>Angela Ashman, [http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-07-27/voice-choices/cartoon-central/ "Cartoon Central,"] ''[[The Village Voice]]'', July 27, 2010.</ref> In 2011, Animation Block Party received 654 submissions, screening 97 of them at their 8th annual festival.<ref name="cbs"/><ref>Inamdar Shaker, [http://www.irealities.com/ "iRealities: 2D 3D Animation, Visual Effects (VFX), and Top Animation Studio in India,"] ''[[iRealities Technology|Animation]]'', Oct 17, 2017.</ref>
Animation Block Party expanded to a four-day festival in 2013, including an opening night concert with performances by [[Adam Green (musician)|Adam Green]], [[Hooray for Earth]], [[Tim Harrington (singer)|Tim Harrington]], and others, and exclusive animation from [[Cartoon Network]], [[Nickelodeon]] and [[Pixar]].<ref>Zubair Siddique, [http://www.metro.us/newyork/events/animation-block-party-opening-night "Animation Block Party Opening Night,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821204031/http://www.metro.us/newyork/events/animation-block-party-opening-night |date=2013-08-21 }} ''[[Metro International|Metro]]'', July 15, 2013.</ref>
===Around the US=== Animation Block Party has held traveling shows in Philadelphia,<ref>Matthew Schantz, [http://archives.citypaper.net/articles/2009/05/28/animation-block-party "Animation Block Party: NYC's animated celebration wises up and comes to Philly,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909081709/http://archives.citypaper.net/articles/2009/05/28/animation-block-party |date=September 9, 2011 }} ''[[Philadelphia City Paper]]'', May 26, 2009.</ref> Austin,<ref>[http://www.nowplayingaustin.com/event/detail/440124241/Best_of_Animation_Block_Party "Best of Animation Block Party,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415201235/http://www.nowplayingaustin.com/event/detail/440124241/Best_of_Animation_Block_Party |date=2014-04-15 }} NowPlayingAustin.com, November 16, 2009.</ref> Omaha,<ref>[http://www.filmstreams.org/filmstreams_calendar.aspx?ID=851 "Animation Block Party: Animation for Kids,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104162041/http://www.filmstreams.org/filmstreams_calendar.aspx?ID=851 |date=January 4, 2012 }} [[Film Streams]], 2011.</ref> Boston<ref>Jim Landry, [https://archive.is/20120707200118/http://digboston.com/experience/2009/03/19896/ "Animation Block Party,"] ''[[Boston's Weekly Dig]]'', March 24, 2009.</ref> and Los Angeles, including a 2014 Valentine's Day showcase at [[The Troubadour, West Hollywood|The Troubadour]] in West Hollywood, which included original shorts from MTV Other, [[Nickelodeon]], [[Six Point Harness]], Loopdeloop and [[Bill Plympton]].<ref>Laura Gaddy, [http://racketmag.com/culture/animation-block-party-valentines-day-showcase/ "Animation Block Party Valentine’s Day Showcase,"] ''Racket'', February 14, 2014.</ref>
== Production == Animation Block Party also has a production division called Animation Block, which has turned several pieces from the festival into series.<ref>[http://animationblock.com/images/press/ABP_NYTIMES08.jpg "Animation Block Party,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919093613/http://animationblock.com/images/press/ABP_NYTIMES08.jpg |date=September 19, 2015 }} ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 25, 2008.</ref> In 2008, Animation Block produced the series "Perfectland" for [[MTV]], which premiered on April 22, 2008.<ref name="indie">[http://www.indiewire.com/article/ny_ny_animation_block_party_sets_record_lou_reed_visits_film_forum_and_linc "Animation Block Party Sets Record, Lou Reed Visits Film Forum, and Lincoln Center Celebrates,"] ''IndieWire'', July 31, 2008.</ref> In 2009, Animation Block produced the series "Breakfast" for the [[Sundance Channel (United States)|Sundance Channel]],<ref name="indie"/> as well as a 28 episode web series for [[My Damn Channel]].<ref>[http://www.clicker.com/blog/animation-block-review-10338.html "Animation Block Proves the Internet Can Be Better Than TV,"] [[Clicker.com]], March 21, 2011.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|3}}
==External links== * [http://www.animationblock.com Festival Website]

(PFLP-GC claim) |casualties2 = 9–15 killed, 10 captured{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/explosion-near-tal-tamir-and-is-captures-10-militants-in-the-yarmouk-camp/ |title=Explosion near Tal Tamir, and IS captures 10 militants in the Yarmouk camp |author=Master |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415174905/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/explosion-near-tal-tamir-and-is-captures-10-militants-in-the-yarmouk-camp/ |archivedate=15 April 2015 |df= }} |casualties3 = 5 killed |casualties4 = 8–13 civilians executed by ISIL{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/daesh-kills-13-yarmouk-refugee-camp-activists-678456|title=Daesh kills 13 in Yarmouk refugee camp: activists|work=Al Bawaba|accessdate=11 April 2015}}
38 killed overall (8 civilians; [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights|SOHR]])
4,000 civilians displaced{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/04/yarmouk-palestinians-waiting-death-knock-150426073555865.html|title=Yarmouk's Palestinians: 'Waiting for death to knock'|publisher=|accessdate=9 May 2015}} }} {{Campaignbox Syrian Civil War}} {{Campaignbox Rif Dimashq Campaign}} The '''Battle of Yarmouk Camp (2015)''' was a battle that broke out in April 2015, during the [[Syrian Civil War]], when the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] stormed the rebel-held Yarmouk Camp. The [[Yarmouk Camp]] is a district of [[Damascus]] that is home to the largest community of [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] refugees in [[Syria]].{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jevFaBhWboO5_Mqrgpk7ycShh4RQ?docId=CNG.493b5bfef777e0c4e6e2103828c1614e.1b1 |accessdate=5 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219055345/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jevFaBhWboO5_Mqrgpk7ycShh4RQ?docId=CNG.493b5bfef777e0c4e6e2103828c1614e.1b1 |archivedate=19 February 2014 }} ==Background== {{further|Battle of Yarmouk Camp (December 2012)}} On 17 December 2012, the [[Free Syrian Army]] and anti-government Palestinians took control of the camp. After subsequent heavy fighting, the FSA and the Syrian Army agreed to leave Yarmouk as a neutral, demilitarized zone, but the camp remained besieged and sporadic clashes continued. Syrian government forces besieged Yarmouk for two years, and as a result, approximately 200 people were believed to have died of hunger in 2014.[http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/middle-east/palestinian-refugees-at-yarmouk-are-left-to-their-fate-1.2172106 Palestinian refugees at Yarmouk are left to their fate], irishtimes.com. ==The battle== ===ISIL storms the camp=== On 1 April, [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] militants entered the Yarmouk Refugee Camp from the Hajar Al-Aswad district, but were expelled the next day by Syrian and Palestinian rebels. However, ISIL re-entered the camp on 4 April and took control of 90% of it.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/04/isil-enters-yarmouk-refugee-camp-syria-capital-150403124537528.html|title=ISIL re-enters Yarmouk refugee camp in Syria's capital|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015}} Local recruits were among the ISIL forces—having joined the militants due to anger at being starved by the Syrian government and disliking some of the rebel groups that controlled Yarmouk "for playing politics with the regime rather than confronting it."{{cite news|title=The war against Islamic State (1): Creeping toward Damascus|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21648016-jihadists-advance-syria-poses-difficult-questions-america-creeping|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=[[The Economist]]|date=11 April 2015}} On 5 April, [[Jaysh al-Islam]] claimed that its fighters were refused access to the camp by [[al-Nusra Front]] and that al-Nusra allowed ISIL to enter the camp, which led to some defections from the first party. The al-Nusra Front responded by defending its neutral stance in the conflict{{cite web |url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/jabhat-al-nusra-stands-for-impartiality-and-refuse-the-entry-of-jaysh-al-islam-to-al-yarmouk-refugee-camp/ |title=Jabhat al- Nusra stands for impartiality and refuse the entry of Jaysh al- Islam to al- Yarmouk refugee camp |author=sohranas |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407015704/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/jabhat-al-nusra-stands-for-impartiality-and-refuse-the-entry-of-jaysh-al-islam-to-al-yarmouk-refugee-camp/ |archivedate=7 April 2015 |df= }} and claimed to have mediated a ceasefire. It also denied rumors about the alleged defections.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2015/04/islamic-state-releases-photos-from-yarmouk-palestinian-refugee-camp-in-damascus.php|title=Islamic State releases photos from Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus - The Long War Journal|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015}} Meanwhile, the Army bombed the camp with 13 [[barrel bombs]].{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/13-explosive-barrels-on-the-yarmouk-camp/ |title=13 explosive barrels on the Yarmouk camp |author=Master |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415161007/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/13-explosive-barrels-on-the-yarmouk-camp/ |archivedate=15 April 2015 |df= }} A commander in the [[Aknaf Bait al-Maqdis]] was killed during clashes with ISIL.{{cite web |url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-capital-witnesses-power-outage/ |title=The capital witnesses power outage |author=sohranas |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407015709/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-capital-witnesses-power-outage/ |archivedate=7 April 2015 |df= }} On 6 April, it was reported that about 2,000 people were evacuated from the camp since ISIL's attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/2000-civilians-evacuated-from-syrias-yarmouk/a-18362344|title=2,000 civilians evacuated from Syria′s Yarmouk - News - DW.DE - 05.04.2015|work=DW.DE|accessdate=6 April 2015}} The same day, pro-government Palestinian groups led by the [[Palestine Liberation Army]], the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine|PFLP]], [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command|PFLP-GC]] and [[Fatah al-Intifada]] launched an assault against ISIL. They reportedly captured Morocco Street, Al-Ja’ounah Street and the Martyrs Cemetery and claimed to have killed 36 ISIL militant and controlled 40% of the Yarmouk camp. On 7 April, the fighting had ceased,{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/syria-offers-palestinians-its-firepower-in-yarmuk-battle_1575072.html|title=Syria offers Palestinians its firepower in Yarmuk battle|work=Zee News|accessdate=11 April 2015}} with ISIL in control of 95% of the camp.{{cite web|url=http://www.syrianobserver.com/EN/News/28964/ISIS_Controls_Percent_Yarmouk_Refugee_Camp|title=ISIS Controls 95 Percent of Yarmouk Refugee Camp |author=Al-Souria Net |work=The Syrian Observer|accessdate=11 April 2015}} ===Rebel counterattack=== On 12 April, Jaysh al-Islam and allied forces launched a counterattack on the ISIL-held Hajar al-Aswad district{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Syria_Rebel_Obs/status/587174263653797888|title=Syrian Rebellion Obs on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=19 April 2015}} and reportedly advanced.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Syria_Rebel_Obs/status/587174584086097920|title=Syrian Rebellion Obs on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=19 April 2015}} Jaysh al-Islam also recaptured Al-Zein street in Yarmouk Camp from ISIL, during a nighttime operation.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/587175600831516672|title=Elijah J. Magnier on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=19 April 2015}} By 16 April, ISIL and al-Nusra were still holding 80% of the Yarmouk Camp, after clashes with Aknaf Bait al-Maqdis and other rebels.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/80-of-the-yarmouk-camp-is-under-control-by-the-is/ |title=80% of the Yarmouk camp is under control by the IS |author=Master |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=19 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603091954/http://www.syriahr.com/en/2015/04/80-of-the-yarmouk-camp-is-under-control-by-the-is/ |archivedate=3 June 2015 |df= }} Two days later, fighting between the rebels and ISIL expanded to the neighborhoods of al-Qaboun and Barzah. The rebels captured 9 ISIL militants{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-rebels-and-islamic-battalions-capture-9-is-militants-and-kill-12-others-in-damascus/ |title=The rebels and Islamic battalions capture 9 IS militants and kill 12 others in Damascus |author=sohranas |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=19 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418111743/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-rebels-and-islamic-battalions-capture-9-is-militants-and-kill-12-others-in-damascus/ |archivedate=18 April 2015 |df= }} and killed 12 others.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-death-toll-of-is-rises-to-12-in-damascus-while-hundreds-of-food-baskets-let-in-into-the-south-of-rif-dimashq/ |title=The death toll of IS rises to 12 in Damascus, while hundreds of food baskets let in into the south of Rif Dimashq |author=sohranas |work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights |accessdate=19 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419084927/http://syriahr.com/en/2015/04/the-death-toll-of-is-rises-to-12-in-damascus-while-hundreds-of-food-baskets-let-in-into-the-south-of-rif-dimashq/ |archivedate=19 April 2015 |df= }} On 19 April, an activist reported that ISIL was planning to leave the camp, although they had not yet done so. He also revealed that most of the al-Nusra Front fighters in Yarmouk Camp had defected to ISIL, and that the two groups were closely collaborating in the area. By then, Aknaf Bai al-Maqdis had dissolved and joined Syrian Government forces. By 20 April, the ISIL attack on the two districts had been repelled.{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2015/04/syrian-rebels-defeat-isis-in-damascus/|title=Syrian rebels defeat ISIS in Damascus|work=ARA News|accessdate=9 May 2015}} ==Aftermath== After the retreat of ISIL from the al-Qaboun and Barzah districts, the UN continued trying to bring relief aid into Yarmouk Camp. However, the camp remained sealed off, and the relief workers were only able to deliver supplies to the communities outside of Yarmouk Camp.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=50669|title=United Nations News Centre|date=23 April 2015|work=UN News Service Section|accessdate=9 May 2015}} ISIL control was eventually shrunk to 40% of the area, with another 20% being contested.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/jihadists-palestinians-battle-syria-refugee-camp-165054789.html|title=Jihadists, Palestinians battle in Syria refugee camp|publisher=|accessdate=26 May 2015}} Meanwhile, talks continued for making the Yarmouk Camp a neutral region, with plans for the expulsion of all gunmen from the area.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/05/05/Palestinian-officials-in-Syria-over-Yarmouk-camp-.html|title=Palestinian officials in Syria over Yarmouk Camp|publisher=|accessdate=9 May 2015}} Fighting between ISIL and government forces continued in the camp into late May.[http://www.syriahr.com/en/2015/05/clashes-in-jobar-and-the-yarmouk-camp-and-aerial-bombardment-on-al-sokhna-city/ Clashes in Jobar and the Yarmouk camp, and aerial bombardment on al-Sokhna city] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526155101/http://www.syriahr.com/en/2015/05/clashes-in-jobar-and-the-yarmouk-camp-and-aerial-bombardment-on-al-sokhna-city/ |date=26 May 2015 }} On 8 June 2015, Palestinian militias in Yarmouk Camp reportedly expelled ISIL from the area of Damascus.[http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/palestinian-militias-force-isis-out-of-yarmouk-camp/ Palestinian Militias Force ISIS Out of Yarmouk Camp] However, three weeks later, it was revealed that Yarmouk Camp was still under siege by Syrian Army forces.[http://www.albawaba.com/news/palestinians-syria-facing-%E2%80%98imminent-threat%E2%80%99-plo-712048 Palestinians in Syria facing ‘imminent threat’: PLO] === October 2017 === The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) launched a big assault in the Yarmouk Camp, targeting the neighbourhoods controlled by Aknaf Beit Al-Maqdis and Jaysh Al-Islam. According to the terrorist group’s official media wing, their forces captured the Yarmouk Hospital and several buildings nearby after overtaking the Islamist fighters in the southern part of the district. Most of the Yarmouk Camp is under the occupation of the Islamic State, which leaves the remaining civilians inside the district at the mercy of the terrorist group. While the Syrian Red Crescent and U.N. have attempted to deliver humanitarian aid to the beleaguered neighbourhoods of Yarmouk, they have found themselves often blocked by the Islamic State terrorists manning checkpoints between this district and nearby Palestine Camp.{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/isis-seizes-large-part-yarmouk-camp/|title=ISIS seizes large part of Yarmouk Camp|date=25 October 2017|work=AMN - Al-Masdar News {{!}} المصدر نيوز|access-date=25 October 2017|language=en-US}} ===January 2018=== {{See also|Southern Damascus offensive}} On 5 January 2018, [[Jaysh al-Islam]] fighters attempted to infiltrate ISIL positions within the orchards situated in-between [[Yalda, Syria|Yalda]] and [[Al-Hajar al-Aswad|Hajjar As-Aswad]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/battle-erupts-isis-syrian-rebels-south-damascus/|title=Battle erupts between ISIS and Syrian rebels in south Damascus|date=5 January 2018|work=AMN - Al-Masdar News {{!}} المصدر نيوز|access-date=17 February 2018|language=en-US}} After weeks of sporadic clashes, ISIL managed to capture 3/4 of Yarmouk Camp. By 27 January, ISIL almost entirely controlled Hajjar al-Aswad after breaking through the last lines of defense, and were on the verge of entering the town of Yalda. During the same time, further areas had also been captured in Yarmouk district.{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/isis-forces-verge-entering-new-town-southern-damascus-map/|title=ISIS forces on the verge of entering new town in southern Damascus - map|date=27 January 2018|work=AMN - Al-Masdar News {{!}} المصدر نيوز|access-date=17 February 2018|language=en-US}} ==Foreign reactions== * {{flagu|United States}} – State Department Deputy Spokesperson Marie Harf condemned ISIL's attack on the Yarmouk refugees camp. * {{flagu|Egypt}} – The Egyptian Foreign Ministry also condemned ISIL's attack and called for "an immediate end to the fighting in order to preserve the lives of civilians… and reiterates Egypt’s solidarity with our Palestinian brotherly-people."[http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2015/04/04/egypt-condemns-is-advances-on-yarmouk-refugee-camp/ Egypt condemns IS advances on Yarmouk refugee camp] * {{flagu|United Nations}} – The UN Security Council demanded humanitarian aid access to the camp "for the protection of civilians".{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/Apr-06/293508-un-security-council-demands-aid-access-to-yarmuk-camp-in-syria.ashx|title=UN Security Council demands aid access to Yarmuk camp in Syria|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=6 April 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal|Syrian Civil War}} *[[Battle of Yarmouk Camp (December 2012)]] *[[Hama and Homs offensive (March–April 2015)]] *[[Qalamoun offensive (May 2015)]] *[[Palmyra offensive (2015)]] *[[Military intervention against ISIL]] **[[American-led intervention in Syria]] *[[List of wars and battles involving ISIL]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} {{Syrian Civil War}} {{coord missing|Syria}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yarmouk Camp 2015}} [[Category:Battles of the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:2015 in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Damascus in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Damascus Governorate in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Syrian government]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the al-Nusra Front]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Free Syrian Army]] [[Category:April 2015 events in Asia]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Bernard Waldman | image = File:Bernard Waldman Los Alamos ID.png | image_size = 240 px | caption = Bernard Waldman's wartime Los Alamos security badge | birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|10|12}} | birth_place = [[New York, New York]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1986|11|1|1913|10|12}} | death_place = [[Sanford, North Carolina]] | residence = | citizenship = United States | nationality = | ethnicity = | field = [[Physics]] | work_institution = [[Los Alamos Laboratory]]
[[University of Notre Dame]]
[[Michigan State University]] | alma_mater = [[New York University]] | thesis_title = The Resonance Processes in the Disintegration of Boron by Protons | thesis_year = 1939 | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = Physics, [[Bombing of Hiroshima]] | prizes = | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Bernard Waldman''' (October 12, 1913 – November 1, 1986) was an American physicist who flew on the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Hiroshima atomic bombing mission]] as a cameraman during [[World War II]]. A graduate of [[New York University]], joined the faculty of the [[University of Notre Dame]] in 1938. During [[World War II]], he served in the [[United States Navy]] as an engineering officer. He headed a group that conducted blast measurements for the [[Trinity nuclear test]], and served on [[Tinian]] with [[Project Alberta]]. After the war he returned to Notre Dame. He was director of the [[Midwestern Universities Research Association]] Laboratory from 1960 to 1964, dean of its [[Notre Dame College of Science]] at Notre Dame from 1967 to 1979, and associate director of the [[National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory]] from 1979 to 1983. ==Early life and education== Bernard Waldman was born in [[New York City]] on October 12, 1913. He attended [[New York University]], from which he received Bachelor of Science and Doctor of Philosophy degrees. His thesis, on "The Resonance Processes in the Disintegration of Boron by Protons",{{cite web |url=http://library.nd.edu/chemistry/resources/genealogy/physics/documents/WaldmanB.pdf |title=Bernard Waldman - PhD |publisher=University of Notre Dame |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }} formed the basis of a paper published in the ''[[Physical Review]]''. His research supported the estimates of [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[Robert Serber]].{{cite journal |title = The Resonance Processes in the Disintegration of Boron by Protons |last=Waldman |first=B. |last2=Waddel |first2=R. C. |last3=Callihan |first3=D. |last4=Schneider |first4=W. A.|journal = [[Physical Review]] |volume = 54 |issue = 12 |pages = 1017–1020 |date=December 1938 |publisher = American Physical Society |doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.54.1017 }} Although he was a [[Congregationalist]], Waldman joined the faculty of the [[University of Notre Dame]] in 1938. He became an [[assistant professor]] in 1941. == Manhattan Project == During [[World War II]], Waldman served in the [[United States Navy]] as an engineering officer, and was involved in construction and extension of naval bases in the United States.{{sfn|Jones|Mills|Sessler|Symon|2010|p=102}} He took a leave of absence from Notre Dame and joined Oppenheimer and Serber at the [[Manhattan Project]]'s [[Los Alamos Laboratory]] in 1943. He was assigned to [[Norman F. Ramsey]]'s E-7 Group, which was part of the Ordnance (O) Division responsible for "integration of design and delivery". Most of the work involved preparing and checking instrumentation from drop tests involving dummy bombs.{{cite web |url=http://www3.nd.edu/~nsl/General_info/ND_Manhattan_project.pdf |title=Early Days of Nuclear Physics at Notre Dame and the Manhattan Project |first=Philipp |last=Wiescher |publisher=University of Notre Dame |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }} [[File:Agnew on Tinian.jpg|thumb|left|Waldman (bottom right) on Tinian with [[Harold Agnew]] (top left), [[Luis W. Alvarez]] (top right) and [[Lawrence H. Johnston]] (bottom left)]] Waldman was the head of Group TR-6 (Airborne Measurements) for the [[Trinity nuclear test]] in July 1945. He developed microphones that were dropped by parachute to measure the effect of the blast. He was then assigned to [[Project Alberta]], the part of the Manhattan Project that oversaw the preparation of facilities to test and deploy nuclear weapons, and support their use during the actual missions.{{cite web |url=http://physicsnow.org/history/acap/institutions/manhattan.jsp |title=The Manhattan Project |publisher=Array of Contemporary American Physicists |accessdate=February 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204013045/http://physicsnow.org/history/acap/institutions/manhattan.jsp |archivedate=February 4, 2014 |df= }} As such, he participated in the [[atomic bombing of Hiroshima]], as a camera operator on the [[Necessary Evil (aircraft)|observation aircraft]]. He was equipped with a special high-speed Fastax movie camera with six seconds of film in order to record the blast. Unfortunately, Waldman forgot to open the camera shutter, and no film was exposed.{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20030824&slug=marquardtobit24 |newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |title=George Marquardt, U.S. war pilot over Hiroshima, dies at 84 |first=Dennis |last=McLellan |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }}{{sfn|Alvarez|Trower|1987|p=66}} ==Later life== After the war ended, Waldman returned to Notre Dame, where he continued his research into the [[photodisintegration]] of [[deuterium]] and [[beryllium]].{{sfn|Jones|Mills|Sessler|Symon|2010|p=102}} For a time he was in charge of a 3-million volt [[particle accelerator]] that was the world`s second most powerful source of [[X-rays]] in 1949. In 1960, Waldman took a sabbatical from Notre Dame to become director of the [[Midwestern Universities Research Association]] (MURP) Laboratory. He set about fixing problems with the 50 MeV accelerator. These were resolved, but the Federal Government declined to fund MURP's activities, and Walden returned to Notre Dame in 1964.{{sfn|Jones|Mills|Sessler|Symon|2010|p=102}} Waldman was appointed dean of Notre Dame's College of Science in 1967. He held this position August, 1979, when he retired at the age of 65. He then became as associate director of the [[National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory]] at [[Michigan State University]], a position he held until 1983. Waldman died in a hospital in [[Sanford, North Carolina]], where he was being treated for cancer, on November 1, 1986. He was survived by his wife, Glenna and three daughters.{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-11-16/news/8603260170_1_hiroshima-atomic-bomb-mr-waldman |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |title=Bomb Physicist Bernard Waldman |date=November 16, 1986 |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }} A funeral service was held at the [[Basilica of the Sacred Heart, Indiana|Basilica of the Sacred Heart]] on the campus of the University of Notre Dame, and he was interred in its Cedar Grove Cemetery.{{cite news |newspaper=[[Star-News]] |date=Nov 13, 1986 |title=Atomic Bomb Scientist Bernard Waldman dies |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19861113&id=P3ZSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4RMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4495,5334268 |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }} His papers are in the University of Notre Dame Archives.{{cite web |url=http://archives.nd.edu/findaids/ead/xml/wal.xml |title=Bernard Waldman Papers |publisher=University of Notre Dame |accessdate=February 2, 2014 }} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book | last = Alvarez | first = Luis W. | authorlink = Luis W. Alvarez | first2 = W. Peter | last2 = Trower | year = 1987 | title = Discovering Alvarez: selected works of Luis W. Alvarez, with commentary by his students and colleagues | location = Chicago | publisher = University of Chicago Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=imidr-iFYCwC&pg=PA66 | isbn = 9780226813042 | oclc = 15791693 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | title = Innovation was not enough: a history of the Midwestern Universities Research Association (MURA) | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Bn7Z4VVB9uUC&pg=PA102 | isbn = 9789812832832 | year = 2010 | first1 = L. | last1 = Jones | first2 = F. | last2 = Mills | first3 = A. | last3 = Sessler | first4 = K. | last4 = Symon | first5 = D. | last5 = Young | publisher = World Scientific | location = Hackensack, N.J. | oclc = 670429483 | ref = harv }} {{Manhattan Project}} {{Portal bar | World War II | Nuclear technology | Physics | History of science | Biography }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Waldman, Bernard}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:Los Alamos National Laboratory personnel]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:Scientists from New York City]] [[Category:American Congregationalists]] [[Category:People associated with the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame faculty]]

[[Image:Firenze-boboligrotta2.jpg|thumb|250px|The famous Mannerist Buontalenti Grotto in the [[Boboli Gardens]].]]
'''Bernardo Buontalenti''' ({{IPA-it|berˈnardo ˌbwɔntaˈlɛnti}}), byname of '''Bernardo Delle Girandole''' (''[[circa|c.]]'' 1531 – 25 or 26 June 1608), was an [[Italy|Italian]] stage designer, architect, theatrical designer, military engineer and artist.
==Biography== Buontalenti was born in [[Florence]].
He entered the service of the [[Medici]] as a youth and remained with them the rest of his life. He is said to have been instructed in painting by [[Francesco de' Rossi (Il Salviati)|Salviati]] and [[Bronzino]], in sculpture by [[Michelangelo Buonarroti]], in architecture by [[Giorgio Vasari]], and to have learned miniature painting under [[Giulio Clovio]]. He executed a number of miniatures for [[Francesco I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany |Francesco]], the son of [[Cosimo I]]. More than a painter, he was celebrated as an architect; in this role he was much employed in the design of fortifications, villas, and gardens and is considered one of the most important architects of the Mannerist period. He was also a great mechanic, and an excellent mathematician. In 1562 he travelled to [[Spain]].
His first known work is from 1568, the [[Palazzo di Bianca Cappello, Florence|Palazzo di Bianca Cappello]] in Florence. His main achievements include the project for the new city of [[Livorno]], the decoration of [[Palazzo Pitti]] and the [[Boboli Gardens]] with the famous grotto, as well as the [[Villa di Pratolino|Parco di Pratolino]] of which little remains today, except for a giant sculpture by Giambologna, representing the Colossus of the Apennines. Buontalenti's skills as a military engineer are shown by the fortifications of the port of [[Livorno]], the [[Forte di Belvedere]] in Florence, the city walls of [[Pistoia]], [[Grosseto]], [[Prato]], [[Portoferraio]] (Elba) and [[Naples]]; he also perfected designs for cannons, and devised a new type of incendiary grenade.
In the [[Uffizi Palace]] of Florence, he built a great court stage, where, during the winter of 1585–1586, splendid festivities were produced under his direction. He designed costumes for the Medici [[intermedio|extravaganzas]]. He was also an innovator in ice conservation and is credited with inventing the precursor to modern Florentine cream.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=1elpxy2oCW4C&lpg=PA1577&ots=VTnbP3BYUn&dq=Bernardo%20Buontalenti%20ice%20cream&lr&pg=PA1573#v=snippet&q=Bernardo%20Buontalenti%20ice&f=false|title=Harvest of the Cold Months: The Social History of Ice and Ices|last=David|first=Elizabeth|date=2011-01-20|publisher=Faber & Faber|isbn=9780571275328|language=en}}</ref>
Despite his successes, his prodigality led Buontalenti to financial ruin; he survived in his later life thanks to a pension given him by the [[Grand Duke of Tuscany]].
==References== <references /> {{Commons category|Bernardo Buontalenti}} *{{cite book| first=Michael| last=Bryan| year=1886| title=''Dictionary of Painters and Engravers, Biographical and Critical'' (Volume I: A-K)| editor = Robert Edmund Graves| pages= | publisher=George Bell and Sons|location=York St. #4, Covent Garden, London; Original from Fogg Library, Digitized May 18, 2007 |id= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4GYCAAAAYAAJ&printsec=titlepage&dq=DICTIONARY+AACHEN+AALST&as_brr=1| authorlink=}} * ''Bernardo Buontalenti and the Grotta Grande of Boboli'', Florence: Maschietto Editore, 2012. {{ISBN|978-88-6394-041-1}}
{{Authority control}}

Satheesh Babu | cinematography = Prakash Kutty | editing = Abhilash Viswanath | studio = Alpha Films | distributor = | released = 28 September 2018 | runtime = 161 minutes | country = India | language = [[Malayalam]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Chalakkudykkaran Changathy''''' is a 2018 Indian [[Malayalam]]-language [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[Vinayan]], featuring Senthil Krishna, [[Honey Rose]], [[Dharmajan Bolgatty]] and [[Salim Kumar]] in the lead roles.{{cite web|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/tribute-actor-kalabhavan-mani-first-look-poster-chalakkudikkaran-changathi-77525|title=Tribute to actor Kalabhavan Mani: First look poster of 'Chalakkudikkaran Changathi'|date=6 March 2018|publisher=}} The film was inspired by the real life of [[Kalabhavan Mani]], the central character Rajamani was created after him.{{cite web|url=https://www.filmibeat.com/malayalam/movies/chalakkudikkaran-changathi.html|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi (2018) - Chalakkudikkaran Changathi Malayalam Movie - Chalakkudikkaran Changathi Review, Cast & Crew, Release Date, Photos, Videos – Filmibeat|website=FilmiBeat}}{{cite web|url=https://malayalam.indianexpress.com/entertainment/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-movie-review-audience-response-vinayan-kalabhavan-mani/|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi Review: ഉത്തരം കിട്ടാത്ത ചോദ്യങ്ങളും നിറയുന്ന കണ്ണുകളും: 'ചാലക്കുടിക്കാരന്‍ ചങ്ങാതി' റിവ്യൂ|date=28 September 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/malayalam/movies/news/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-vinayan-says-he-could-feel-manis-blessing-throughout-the-project/articleshow/66003120.cms|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi: Vinayan says he could feel Mani's blessing throughout the project - Times of India|publisher=}} ==Plot== A biographical drama that chronicles the life and the untimely death of actor Rajamani, who rose from his humble beginnings to become one of the most versatile artists in [[Malayalam cinema]].{{cite web|url=https://in.bookmyshow.com/kottayam/movies/chalakkudikkaran-changathi/ET00084794|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi Movie (2018) - Reviews, Cast & Release Date in Kottayam - BookMyShow|last=BookMyShow|website=BookMyShow}}{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt7269374/plotsummary|title=Chalakkudykkaran Changathy (2018)|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/malayalam/music/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-song-otto-vandi-is-a-colourful-episode-from-kalabhavan-manis-life/articleshow/65049934.cms|title='Chalakkudikkaran Changathi' song 'Otto Vandi' is a colourful episode from Kalabhavan Mani's life - Times of India|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.manoramaonline.com/movies/movie-news/2018/09/28/chalakudikaran-changathi-audience-response-review.html|title=ചാലക്കുടിക്കാരൻ ചങ്ങാതി കണ്ട് പൊട്ടിക്കരഞ്ഞ് മണി ആരാധകർ; വി‍ഡിയോ|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/malayalam/movies/news/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-a-bittersweet-tribute-to-kalabhavan-mani/articleshow/65992012.cms|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi: A bittersweet tribute to Kalabhavan Mani - Times of India|publisher=}} ==Cast== * Senthil Krishna as Rajamani * [[Honey Rose]] * [[Dharmajan Bolgatty]] * [[Salim Kumar]] * [[Anil Murali]] * [[Guinness Pakru]] * [[Joju George]] * [[Joy Mathew]] * [[Kochu Preman]] * [[Kottayam Nazeer]] * [[Ponnamma Babu]] * [[Ramesh Pisharody]] * [[Sreejith Ravi]] * [[Sudheer Karamana]] * [[Sunil Sukhada]] * Renu Sounder * S. P. Sreekumar * Vishnu Govindan ==Music== The music of ''Chalakkudykkaran Changathy'' is by [[Bijibal]] and Satheesh Babu.{{cite web|url=https://www.nowrunning.com/movie/21771/malayalam/chalakudykkaran-changathy/|title=Chalakudykkaran Changathy (2018) - Malayalam Movie Chalakudykkaran Changathy - Chalakudykkaran Changathy Cast & Crew, Trailers, Reviews - nowrunning|publisher=}} The lyrics are written by B. K. Harinarayanan. ==Release== ''Chalakkudykkaran Changathy'' was released on 28 Sep 2018 (India).{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt7269374/releaseinfo|title=Chalakkudykkaran Changathy (2018)|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} ===Reception=== ''[[The Times of India]]'' and ''[[Deccan Chronicle]]'' gave the film a rating of 3.0/5{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/malayalam/movie-reviews/chalakkudikkaran-changathi/movie-review/65994726.cms|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi Movie Review {3/5}|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/290918/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-movie-review-a-befitting-tribute-to-kalabh.html|title=Chalakkudikkaran Changathi movie review: A befitting tribute to Kalabhavan Mani|date=29 September 2018|publisher=}} and ''[[Mathrubhumi]]'' gave the film a rating of 2/5.{{cite web|url=https://www.mathrubhumi.com/movies-music/review/chalakkudikkaran-changathi-movie-movie-review-vinayan-kalabhvan-mani-rajamani-biopic-cinema-death-1.3178306|title=മണി മുഴങ്ങിയില്ല - Movie Rating : 2/5|first=ടി.|last=നിര്‍മല്‍കുമാര്‍|publisher=}} ==Police inquiry== [[Vinayan]] had made it clear even before the release of the film that it is not a biopic on [[Kalabhavan Mani]]. Now, the climax of the film has become controversial as several questions have been raised regarding the death of [[Kalabhavan Mani]]. According to some reports, the investigating agency [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]] has asked Vinayan for explanation on the film’s climax. The death of Kalabhavan Mani has been under CBI investigation, after the actor’s family expressed doubts about the reasons for his early death.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/the-climax-of-chalakkudikkaran-changathi-become-controversial-news-malayalam-skekunajdjgfa.html|title=The climax of 'Chalakkudikkaran Changathi' become controversial|publisher=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|7269374}} [[Category:2000s Malayalam-language films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:2018 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Indian biographical films]] [[Category:Indian drama films]] [[Category:Films based on real people]]
