[[Gerhard Weber]] (1955 building) | seating_type = | capacity = 1,690 | website = {{URL|www.hamburgische-staatsoper.de}}}} The '''Hamburg State Opera''' (in German: '''Hamburgische Staatsoper''') is a Germany [[opera]] company based in Hamburg. Its theatre is located near the square of [[Gänsemarkt]]. Since 2015, the current ''Intendant'' of the company is [[Georges Delnon]], and the current ''Generalmusikdirektor'' of the company is [[Kent Nagano]]. == History == {{See also|Opera in German}} Opera in Hamburg dates to 2 January [[1678 in music|1678]] when the [[Oper am Gänsemarkt]] was inaugurated with a performance of a biblical Singspiel by Johann Theile. It was not a court theatre but the first public opera house in Germany established by the art-loving citizens of Hamburg, a prosperous member of the [[Hanseatic League]]. The Hamburg ''Bürgeroper'' resisted the dominance of the Italianate style and rapidly became the leading musical center of the German Baroque. In 1703, [[George Friedrich Handel]] was engaged as violinist and harpsichordist and performances of his operas were not long in appearing. In 1705, Hamburg gave the world première of his opera ''[[Handel's lost Hamburg operas|Nero]]''. In 1721, [[Georg Philipp Telemann]], a central figure of the German Baroque, joined the Hamburg Opera, and in subsequent years [[Christoph Willibald Gluck]], [[Johann Adolph Hasse]] and various Italian companies were among the guests. [[File:Stadttheater Hamburg 1827.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The Stadt-Theater, built in 1827]] [[File:Hamburg Stadttheater um 1890.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The same building, redecorated in 1890, destroyed in 1943]] To replace the aging wooden structure, the first stone was laid on 18 May 1826 for the ''Stadt-Theater'' on the present-day site of the Hamburg State Opera. The new theater, with seating for 2,800 guest, was inaugurated less than a year later with [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven's]] incidental music to ''[[Egmont (play)|Egmont]]''. In 1873, both the exterior and interior of the structure were renovated in the reigning "[[Gründerzeit]]" style of the time, and again in 1891, when electric lighting was introduced. Under the direction of Bernhard Pollini, the house mounted its first complete ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen|Ring Cycle]]'' in 1879. In 1883, the year of [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s death, a cycle comprising nine of his operas commenced. The musical directors [[Hans von Bülow]] (from 1887 to 1890) and [[Gustav Mahler]] (from 1891 to 1897) also contributed to the fame of the opera house. In the beginning of the 20th century, opera was an important part of the theatre's repertoire; among the 321 performances during the 1907–08 season, 282 were performances of opera. The Stadt-Theater performed not only established repertoire but also new works, such as [[Paul Hindemith]]'s ''[[Sancta Susanna]]'', [[Igor Stravinsky]]'s ''[[The Soldier's Tale]]'', [[Ernst Krenek]]'s ''[[Jonny spielt auf]]'', and [[Leoš Janáček]]'s ''[[Jenůfa]]''. [[Ferruccio Busoni]]'s ''[[Die Brautwahl]]'' (1912) and [[Erich Wolfgang Korngold]]'s ''[[Die tote Stadt]]'' (1920) both had their world premieres in Hamburg. In the 1930s, after Hitler came to power, the opera house was renamed ''Hamburgische Staatsoper''. On the night of 2 August 1943, both the auditorium and its neighbouring buildings were destroyed during air raids by fire-bombing; a low-flying airplane dropped several petrol and phosphorus containers on to the middle of the roof of the auditorium, turning it into a conflagration. [[File:Hamburg Staatsoper Zuschauerraum 03.jpg|thumbnail|Current interior]] The current Staatsoper opened on 15 October 1955 with Mozart's ''[[Die Zauberflöte]]''. Hamburg continued to devote itself to new works, such as [[Hans Werner Henze]]'s ''[[Der Prinz von Homburg (opera)|The Prince of Homburg]]'' (1960), Stravinsky's ''The Flood'' (1963), [[Gian Carlo Menotti]]'s ''[[Help, Help, the Globolinks!]]'' (1968), and [[Mauricio Kagel]]'s ''Staatstheater'' (1971). In 1967, under the direction of Joachim Hess, the Hamburg State Opera became the first company to broadcasts its operas in color on television, beginning with ''Die Hochzeit des Figaro'' (a German translation of ''[[Le Nozze di Figaro]]''). Ten of these television productions have been released on DVD by [[ArtHaus Musik]] as ''Cult Opera of the 1970s'', as well as separately. All of these were performed in German regardless of the original language (six were written in German, one in French, two in English, and one in Italian). More recently, Hamburg gave the world premières of [[Wolfgang Rihm]]'s ''[[Die Eroberung von Mexico]]'' (1992) and [[Helmut Lachenmann]]'s ''Das Mädchen mit den Schwefelhölzern'' (1997), for which it received much international acclaim.{{cite news |last=Herbort |first=Heinz Josef |date=14 February 1992 |title=Dieser Schrei ist ein Traum |trans-title=This Scream is a Dream |url=http://www.zeit.de/1992/08/dieser-schrei-ist-ein-traum |work=[[Die Zeit]] |location=Hamburg |language=German |access-date=6 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Umbach |first=Klaus |date=27 January 1997 |title=Qualm vom Quälgeist |trans-title=Smoke from a tormenting spirit |url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-8652148.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |location=Hamburg |language=German |access-date=6 September 2017}} The company has won the "[[Opera house of the year|Opera House of the Year]]" award by the German magazine Opernwelt in 1997 and in 2005.{{cite news |trans-title=Hamburg is "Opera House of the Year", new project by Metzmacher / Konwitschny |date=23 September 2005 |title=Hamburg ist "Opernhaus des Jahres", neues Projekt von Metzmacher/Konwitschny |url=https://www.welt.de/print-welt/article166450/Hamburg-ist-Opernhaus-des-Jahres-neues-Projekt-von-Metzmacher-Konwitschny.html |location=Hamburg |publisher=[[Die Welt]] |agency=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] |access-date=6 September 2017}} Recent General Music Directors (GMD) have included Ingo Metzmacher and [[Simone Young]]. Young was the first female GMD in the company's history, serving from 2005 to 2015.{{cite news |last=Banuscher |first=Doris |date=20 February 2005 |title=Hello, Simone Young |url=https://www.welt.de/print-wams/article123758/Hello-Simone-Young.html |work=Die Welt |location=Hamburg |language=German |access-date=6 September 2017}} [[Kent Nagano]] became GMD as of the 2015-2016 season, with an initial contract of 5 seasons.{{cite news| url=http://www.gramophone.co.uk/classical-music-news/kent-nagano-appointed-music-director-of-hamburg-state-opera-from-2015| title=Kent Nagano appointed music director of Hamburg State Opera from 2015| work=[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]]| first=Charlotte| last=Smith| date=26 September 2012| accessdate=2014-06-09}} In October 2017, the company announced the extension of Nagano's Hamburg contract through 2025.{{cite news | url=https://www.abendblatt.de/hamburg/elbphilharmonie/article212129173/Kent-Nagano-verlaengert-Vertrag-bis-2025.html | title=Kent Nagano verlängert – und Kühne gibt Millionen | work=Hamburger Abendblatt | author= | date=2017-10-04 | accessdate=2018-01-07}} ==General Music Directors (GMD)== * [[Eugen Jochum]] (1934–1949) * [[Joseph Keilberth]] (1951–1959) * [[Wolfgang Sawallisch]] [[Image:'Herbie', Yarmouth, Maine.jpg|thumb|"Herbie", formerly [[New England]]'s oldest and largest [[elm]] tree. Photograph taken prior to its spread being reduced in 2008. The tree was cut down in 2010]] "'''Herbie'''" was an [[American elm]] tree located in [[Yarmouth, Maine]]. It stood by present-day East Main Street ([[Maine State Route 88|State Route 88]]), at its intersection with Yankee Drive,[http://www.sjcme.edu/magazine/summer07/elm.php "Will elm trees make their way back?" - St. ''Joseph's College Magazine''] between 1793 and January 19, 2010. At 110 feet in height, it was, between 1997 and the date of its felling,According to the plaque on its trunk. the oldest''Images of America: Yarmouth'', Hall, Alan M., Arcadia (2002) and largest[http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/story.php?id=275876 "Yarmouth braces for Herbie's demise"]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'', August 10 2009 of its kind in [[New England]].[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1016/is_1_106/ai_61535152/pg_3 The National Register of Big Trees: 2000-01] The tree, which partially stood in the front yard of a private residence, also had a 20-foot circumference and (until mid-2008) a 93-foot crown spread. It was so-named when children witnessed some of its diseased limbs being sawn off. "What are you going to do to Herbie? Don't cut Herbie!" they cried, and the name stuck. A plaque on its trunk stated: {{quotation|
'''Historic Elm''' This tree is hereby designated
a historic landmark to be
honored and preserved for
future generations. Elm Research Institute
[[Harrisville, New Hampshire|Harrisville, N.H.]] 03450}}
[[File:Yarmouthville, Yarmouth ME.jpg|thumb|Yarmouth was once flush with American elms. These, on Main Street, were some of the original 739 that existed]] [[File:Herbie T-shirt.jpg|thumb|left|The front and back of a "The Herbie Project" [[T-shirt]]]] On May 1, 1834, the town gave Herbie some company by planting rows of elm trees along East Elm Street. From 1957 onward, however, most of them succumbed to [[Dutch elm disease]]. As of 2003, only twenty of Yarmouth's original 739 elms had survived.[http://www.americanprofile.com/heroes/article/2967.html "Champion of Trees" - American Profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110212014413/http://www.americanprofile.com/heroes/article/2967.html |date=2011-02-12 }} [[File:Herbie's stump.jpg|thumb|A section of Herbie's stump, pictured in May 2010, is prepared for removal. A [[stump grinder]] removed the remainder at the end of the month]] [[File:Herbie on display.jpg|thumb|The above section on display at the 2010 [[Yarmouth Clam Festival]]. It is now on permanent display on Cleaves Street, on the property of Yarmouth's town hall]] After battling fifteen bouts of Dutch elm disease, in 2007, stripes appeared under the tree's bark, indicating a worsening condition. In August 2009, it was revealed that Herbie would be cut down on January 18 and 19, 2010,[http://yarmouth.me.us/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC={3BC710CA-C840-417A-9B74-A684B5565116} "The Herbie Project" - Town of Yarmouth's website] at a cost of $20,000.[http://www.boston.com/news/local/maine/articles/2009/12/27/when_this_tree_falls_he_will_feel_it/?page=2 "When this tree falls, he will feel it"] - Boston.com, December 27 2009 In October 2009, the plaque was removed from its trunk and replaced with a laminated version, and before the end of the year, "The Herbie Project" fund-raising campaign was set up to raise money to care for and plant other trees in the town. After the tree's demise, local [[woodworker]]s used its wood to make products which will be auctioned off to raise money for the trust. A snowstorm during the night of January 17–18, 2010 postponed the removal. The tree was removed on January 19. A preliminary count of the tree's rings, done on site, revealed its age to be at least 212 years.[http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/story.php?id=310050&ac=PHnws "Farewell to Herbie and a 'beautiful relationship'"]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'', January 19 2010 On February 4, however, the official count showed it to be 217. The stump was removed over the weekend of May 29 and 30. A section of the trunk's base was on show at the 2010 [[Yarmouth Clam Festival]]. It is now on permanent display outside Yarmouth town hall, on Cleaves Street, a project of the local [[Eagle Scouts]]. Frank Knight, the town's former "tree warden", died at the age of 103 on May 14, 2012. Knight's casket was made, in secret, out of Herbie's wood.{{cite news|title=Frank Knight Dead: 'Herbie' The Elm Tree Caretaker Dies At 103|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/14/frank-knight-dead-age-103_n_1515496.html?ref=topbar|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=15 May 2012|date=May 14, 2012}} Succeeded by Deb Hopkins in 2006, Knight cared for the tree for half of his life, having accepted the role in 1956. Knight's efforts were recognized by the town: the athletic fields at North Yarmouth Academy bear his name, as does a forest behind the town's [[community garden]];{{cite web |url=http://www.yarmouthcommunityservices.org/spaces.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812172237/http://www.yarmouthcommunityservices.org/spaces.html |archivedate=2007-08-12 |df= }} a tree in front of Yarmouth's town hall was planted in his honor; and, in 1983, he was the fourth recipient of the town's Latchstring Award.[http://www.yarmouth.me.us/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC={240DDD84-B4CF-4BB7-89FE-6F9A5380DD38} Town of Yarmouth, Maine -- Latchstring Award] ==References in popular culture== In 2017, Portland's Liquid Riot Bottling Company released a beer in tribute to Herbie.[http://www.pressherald.com/2017/09/19/herbie-the-oldest-american-elm-is-back/ "Brewery cheers beloved Yarmouth tree Herbie with new beer"] - ''Portland Press Herald'', September 19, 2017 ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Maine}} ==External links== *[http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/story.php?id=310050&ac=PHnws "Farewell to Herbie and a 'beautiful' relationship"]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'' article, January 19 2010 {{DEFAULTSORT:Herbie}} [[Category:Individual elm trees]] [[Category:Cumberland County, Maine]] [[Category:Yarmouth, Maine]] [[Category:Trees of the Northeastern United States]] [[Category:2010s individual tree deaths]] [[Category:Individual trees in the United States]]

[[Chairman]] of the [[Network Television Marketing]] | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} [[Brigadier (United Kingdom)|Brigadier]] '''Imtiaz Ahmed''' ([[Urdu]]: امتياز احمد; b. 1935{{rp|33}}), {{small|[[Sitara-e-Basalat|SBt]], [[Tamgha-e-Imtiaz|TI(m)]]}}, also known as '''Imtiaz Billa''',{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Sabir|title=Recapping the previous Karachi operations|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-2-201513-Recapping-the-previous-Karachi-operations|accessdate=11 July 2014|publisher=The News|date=12 September 2013}} is a retired [[engineering officer]] in the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers]] and a former [[Spymaster|spy]] who served as the [[:Category:Directors General of the Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Director-General]] of the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]] from 1990–93. After a brief career in the [[Combat Engineering|combat engineering formations]] in the [[Pakistan Army]], his career mostly spent in the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI), where he was responsible for running [[internal security]] before serving in the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]]. In 1989, his [[Military Commission|military commission]] was [[Military discharge|discharge]] when he implicated in a [[Operation Midnight Jackal|political scandal]] in trying to sabotage then-[[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Benazir Bhutto]]'s [[Bainazir Bhuttoo Government|administration]].Ahmed, Khaled (28 March 2002) How blameless is the ISI? [[The Friday Times]] In 2001, Ahmad was convicted by the [[Court system of Pakistan|anti-corruption court]] when [[National Accountability Bureau]] (NAB) prosecuted him on monetary embazzlement.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/1466874.stm BBC] Former Pakistan intelligence chief sentenced 31-July-2001 Ahmad is a controversial figure in the country, having been accused of involved in the custodial death of [[Communist Party of Pakistan|Communist leader]] [[Nazeer Abbasi]] in 1987, and later was accused of having forthknowledge on [[Death and state funeral of Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|plane crash]] that resulted in [[Death and state funeral of Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|death]] of [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]] and his dignitaries in 1988.[http://www.thenews.com.pk/updates.asp?id=86038 Daily The News International 29 August 2009][http://thenews.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=195828 Custodial death of Nazeer Abbasi] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902052337/http://www.thenews.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=195828 |date=2 September 2009 }}, [[The News (Pakistan)|The News]], 31 August 2009[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\08\31\story_31-8-2009_pg7_11 Brig Imtiaz's arrest demanded for communist leader's murder], [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]], 31 August 2009 ==Biography== Imtiaz Ahmed was born in [[Gujranwala]], [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab]] in [[British Indian Empire|India]] on 4 June 1935, according to the Indian author, P.C. Joshi.{{rp|33}} After his [[Matriculation in Pakistan|matriculation]], he joined the [[Pakistan Army]] and entered in the [[Pakistan Military Academy]] in [[Kakul]], and decided to attend the [[Military College of Engineering (Pakistan)|Military College of Engineering]] in [[Risalpur]] in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa]].{{rp|131}}{{cite book|last1=Ahmad|first1=Imtiaz|title=National Defence College Journal|date=2004|publisher=National Defence University press|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en}} He graduated with [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in [[civil engineering]], and earned [[Commissioned officer|commission]] as [[Second lieutenant|2nd-Lt.]] in the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers]] in 1960.{{rp|33}}{{rp|131}} His career is mostly spent in the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]], and served on the [[Combat Engineer Vehicle|combat engineering formations]] during the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|second war]] with India in 1965 and [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|third war]] with India in 1971.{{rp|35–36}} After 1971, Ahmed was directed to attend the staff course at the [[Command and Staff College]] in [[Quetta]].{{rp|131}} Due to his cunningness and the [[Eye color#green|greenish-eye]] feline colors, Ahmed was famously known by his codename in the ISI as "[[Cat|''billa'']]" (the [[Cat|male cat]]).{{rp|30}}{{cite book|title=The Herald|date=1991|publisher=Pakistan Herald Publications.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mGi8prOK-oAC&q=billa|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}} In late 1970s, he joined the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI) as an [[Security analysis|security analyst]] and remained associated with the [[Pakistan|country's]] [[Pakistan Intelligence Community|intelligence community]] for many years.{{rp|contents}} In 1979, [[Major]] Ahmed was posted on a [[security detail]] assignment on the [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant]] (KANUPP), involved in running the [[background check]]s and providing covert security to the technicians working on the [[power plant]].{{cite news|last1=Abbasi|first1=Ansar|authorlink1=Ansar Abbasi|title=Brig Imtiaz reveals CIA plots|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/|accessdate=17 November 2017|agency=The News International|publisher=The News International , Abbasi|date=1 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100201012027/http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=24241|archivedate=1 February 2010|location=Islamabad|language=en-pk|format=web.archive}} In 1979, he became aware of an [[American CIA]] [[Mole (espionage)|mole]] working as an engineer who was trying to seek security details on the commercial nuclear power plant for the [[Nuclear sabotage|sabotage]] purposes. After thoroughly running the background checks, Ahmad identified the suspected mole and eventually led a [[Operation Rising Sun|sting operation]] that successfully resulted in an arrest and conviction of a local Pakistani CIA agent, declaration of a few undercover CIA agents, and U.S. diplomats at the [[Consulate General of the United States, Karachi|U.S. Consulate General]] in Karachi as ''[[personae non gratae]]'' and their return to the [[United States]].{{Cite news |last=Klasra |first=Rauf |author2= |title=How a jilted Karachi woman saved Pak N-programme |newspaper=[[The News International]] |location= |pages= |language= |publisher= |date= |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=22396 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131215449/http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=22396 |archivedate=31 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }} The details and veracity of such assignment has been criticized in the editorial written in [[Dawn (newspaper)|''Dawn'']], whose [[Investigative journalism|investigations]] identified the engineer who was working for the [[Karachi Electric]] (KE) [[electric power transmission]] and had been a prominent member of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]], not working for the [[KANUPP|nuclear power plant]] as claimed by Brig. Ahmed. ==Secrecy: policy and secrets== {{Main|Jam Saqi case|Operation Midnight Jackal}} In 1980, [[Lieutenant-Colonel|Lt-Col.]] Ahmed joined the [[ISI of Pakistan|Joint Counterintelligence Bureau]] (JCIB), mainly working in [[counterintelligence]] management and overseeing the [[Jam Saqi case|anti-communist]] operations in [[Sindh]].{{rp|119–122}}{{cite book|last1=Ahmed|first1=Khaled|title=Pakistan: The State in Crisis|date=2002|publisher=Vanguard|accessdate=18 November 2017|language=en}} In 1981, he began investigating the [[Al-Zulfiqar|al-Zulikar]], led by [[Murtaza Bhutto]], after the [[1981 Pakistan International Airlines hijacking|hijacking]] of the [[Pakistan International Airlines|PIA Flight–326]], eventually expanding the spying on the leaders of the [[Movement for Restoration of Democracy]] led by [[Benazir Bhutto]] in 1982–85.{{cite web|last1=Abbasi|first1=Zafar|last2=Editorial|first2=Dawn|title=Only bean-spilling spooks can tell why|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/487888|website=DAWN.COM|publisher=Dawn Newspapers|accessdate=18 November 2017|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|date=1 September 2009}} From 1983–88, he also monitored the [[Anti-communism|anticommunist]] [[Jam Saqi case|judicial probe]] that implicated the journalists [[Jam Saqi]] and [[Sohail Sangi]], and harboured doubts of [[Mutual fund|foreign funding]] of [[Movement for the Restoration of Democracy]] (MRD) alliance led by [[Benazir Bhutto]].{{cite news|last1=Khan|first1=Tahir Hassan|title=The politics of Brigadier 'Billa'|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/|accessdate=19 November 2017|work=thenews.com.pk|agency=The News International|publisher=Tahir Hassan Khan's report at The News International|date=31 August 2009|archiveurl=https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:EmIrq0D5F7MJ:https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/194088-the-politics-of-brigadier-billa+&ct=clnk&gl=us|archivedate=31 August 2009|location=Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan|language=en-pk|format=webarchives}} Over this judicial probe, the [[Communist Party of Pakistan]] politicians have leveled accusations on Ahmed's [[Special Security Unit|CI bureau]] in Sindh of ''wrongfully'' investigating on the [[Nazeer Abbasi]]'s political ambitions whose [[Death in custody|death resulted in the custody]] of the [[Sindh Police]]. In 1986–87, [[Colonel|Col.]] Ahmed was appointed as the Director-General [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]] (DGIB) before being posted to take over the directorship of the [[ISI of Pakistan|JCIB]] in [[Islamabad]] when [[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen.]] [[General Akhtar Abdur Rahman|Akhtar Abdur Rahman]] became [[:Category:Directors General of Inter-Services Intelligence|DG ISI]].{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Kiessling|first1=Hein|title=Faith, Unity, Discipline: The Inter-Service-Intelligence (ISI) of Pakistan|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9781849048637|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y_cgDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT82#v=onepage&q=Imtiaz%20Ahmed%20Brig%20counter-intelligence|accessdate=18 November 2017|language=en}} In 1988, [[Brigadier|Brig.]] Ahmed was appointed as director of [[ISI (Pakistan)|Political Wing]] of the [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]] in [[Islamabad]], managing the country's [[internal security]] and tried uniting the [[Pakistan National Alliance|conservative mass]] against the left-oriented [[Pakistan Peoples Party]].{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Sirrs|first1=Owen L.|title=Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate: Covert Action and Internal Operations|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317196082|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzGTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT163#v=onepage&q=brigadier%20imtiaz%20ahmed|accessdate=19 November 2017|language=en}} Due to the complaints of [[Naseerullah Babar]], [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Security Adviser]] at the [[Ministry of Interior (Pakistan)|Interior Ministry]], Brig. Ahmad was rotated back to the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]] on a [[construction engineering]] assignment in [[Risalpur]] but his skills on intelligence [[Intelligence analysis management|management]] and [[Extraction (military)|extraction]] was valuable, eventually found a way to secretly serve in the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]].{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Kiessling|first1=Hein|title=Faith, Unity, Discipline: The Inter-Service-Intelligence (ISI) of Pakistan|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9781849048637|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y_cgDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT82#v=onepage&q=brigadier%20imtiaz%20ahmed%20engineers|accessdate=19 November 2017|language=en}} In 1989, Brig. Imtiaz, in secret conversation with [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] [[Amir Khan (Pakistan Army officer)|Amir Khan]], talked on sponsoring the [[:Category:Pakistani MNAs 1988–90|Members of Parliament]] (MP) belonging to the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] to bring about a [[vote of no-confidence]] movement to remove [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Benazir Bhutto]] in order to bring [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)|PML(N)]] led by its then-[[President of Pakistan Muslim League (N)|President]] [[Fida Mohammad Khan|Fida Mohammad]] and his chief secretary [[Nawaz Sharif]] in the administration.{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Kiessling|first1=Hein|title=Faith, Unity, Discipline: The Inter-Service-Intelligence (ISI) of Pakistan|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9781849048637|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y_cgDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT82#v=onepage&q=Imtiaz%20Ahmed%20benazir|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|146}}{{cite book|last1=Sirrs|first1=Owen L.|title=Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate: Covert Action and Internal Operations|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=9781317196099|pages=310|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_S-TDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA146#v=onepage&q=Imtiaz%20Ahmed%20Jackal|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en-us|format=googlebooks|chapter={{small|Intelligence wars}}}} The plan backfired when the conversation was apparently videotaped by the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|IB]] and [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]], and released to the public, which eventually led to the General [[Mirza Aslam Beg]], then-[[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]], to allow the [[Military Intelligence of Pakistan|Military Intelligence]] (MI) to conduct the inquiry in such manner.{{rp|146}} Both [[Brigadier (United Kingdom)|Brig.]] Ahmed and [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] [[Amir Khan (Pakistan Army officer)|Amir Khan]] were [[Military discharge|discharged]] from their [[Commissioned officer|military commission]] in 1989, and the inquiry remains classified since it is still unclear who the real culprit behind the plot was or was it under the instructions of the DG ISI [[Shamsur Rahman Kallu]].{{rp|146}}{{rp|conts}}{{Cite news | last =Khan | first =Ism | author2 = | title =In the News – Brigadier Imtiaz Ahmad | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher =multipak.wordpress.com | date =29 August 2009 | url =http://multipak.wordpress.com/2009/08/28/in-the-news-brigadier-imtiaz-ahmad/ | accessdate = }} After his discharge in 1989, he was reportedly employed by then-[[Chief Minister of Punjab (Pakistan)|Chief Minister of Punjab]], [[Nawaz Sharif]], as his Additional Chief Secretary in the [[Government of Punjab, Pakistan|Government of Punjab]], which he served until 1990.{{rp|30–31}}{{cite book|last1=Hussain|first1=Mushahid|last2=Hussain|first2=Akmal|last3=CPR|first3=Centre for Policy Research (New Delhi|title=Pakistan: problems of governance|date=1993|publisher=Konark Publishers|location=New Delhi, India|pages=166|url=|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|151}} ==Director of IB (1990–93) and Later work== {{Main|Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Network Television Marketing|Shalimar Television Network}} When the [[Pakistani general election, 1990|general elections]] were held in [[1990 in Pakistan|1990]], which saw [[Nawaz Sharif]] forming the [[First Sharif ministry|first government]], Imtiaz Ahmed was re-appointed as the [[:Category:Directors General of the Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Director-General]] of the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]] (DGIB).{{rp|124}}{{cite book|last1=Sehgal|first1=Ikram ul-Majeed|title=Defence Journal|date=2005|publisher=Ikram ul-Majeed Sehgal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qa3fAAAAMAAJ&q=+Imtiaz|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}} In 1992, he aided in launching of the [[Operation Clean-up|armed operation]] to cleanse the Karachi of "anti-social" elements, and ultimately targeting the [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement|MQM]] once the [[Jinnahpur|conspiracy]] to partitioned Karachi from [[Sindh]] was unearthed.{{rp|75}}{{cite book|last1=Hoodbhoy|first1=Nafisa|title=Aboard the Democracy Train: A Journey Through Pakistan's Last Decade of Democracy|date=2011|publisher=Anthem Press|location=Karachi, Pakistan|isbn=9780857289063|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEnHdnvCW4MC&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q=Brigadier%20Imtiaz%20%20clean%20up|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter={{small|News is what the rulers wants to hide}}}}{{Cite news | last =Associate Press | first = | author2 = | title =Details of Brig. (R) Imtiaz Ahmed | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = | url =http://pakistanherald.com/Profile/Brig-R-Imtiaz-Ahmed-1025 | accessdate = }} After the resignations of the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] Sharif and [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan]], Ahmed resigned from the directorship of the [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]], which he termed his resignation as "on principle" on 19 April 1992.{{rp|29}}{{cite book|title=JPRS Report: Near East & South Asia|date=1993|publisher=Foreign Broadcast Information Service|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8Ui6AAAAIAAJ&q=Brigadier+Imtiaz+DG+IB|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}} In 1997, Ahmed was appointed by Prime Minister Sharif as [[Director-General]] of the [[Federal Investigation Agency|FIA]] but the appointment did not come through.{{rp|38–39}} On October 1997, Ahmed took over the chairmanship of the [[Network Television Marketing|NTM]], appointed by the NTM's [[board of directors]] amid controversy when NTM's chairman Faisal Sher Jan was fired from the channel.{{cite book|last1=Joshi|first1=P. C.|title=Main Intelligence Outfits Of Pakistan|date=2008|publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Limited|isbn=9788126135509|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B3zfAAAAMAAJ&q=NTM|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|38}} He chaired the channel until 1999.{{rp|40}} ==Controversies and allegations== The [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) led by [[Benazir Bhutto]] secured the [[Plurality voting|plurality]] after the [[Pakistani general election, 1993|general elections]] held in [[1993 in Pakistan|1993]], and [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Benazir Bhutto]] opened the investigation and inquiry when authorizing the [[arrest warrant]]s of Imtiaz Ahmed on charges of indulging in illegal activities in 1994.{{rp|159–160}}{{cite book|last1=Raman|first1=B.|title=Intelligence: Past, Present & Future|date=2002|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9788170622222|pages=400|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mTf1vRYx_U4C&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q=Brigadier%20Imtiaz%20arrested|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter={{small|Financial and Narcotics Intelligence}}}} The case against him was marked on the political motives, and he was later released due to lack of evidences.{{rp|159–160}}{{rp|9–10}}{{cite book|title=World in Transition.|date=2003|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|isbn=9788178352657|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lmNTY6smsUEC&pg=PA9#v=onepage&q=Brigadier%20Imtiaz%20arrested|accessdate=20 November 2017|language=en}} After the [[1999 Pakistani coup d'état|turnover of the government]] in 1999 by General [[Pervez Musharraf]], the inquiries led by the [[National Accountability Bureau]] (NAB) indicted him on large-scale corruption and misappropriation of funds while serving as the Director of IB, eventually found him guilty in 2001.{{cite news|last1=staff writer|first1=staff|title=Former Pakistan intelligence chief sentenced|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1466874.stm|accessdate=20 November 2017|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC Pakistan Bureau|date=31 July 2001}} He was sentenced to sentenced to eight years imprisonment for corruption., released in 2008–09 On 21 September 2010, Imtiaz Ahmed was again arrested along with Adnan Khawaja, the former chairman of the [[Oil and Gas Development Company|OGDC]], and was shifted to [[Adiala Jail|Adiala Prison]] where they were earlier arrested from the courtroom.{{cite news|title=Brig (R) Imtiaz released on bail - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/53930/brig-r-imtiaz-released-on-bail/|accessdate=20 November 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=24 September 2010}} In a [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court bench]] headed by then-[[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] [[Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry]] who heard the NRO implementation case, Ahmed was arrested from the court on orders by Supreme Court during the hearing of a case relating the implementation of National Reconciliation Ordinance (NRO). On 25 September 2010, the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] eventually released him as he already had served him time.{{cite news|title=Former Brigadier Imtiaz released from Adiala Jail|url=http://fp.brecorder.com/2010/09/201009261106129/|accessdate=20 November 2017}}{{cite news|title=Brig. (retd.) Imtiaz Ahmed released - Samaa TV|url=https://www.samaa.tv/pakistan/2010/09/brig-retd-imtiaz-ahmed-released/|accessdate=20 November 2017|work=www.samaa.tv}}{{cite news|title=Brigadier (R) Imtiaz released on LHC orders - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/54332/court-fails-to-produce-orders-for-surety-bonds/|accessdate=20 November 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=25 September 2010}} His release was given on grounds of his age and medical condition, which he reportedly suffering from the [[coronary artery disease]]. ===Forth Knowledge on Bahawalpur incident === {{Main|Death and state funeral of Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq}} In 2009, [[Humayun Akhtar Khan]], the former [[Commerce Minister of Pakistan|Commerce minister]] and son of Gen. [[Akhtar Abdur Rahman]], had leveled accusations when he reportedly marked: ''Brig. Imtiaz is the man who encouraged [[Akhtar Abdur Rahman|my father]] to board on the [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 aircraft]] which later met an accident. I ask Brig. Imtiaz to explain what led him to play a role in my father's killing'', Humayun Akhtar maintained.{{Cite news | last =The Press Report | first = | author2 = | title =Brig. (R) Imtiaz trying to get world attention | newspaper =[[The News International]] | location = | pages = | publisher =[[Jang Group of Newspapers]] | date =29 August 2009 | url =http://www.thenews.com.pk/updates.asp?id=86038 | accessdate = }} ===Jinnahpur plan controversy=== After his release in 2009, Ahmed became an intelligence commentator and gave several television parties against the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]].[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\08\28\story_28-8-2009_pg1_4 'Midnight Jackal' was launched to overthrow Benazir: Imtiaz], [[Daily The '''Kiev uprising of 1068''' was a revolt against Grand Prince [[Iziaslav Yaroslavich]] of Kiev in the aftermath of a [[Kievan Rus’]] defeat at the hands of the [[Cuman people|Cumans]] at [[Battle of the Alta River]] near the city of [[Pereyaslav-Khmelnytskyi|Pereiaslavl]], southeast of Kiev. The Polovtsy raid of 1068–1069 was only the tribe's second major raid into Rus’ (they had negotiated a treaty with Prince [[Vsevolod Yaroslavich]] of Pereislavl’ (the father of [[Vladimir Monomach]]) in 1055, but the tribesmen broke the treaty and attacked Kievan Rus’ six years later, defeating Vsevolod in battle). In 1068-1069, the Polovtsy penetrated the earthwork defensive lines built up over the years by Prince [[Vladimir I of Kiev|Vladimir Svyatoslavich]] (r. ca. 980–1015) and his son, [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (r. 1019–1054). They were met by a combined army of Yaroslav’s sons: Grand Prince Iziaslav of Kiev and his brothers, Princes [[Sviatoslav II of Kiev|Sviatoslav Yaroslavich]] of Chernigov, and Vsevolod, which was defeated and fled back to Kiev in disarray.Janet Martin, ''Medieval Russia 980-1584'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1995), 45 The Polovsty continued to raid throughout the area, prompting the Kievans to call on the grand prince to rearm them so they could march out and meet the threat. Iziaslav refused, prompting the rebellion. ''The Tale of Bygone Years'' (in Russian ''Povest Vremennikh Let''), a part of ''The Lavrentian Chronicle'', relates what happened next:
The Kievans who had escaped to their native city held a veche (literally "created a veche") on the marketplace and sent the following communication to the Prince [Iziaslav]: 'The Polovtsy have spread over the country. O Prince, give us arms and horses, that we may offer them combat once more.' Iziaslav, however, paid no heed to this request. Then the people began to murmur against his general (voevoda) Konstantin. From the place of the assembly, they mounted the hill and arrived before the house of Konstantin.''Lavrentevskaia Letopis'' (''Povest Vremennikh Let''), in ''Polnoe Sobranie Russkikh Letopisei'', Vol. 1, cols. 170-1; see also Boris D. Grekov, ''Kiev Rus'', trans. by Y. Sdobnikov (Moscow, Foreign Language Publishing House. 1959), 656-7; Martin, ''Medieval Russia'', 35, 49; Mikhail Tikhomirov, ''The Towns of Ancient Rus'', trans. by Y. Sdobnikov (Moscow, Foreign Language Publishing House. 1959), 198-199.
The Kievan mob ransacked Konstantin's house, apparently blaming him for the defeat. They then drove out Iziaslav and freed Prince [[Vseslav of Polotsk]], who had been imprisoned earlier by Iziaslav, Vsevolod, and Sviatoslav, and placed him on the Kievan throne in hopes that he could stop the Polovtsy. Iziaslav, for his part, fled to [[Boleslaus II of Poland|Boleslaw II]] of Poland, who supported him with arms with which he returned to Kiev the following May (1069) and took back the throne. In Iziaslav's absence, Prince Sviatoslav managed to defeat a much larger Polovetsian army on November 1, 1068 and stem the tide of Polovetsian raids. A small skirmish in 1071 was the only disturbance by the Polovtsy for the next two decades.Martin, Medieval Russia, 49. Thus, while the Battle of Alta River was a disgrace for Kievan Rus' and led briefly to the ouster of the grand prince, Sviatoslav's victory the following year relieved the Polovtsy threat to Kiev and Chernigov for a considerable period and allowed Iziaslav the breathing space necessary to reclaim the throne. The uprising has been seen by a number of Russian and Soviet historians as proof of the power of the [[veche]], which was rather more important in the northwestern Rus' cities of [[Novgorod the Great]] and [[Pskov]] (and at a later period) and less important in the south, but showed itself to be important here in displacing a Kievan grand prince and bringing in another one. The ''veche'', usually seen as a public assembly and often quite institutionalized in the literature, would, however, appear in this instance to be little more than an angry mob which sacked the ''voevoda's'' house and drove out the prince. It does not appear to be anything like a parliament or legislature as it has often been portrayed in the traditional historiography. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} [[Category:11th century in Kievan Rus']] [[Category:Medieval rebellions in Europe]] [[Category:Rebellions in Ukraine]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1068]] [[Category:Kipchaks]] [[Category:1068 in Europe]]

[[File:WeaponsInspector.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A UN weapons inspector in Iraq]]
The '''lead-up to the Iraq War''' (i.e., the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] and [[Iraq War|subsequent hostilities]]) began with [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 687]] and subsequent [[United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission|UN weapons inspectors inside Iraq]]. This period also saw low-level hostilities between Iraq and the United States-led coalition from 1991-2003.
==1991–2000: UN inspectors, no-fly zones, and Iraqi opposition groups== Following the 1991 [[Gulf War]], as part of the ceasefire agreement, the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 687]] mandated that [[Iraq and weapons of mass destruction|Iraqi chemical, biological, nuclear, and long range missile programs]] be halted and all such weapons destroyed under [[United Nations Special Commission]] control. [[United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission|The UN weapons inspectors inside Iraq]] were able to verify the destruction of a large amount of WMD-material, but substantial issues remained unresolved in 1998 when the inspectors left Iraq due to then current UNSCOM head [[Richard Butler (diplomat)|Richard Butler]]'s belief that U.S. and UK military action was imminent. Shortly after the inspectors withdrew, the U.S. and UK launched a [[Bombing of Iraq (December 1998)|four-day bombing campaign in Iraq]]. Also, during this period the [[U.S. Congress]] and U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] issued a [[Iraq Liberation Act|resolution calling for regime change in Iraq.]]
In addition to the UN inspections, the U.S. and UK (along with France until 1998) engaged in a low-level conflict with Iraq by enforcing non-UN mandated northern and southern [[Iraqi no-fly zones]]. These were known as [[Operation Provide Comfort|Operation Provide Comfort and Operation Provide Comfort II]] then followed by [[Operation Northern Watch]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] in the north and [[Operation Southern Watch]] in the south, and were seen by the Iraqi government as an infringement of Iraq's [[sovereignty]]. These overflights intensified one year before the Iraq war began when the U.S. initiated [[Operation Southern Focus]] in order to disrupt the military command structure in Iraq before the invasion.
===Iraqi expatriate opposition groups=== Following the 1991 Gulf War, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] signed a presidential finding directing the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] to create conditions for Hussein's removal from power in May 1991. Coordinating anti-Saddam groups was an important element of this strategy and the [[Iraqi National Congress]] (INC), led by [[Ahmed Chalabi]], was the main group tasked with this purpose. The name INC was reportedly coined by [[public relations]] expert [[John Rendon]] (of the [[Rendon Group]] agency) and the group received millions in covert funding in the 1990s, and then about $8 million a year in overt funding after the passage of the [[Iraq Liberation Act]] in 1998. Another opposition group was the [[Iraqi National Accord]] which continues to have influence in the current Iraqi government through its leader [[Ayad Allawi]].
===Presidential involvement=== In late April 1993, the United States asserted that Saddam Hussein had attempted to have former President George H. W. Bush assassinated during a visit to Kuwait on April 14–16.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hnn.us/articles/1000.html |title=How Do We Know that Iraq Tried to Assassinate President George H.W. Bush? |publisher=Hnn.us |author=FBI Study |accessdate=2008-09-10}}</ref> On June 26, as per order of then-President Clinton, U.S. warships stationed in the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea [[Cruise missile strikes on Iraq (June 1993)|launched a cruise missile attack]] at the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]] building in downtown [[Baghdad]] in response to Iraq's plot to assassinate former President George H. W. Bush. Clinton briefed President-elect [[George W. Bush]] in December 2000, expressing his regret that people he regarded as the world's two most dangerous individuals, including Hussein, were still alive and free. He warned Bush that Hussein will "cause you a world of problems."<ref>{{cite book | author = Chollet, Derek and James Goldgeier |title = America Between the Wars: From 11/9 to 9/11; The Misunderstood Years Between the Fall of the Berlin Wall and the Start of the War on Terror | publisher = Public Affairs, Perseus Books Group | year = 2008}}</ref>
Bush's [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Treasury Secretary]] [[Paul O'Neill (Secretary of the Treasury)|Paul O'Neill]] said that Bush's first two [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] meetings included a discussion of invading Iraq. He was given briefing materials entitled "Plan for post-Saddam Iraq," which envisioned peacekeeping troops, war crimes tribunals, and divvying up Iraq's oil wealth. A Pentagon document dated March 5, 2001 was titled "Foreign Suitors for Iraqi Oilfield contracts," and included a map of potential areas for exploration.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rebecca|first=Leung|title=Bush Sought 'Way' To Invade Iraq?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18560_162-592330.html|accessdate=22 March 2013|newspaper=60 Minutes|date=February 11, 2009}}</ref>
In April 2002, [[Colin Powell]] wrote Bush to inform him that [[Tony Blair]] was ready to support the invasion of Iraq, and would present further advice regarding "strategic, tactical, and public affairs lines" during Blair's forthcoming visit to [[Crawford, Texas|Crawford]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3277402/Smoking-gun-emails-reveal-Blair-s-deal-blood-George-Bush-Iraq-war-forged-YEAR-invasion-started.html | title=Smoking gun emails reveal Blair's 'deal in blood' with George Bush over Iraq war was forged a YEAR before the invasion had even started | accessdate=2015-10-18}}</ref>
==CIA SAD Teams== {{main|Operation Viking Hammer}} The CIA's [[Special Activities Division]] (SAD) teams were the first U.S. forces to enter Iraq in July 2002, prior to the U.S. Invasion. Once on the ground, they prepared for the subsequent arrival of U.S. Army Special Forces to organize the [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] [[Peshmerga]]. This joint team (called the Northern Iraq Liaison Element (NILE)) <ref name="Attack, Bob Woodward 2004">''Plan of Attack'', Bob Woodward, Simon and Schuster, 2004.</ref> combined to defeat [[Ansar al-Islam]], an ally of Al Qaeda, in the North East corner of Iraq. This battle was for control of a territory that was occupied by [[Ansar al-Islam]] and was executed prior to the invasion. It was carried out by Paramilitary Operations Officers from SAD and the Army's [[10th Special Forces Group (United States)|10th Special Forces Group]]. This battle was a significant defeat of a key terrorist organization and the uncovering of a [[Chemical warfare|chemical weapons]] facility at Sargat.<ref name="Attack, Bob Woodward 2004"/> Sargat was the only facility of its type discovered in the Iraq war.<ref name="Tucker 2008">{{cite book |title=Operation Hotel California: The Clandestine War inside Iraq |first1=Mike |last1=Tucker |first2=Charles |last2=Faddis |year=2008 |publisher=[[The Lyons Press]] |isbn=978-1-59921-366-8}}</ref><ref name="wamu.org">{{cite web|url=http://wamu.org/audio/dr/08/10/r2081007-22101.asx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930081326/http://wamu.org/audio/dr/08/10/r2081007-22101.asx |archivedate=2011-09-30 |df= }} An interview on public radio with the author</ref>
SAD teams also conducted missions behind enemy lines to identify leadership targets. These missions led to the initial strikes against [[Saddam Hussein]] and his Generals. Although the strike against Saddam was unsuccessful in killing him, it was successful in effectively ending his ability to command and control his forces. Other strikes against his Generals were successful and significantly degraded the command's ability to react to, and maneuver against the U.S. led invasion force.<ref name="Attack, Bob Woodward 2004"/><ref>Behind lines, an unseen war, Faye Bowers, Christian Science Monitor, April 2003.</ref> SAD operations officers were also successful in convincing key Iraqi Army officers into surrendering their units once the fighting started.<ref name="Tucker 2008" />
[[Turkey]] refused to allow the U.S. Army entry into Northern Iraq. Therefore, joint SAD and Army Special forces teams and the Kurdish [[Peshmerga]] were the entire Northern force against Saddam. They managed to keep Saddam's Army in place rather than moving the northern army to contest the U.S. led coalition force coming from the south. The efforts of the Kurds, SAD and 10th Special Forces Group with the Kurds likely saved the lives of many US and coalition forces during and after the invasion.<ref name="plan">{{cite book |title=[[Plan of Attack]] |first=Bob |last=Woodward |authorlink=Bob Woodward |year=2004 |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster|Simon & Schuster, Inc]] |isbn=978-0-7432-5547-9}}</ref> As described by Mike Tucker and Charles Faddis in their book entitled, ''"Operation Hotel California: The Clandestine War Inside Iraq"'', four of these CIA officers were awarded the Intelligence Star for their heroic actions.<ref name="Tucker 2008"/><ref name="wamu.org"/>
==Congressional Assessment of the Need for War==
Sen. [[Bob Graham]] chaired the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence in 2002, when the Congress voted on the Iraq War Resolution. He first became aware of the significance of Iraq in February 2002, when Gen. Tommy Franks told him the Bush administration had made the decision to begin to de-emphasize Afghanistan in order to get ready for Iraq. In September, the Senate Intelligence Committee met with George Tenet, Director of the CIA, and Graham requested a National Intelligence Estimate (NIE) on Iraq. Tenet responded by saying "We've never done a National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq, including its weapons of mass destruction." and resisted the request to provide one to Congress. Graham insisted "This is the most important decision that we as members of Congress and that the people of America are likely to make in the foreseeable future. We want to have the best understanding of what it is we're about to get involved with." Tenet refused to do a report on the military or occupation phase, but reluctantly agreed to do a NIE on the weapons of mass destruction. Graham described the Senate Intelligence Committee meeting with Tenet as "the turning point in our attitude towards Tenet and our understanding of how the intelligence community has become so submissive to the desires of the administration. The administration wasn't using intelligence to inform their judgment; they were using intelligence as part of a public relations campaign to justify their judgment."<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/darkside/interviews/graham.html “Frontline interview with Sen. Bob Graham” Jan 31, 2006]</ref>
Congress voted to support the war based on the NIE Tenet provided in October 2002. However, the bipartisan "Senate Intelligence Committee Report on Prewar Intelligence" released on July 7, 2004, concluded that the key findings in the 2002 NIE either overstated, or were not supported by, the actual intelligence. The Senate report also found the US Intelligence Community to suffer from a "broken corporate culture and poor management" that resulted in a NIE that was completely wrong in almost every respect.<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB129/intro_part1.pdf “Senate Intelligence Committee Report on Prewar Intelligence” July 7, 2004]</ref>

A corporate collapse typically involves the [[insolvency]] or [[bankruptcy]] of a major business enterprise. A corporate scandal involves alleged or actual unethical behavior by people acting within or on behalf of a corporation. Many recent corporate collapses and scandals have involved false or inappropriate [[accounting]] of some sort (see list at [[accounting scandals]]). <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER/CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER -->
==List of a few major corporate collapses== The following list of corporations involved major collapses, through the risk of job losses or size of the business, and meant entering into [[insolvency]] or [[bankruptcy]], or being [[nationalised]] or requiring a non-market loan by a government.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- !width="100px"|Name !width="5px"|HQ !width="30px"|Date !width="60px"|Business !class="unsortable"|Causes !width="45px"|Assets |- |[[Medici Bank]] |Florence |{{dts|format=dmy|1494||}} |[[Banking]] |Owned by the [[Medici family]], it ran up large debts due to the family's profligate spending, extravagant lifestyle, and failure to control the managers, their bank went insolvent. | |- |[[Mississippi Company]] |France |{{dts|format=dmy|1720|Sep|}} |[[Colonialism]] |Scottish economist [[John Law (economist)|John Law]] convinced the French government to support a monopoly trade venture in [[Louisiana]]. He marketed shares based on great wealth, which was highly exaggerated. A speculative bubble grew and then collapsed, and Law was expelled. | |- |[[South Sea Company]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1720|Sep|}} |[[Slavery]] and [[colonialism]] |After the [[War of Spanish Succession]], the UK signed the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] 1713 with Spain, ostensibly allowing it to trade in the seas near [[South America]]. In fact, barely any trade took place as Spain renounced the Treaty, however this was concealed on the UK stock market. A speculative bubble saw the share price reach over £1000 in August 1720, but then crash in September. {{Infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = [[Live Earth]] | image = <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:Live Earth Logo.png|230px|The Live Earth logo representing the "[[Save Our Selves|S.O.S.]]" message.]] --> | location = [[Basilica of St. John Lateran]], [[Rome]] | founders = [[Al Gore]], [[Kevin Wall]] | years_active= 2007 | dates = July 7, 2007 | genre = | website = [http://liveearth.msn.com/ Live Earth Site] }}
The ''Heptavium'' concert, representing also the '''[[Live Earth]] concert in [[Rome]]''', took place on 7 July 2007 at the [[Basilica of St. John Lateran]], the Cathedral of Rome and subject to the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the Holy See. It was part of a series of high-profile concerts organised by [[Al Gore]] and [[Kevin Wall]], which took place across the globe to raise awareness about climate change. [[Jonas Lauren Norr]] of Ethos Investments was responsible for the collaboration of Live Earth with the Heptavium concert as a producer of the event. The concert was masterminded and written by composer and researcher of philosophy Michael I.D'Alessandra. The concert was officially backed by the Vatican, thus being the Catholic Church's autonomous presence at the [[Live Earth (2007 concert)|Live Earth]] events.
== Heptavium/Live Earth: The Concert== [[Image:Michael D'alessandra 3.jpg|thumb|200px|left|M° Michael D'Alessandra]] The Heptavium/Live Earth event was inaugurated by Paul Cardinal Poupard, who explained the scope and meaning of the evening, a prelude to the ''Cathedralia'' Project, an endeavour of original sacred music between Rome and the USA, conceived and composed by D'Alessandra and planned for the next decade. A reading of a page from St. Augustine's "City of God" followed, mentioning the sacred aspect of earthly nature, concluded by an intervention on behalf of the Live Earth event by acclaimed film producer Lawrence Bender.
The concert was performed exclusively in two different locations of the Cathedral of Rome: before its Holy Door, and inside the Cathedral, in the central nave. During the first part of the concert, various works for string quartet and grand piano composed by M° Michael D'Alessandra were performed by the Bernini Quartet, a string ensemble of virtuosos from Rome, and D'Alessandra, a piano virtuoso and organist himself; the performance was shown inside the Church through HD screens placed aside the Church's canopy.
The second part of the concert, consisting of symphonic and choral sacred music, saw the deployment of the largest orchestra the Church had ever experienced. Performing were the [[London Oratory School Schola]], Michael D'Alessandra, The Rome Philharmonic Orchestra and M°Cristiano Serino. The choir and orchestra performed ''Vexilla Regis'', a variation on Franz Liszt's ''Via Crucis'' conducted by Michael D'Alessandra, connected to ''Septem postrema verba'', a concerto for choir, orchestra and cello solo written by M°Cristiano Serino conducting it. The last seven words of Jesus Christ on the cross were utilised for the libretto, culminating towards the core of the concert: D'Alessandra's ''Missa Sylvestri II'', a funeral Mass, beginning with an eerie ''Kyrie Eleison'' progressing to a fast-paced ''Sanctus'', through a solemn ''Benedictus'', reminiscent of German baroque progressions and Russian Orthodox melodies, and concluding with an elegiac ''Agnus Dei''. This funeral Mass, regarded as a masterpiece of new sacred music in Vatican cultural circles, was written for the 1000th anniversary of Pope Sylvester II's death (May 12, 1003) and premiered in the year 2003 in the very Cathedral of Rome, where Sylvester II is buried. The last performance, ''Gloria'', a piece endowed with Wagnerian traits uttered a finale in which, D'Alessandra conducting, 140 musicians and singers reached the acme of their performance.
This ceremonial concert coincided with the issuance of the motu proprio, ''Summorum Pontificum'' relating to the traditional Latin Mass, also on 7 July 2007.
==Heptavium/Live Earth in the media==
The concert was broadcast either in full or in part by many television and radio networks. The concert was broadcast in Italy, America, Australia and New Zealand, and a short clip showing D'Alessandra's funeral ''Kyrie Eleison'' was also shown on [[BBC One]] in the UK, along with Live Earth's world feed, thus honouring the British choir performing in Rome, in remembrance of the victims fallen on the terrorist attacks in London on 7 July 2005, a tragedy mentioned also during Card. Poupard's introduction to the event. Articles about the concert also appeared in [[The Tablet]] and [[The Catholic Herald]]. The fact that a performance of original sacred music of such elevated standards connected the "Mother of all Churches" (as the Cathedral of Rome is also called) to an event featuring iconic rock acts like Metallica or The Police, denotes a surprising dynamism of certain Vatican departments, although remaining conservative, thus representing a promising breakthrough for the dialogue of a sensible Roman Catholic world with secularized modernity, and overall, with contemporary global culture.
==The Heptavium symbolism== [[Image:Sevensevenseven.JPG|thumb|200px|left|Liber 777]] ''Heptavium'' (literally meaning 'place where seven ways meet') is a Latin neologism conceived by D'Alessandra, who, beside being a musician has an extensive background in Vatican Universities and Institutes as a researcher. This new word aims at condensing in one concept the Arts of the ''trivium'' (grammar, logic, rhetoric) and ''quadrivium'' (mathematics, geometry, astronomy, music), the body known as the seven Liberal Arts, as taught in the Cathedral schools and Universities during the Middle Ages. The city of Rome has always been connected to the number seven since its very foundation: built on seven hills, ruled by seven kings, and furthermore enriched by seven churches and by the seven sacraments, the rhythm of Rome and its symbolism has been and is being governed numerically by the number 7 during its pagan imperial rule and since it became the cradle of Christianity. Therefore, ''Heptavium'' may become an esoteric ''nomen secretum'', a secret name for Rome itself, literally the "City where seven ways meet".
These concepts and prerogatives were mentioned during Card. Paul Poupard's introductory speech to the concert, linking the symbolical contents directly to the music performed. Moreover, the ''Heptavium'' concert was performed both outside and inside the Church, and with two different repertoires and styles of music, profane and sacred-symphonic, to stress the transition from the pagan sphere to the one divinely inspired that the city of Rome has been experiencing for over two millennia.
However, the reason why the date 7 July 2007 was chosen by Pope Benedict XVI as the date for the release of a Motu Proprio related to the traditional Latin Mass remains uncertain, as the date July 7 and even more so, the number 777, both seem to reflect the spirit of gnostic and esoteric numerology more than the Spirit of the Latin Mass canonized by St. Pius V. Undeniably, this number holds its great significance in the Western symbolic tradition; nevertheless, the importance of a Motu Proprio aiming at reintroducing liturgical functions in Latin for the Church of Rome, weighed on D'Alessandra's decision to utilise exclusively Latin for the ''Heptavium'' concert's libretto, stressing ''Heptavium'''s alignment to the symbolical orientation of the current pontificate. This original liturgical music in Latin and a Latin neologism with a concept related to Rome paid homage to the city's Cathedral and seat of the Papal authority, ranking even higher than Saint Peter's Basilica at the Vatican and any other Roman Catholic church in the world in terms of canonical primacy.
As a resultance of these two occurrences combined, namely: I) the Heptavium/Live Earth concert, II) the promulgation of ''Summorum Pontificum'', 7 July 2007 may from now on be defined as the ''Heptavium Dies'', the Heptavium Day for the Roman Catholic Church and its future approach to the city of Rome in the contemporary artistic scenario.

{{For|the aircraft that disappeared over the Indian Ocean in March 2014|Malaysia Airlines Flight 370}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox aircraft occurrence | name = Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 | image = Boeing 777-2H6ER 9M-MRD Malaysian (6658105143).jpg | image_upright = 1.1591 | alt = | caption = 9M-MRD, the aircraft that was shot down, photographed in 2011 | occurrence_type = Shootdown | date = {{start date|2014|07|17|df=y}} | summary = Shot down by a [[surface-to-air missile]] provided by the Russian Army | site = Near [[Hrabove, Donetsk Oblast]], Ukraine | coordinates = {{Coord|48|8|17|N|38|38|20|E|type:event|display=inline,title}} | aircraft_type = [[Boeing 777#777-200ER|Boeing 777-200ER]]<!-- The aircraft model is Boeing 777-200ER. The customer code used at Boeing was "777-2H6ER". "H6" is the Malaysia Airlines customer code to indicate certain preferences. Consensus is to use "Boeing 777-200ER" as the model number. --> | aircraft_name = | operator = [[Malaysia Airlines]] | IATA = MH17 | ICAO = MAS17 | callsign = MALAYSIAN 17 | tail_number = 9M-MRD | origin = [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol]], the Netherlands | stopover = | destination = [[Kuala Lumpur International Airport]], Malaysia | occupants = 298 | passengers = 283 | crew = 15 | fatalities = 298<!-- don't need to add "(all)", we already have survivors=0 --> | survivors = 0 }} {{Campaignbox Ukrainian crisis}} '''Malaysia Airlines Flight 17''' ('''MH17'''){{efn|MH is the [[IATA airline designator|IATA designator]]. The flight was also marketed as [[KLM]] Flight 4103 (KLM4103) through a [[codeshare agreement|codeshare]], and has been commonly referred to as "MH17", "Flight 17" or "Flight MH17".}} was a scheduled passenger flight from [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol|Amsterdam]] to [[Kuala Lumpur International Airport|Kuala Lumpur]] that was [[List of airliner shootdown incidents|shot down]] on 17 July 2014 while flying over eastern [[Ukraine]], killing all 283 passengers and 15 crew on board.<ref name="dsb1"/> Contact with the aircraft, a [[Boeing 777-200ER]], was lost when it was about {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the [[Russia–Ukraine border|Ukraine–Russia border]] and wreckage of the aircraft fell near [[Hrabove, Donetsk Oblast|Hrabove]] in [[Donetsk Oblast]], Ukraine, {{convert|40|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the border.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10974050/Malaysia-Airlines-plane-crashes-on-Ukraine-Russia-border-live.html |title=Malaysia Airlines plane crashes on Ukraine-Russia border – live |date=17 July 2014 |first=Harriet |last=Alexander |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=17 July 2014 |archivedate=18 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718001608/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10974050/Malaysia-Airlines-plane-crashes-on-Ukraine-Russia-border-live.html}}</ref> The shoot-down occurred in the [[War in Donbass]], during the [[Battle in Shakhtarsk Raion|Battle of Shakhtarsk]], in an area controlled by [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian rebels]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/10/world/europe/malaysian-airliner-ukraine.html |title=Malaysian Jet Over Ukraine Was Downed by 'High-Energy Objects,' Dutch Investigators Say |last=Higgins |first=Andrew |last2=Clark |first2=Nicola |date=9 September 2014 |website=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The crash was [[Malaysia Airlines]]' second aircraft loss during 2014 after the disappearance of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370|Flight 370]] on 8 March.<ref name="Official nationalities">{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiaairlines.com/my/en/site/mh17.html|title=Saturday, July 19, 07:30 pm GMT +0800 Media Statement 7 : MH17 Incident|last=|first=|date=19 July 2014|website=Malaysia Airlines|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717232838/http://www.malaysiaairlines.com/my/en/site/mh17.html|archive-date=17 July 2014|dead-url=yes|accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref>
The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the [[Dutch Safety Board]] (DSB) and the Dutch-led [[#Criminal investigation|joint investigation team]] (JIT), who concluded that the airliner was downed by a [[Buk missile system|Buk]] [[surface-to-air missile]] launched from pro-Russian [[Novorossiya (confederation)|separatist-controlled territory]] in Ukraine.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report" /><ref name="auto">{{cite web |title=MH17 crash report: Dutch investigators confirm Buk missile hit plane – live updates |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/oct/13/mh17-crash-report-ukraine-live-updates |website=the Guardian |accessdate=13 October 2015 |first=Matthew |last=Weaver}}</ref> According to the JIT, the Buk that was used originated from the [[53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade]] of the [[Russia|Russian Federation]],<ref name="BBC 5.24.18">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-44235402|work=[[BBC News]]|title=MH17 missile owned by Russian brigade, investigators say|date=24 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="CNN 5.24.18">{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/24/europe/mh17-plane-netherlands-russia-intl/index.html|work=[[CNN]]|title=Missile that downed MH17 'owned by Russian brigade'|first1=Laura|last1=Smith-Spark|first2=James|last2=Masters|date=24 May 2018}}</ref> and had been transported from Russia on the day of the crash, fired from a field in a rebel-controlled area, and the launcher returned to Russia after it was used to shoot down MH17.<ref name="BBC News 28 September 2016"/><ref name="BBC 5.24.18"/><ref name="SMH JIT" /> On the basis of the JIT's conclusions, the governments of the Netherlands and Australia hold Russia responsible for the deployment of the Buk installation and are taking steps to hold Russia formally accountable.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2018/05/25/mh17-the-netherlands-and-australia-hold-russia-responsible|title=MH17: The Netherlands and Australia hold Russia responsible|last=Algemene Zaken|first=Ministerie van|last2=Buitenlandse Zaken|first2=Ministerie van|website=www.government.nl|language=nl-NL|access-date=25 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Evidence in The Australian">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/mh17-shot-down-by-missile-from-russia-by-its-military-report-finds/news-story/d3d1cafaa0033e7acc42d9b9fc38dbf4 | title=MH17 evidence points to ‘rogue state’ Russia, Tony Abbott says | website=The Australian}}</ref>
The DSB and JIT findings confirmed earlier claims by American and German intelligence sources as to the missile type and launch area. In 2014 the American intelligence had also said that Russia had supplied the Buk missile to pro-Russian insurgents, and that the insurgents most plausibly shot down MH17 in error, after misidentifying it as a military aircraft.<ref name="LAtimes"/><ref name="WaPoJuly22"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/07/20/the-evidence-that-may-prove-pro-russian-separatists-shot-down-mh17/ |title=The evidence that may prove pro-Russian separatists shot down MH17 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref>
[[Ukrainian Prime Minister]] [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] laid the blame on professional soldiers that he said came from Russia, stating that "it wasn't drunken militants with Ukrainian passports [who shot down the Malaysian plane], it was done by Russian professionals and coordinated from Russia", adding that "the whole world has learned about the Russian lies and Russian propaganda."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yatsenyuk-russia-is-not-planning-to-conduct-any-humanitarian-mission-live-361699.html|title=Yatsenyuk: 'We need to survive first'|date=22 August 2014|work=Kyiv Post}}</ref> As of May 2018, the Russian government rejects claims that Russia bears any responsibility for the crash, and denies involvement. The Russian defense ministry said that it had never deployed anti-aircraft missile systems in Ukraine.<ref name="CNN 5.24.18"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tass.com/defense/1006070|title=No Russian air defense missile systems crossed Russia-Ukraine border — top brass|work=TASS|access-date=25 May 2018|language=ru}}</ref> [[#Russian media coverage|Several false conspiracy theories about the crash]] have since appeared in Russian media, including that the aircraft was followed by a Ukrainian [[Military aircraft|military jet]].<ref name=newyork/><ref name="WaPoJuly22">Greg Miller (22 July 2014), [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-discloses-intelligence-on-downing-of-malaysian-jet/2014/07/22/b178fe58-11e1-11e4-98ee-daea85133bc9_story.html U.S. discloses intelligence on downing of Malaysian jet] ''[[The Washington Post]]''</ref> The Russian Government holds Ukraine responsible since the crash happened in the Ukrainian [[flight information region]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29140593 |title=Ukraine crisis: Poroshenko offers rebels more autonomy |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/mh17-anniversary-in-russia-conspiracy-theories-on-downed-plane-still-find-believers-20150715-gicj7o.html|title=MH17 anniversary: In Russia, conspiracy theories on downed plane still find believers|date=15 July 2015|author=Nick Miller}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.merdeka.com/teknologi/internet-dipenuhi-berita-konspirasi-penembakan-mh17.html|title=Internet dipenuhi berita konspirasi penembakan MH17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.parhlo.com/flight-mh17s-weirdest-conspiracy/|title=Flight MH17's weirdest conspiracy}}</ref>
The [[Ukrainian Air Force]] (UAF) was used extensively in operations against the rebels, and several [[List of Ukrainian aircraft losses during the Ukrainian crisis|UAF aircraft had been shot down over the rebel-controlled territory]], both before and after the MH17 incident. Immediately after the crash, a post appeared on the [[VKontakte]] social media profile attributed to [[Igor Girkin]], leader of the Donbass separatist militia, claiming responsibility for shooting down a Ukrainian [[Antonov An-26|An-26]] military transporter near [[Torez]].<ref name="VK Wall"/> This post was removed later the same day, and the separatists then denied shooting down any aircraft.<ref name="vk.com"/><ref name="Arthur Bright"/><ref name="auto1">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/20/three-pro-russia-rebel-leaders-suspects-over-downed-mh17 |title=The Guardian 20 July 2014 |author=Alec Luhn |work=The Guardian |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref> In late July 2014, communications intercepts were made public in which, it is claimed, separatists are heard discussing an aircraft that they had downed.<ref name="Landay">{{cite web |last=Landay |first=Jonathan S. |url=http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2014/07/22/3762980/us-officials-we-still-dont-know.html |title=WASHINGTON: U.S. officials still don't know who shot down Malaysian airliner | World |work=The Bellingham Herald |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="ONE News">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/militants-admit-shooting-down-mh17-reports-6031634 |title=Militants admit to shooting down MH17 – reports |publisher=ONE News |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="Demirjian">{{cite news |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/07/20/watch-ukraines-pro-russian-rebels-discuss-mh17s-black-box-in-secret-recording/ |title=Watch: Ukraine's pro-Russian rebels discuss MH17′s black box in secret recording |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-militants-mh17-transcript-2014-7?r=US&IR=T&IR=T|title='I'm Nearby The Place Where The Bodies Started Falling': Chilling Transcript Of Militants Realizing They Shot Down An Airliner With Nearly 300 People Aboard|work=Business Insider|access-date=13 April 2018}}</ref> A video from the crash site, recorded by the rebels and obtained by [[News Corp Australia]], shows the first rebel soldiers to arrive at the crash site. At first they assumed that the downed aircraft was a Ukrainian military jet, and were dismayed when they started to realise that it was a civilian airliner.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-updates/incidents/neverbeforeseen-footage-reveals-russianbacked-rebels-arriving-at-the-wreckage-of-mh17/news-story/c5f6bc5e9629a22d17fe2680bfbd61a5|title=The shocking aftermath of MH17|work=NewsComAu|access-date=18 March 2018}}</ref>
==Aircraft== Flight 17, which was also marketed as [[KLM]] Flight 4103 (KL4103) through a [[codeshare agreement]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Statement Malaysia Airlines MH17 |url=http://news.klm.com/en/incident-with-malaysia-airlines-flight-mh017-e/ |website=[[KLM]] |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> was operated with a Boeing 777-2H6ER,{{efn|The aircraft is a Boeing 777-200ER (for Extended Range) model; Boeing assigns a [[List of Boeing customer codes|unique customer code]] for each company that buys one of its aircraft, which is applied as an [[infix]] in the model number at the time the aircraft is built. The code for Malaysia Airlines is "H6", hence "777-2H6ER".}} serial number 28411, registration 9M-MRD.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|30}} The 84th Boeing 777 produced, it first flew on 17 July 1997, exactly 17 years before the incident, and was delivered new to Malaysia Airlines on 29 July 1997.<ref name="airfleets1">{{cite web |url=http://www.airfleets.net/ficheapp/plane-b777-28411.htm# |title=Malaysia Airlines 9M-MRD (Boeing 777 – MSN 28411) | Airfleets aviation |publisher=Airfleets.net |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> Powered by two [[Rolls-Royce Trent 800|Rolls-Royce Trent 892]] engines and carrying 280 seats (33 [[Business class|business]] and 247 [[Economy class|economy]]), the aircraft had recorded more than 76,300 hours in 11,430 cycles before the crash.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|30}} The aircraft was in an airworthy condition at departure.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|31}}
The Boeing 777, which entered commercial service on 7 June 1995, has one of the best safety records among commercial aircraft.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/07/17/boeing-777-safe-track-record/12786181/ |title=Boeing 777 has excellent track record, experts say |author=Larry Copeland |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> In June 2014 there were about 1,212 aircraft in service, with 340 more on order.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/displaystandardreport.cfm?cboCurrentModel=777&optReportType=AllModels&cboAllModel=777&ViewReportF=View+Report |title=777 Model Orders and Deliveries summary |publisher=Boeing |date=June 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref>
==Passengers and crew== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin:0 0 0.5em 1em; float:right; font-size:85%;" |- |+People on board by nationality<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|27}} |- !Nation||data-sort-type="number"|Number<!-- OFFICIAL LIST PER THE OFFICIAL DSB REPORT, DON'T MODIFY --> |- | {{flag|Australia}} || style="text-align:center;"|27 |- | {{flag|Belgium}} || style="text-align:center;"|4 |- | {{flag|Canada}}{{efn|Dual Canadian-Romanian citizen boarding with Canadian passport.}} || style="text-align:center;"|1 |- | {{flag|Germany}}{{efn|Including: * 1 dual German-Dutch citizen}} || style="text-align:center;"|4 |- | {{flag|Indonesia}} || style="text-align:center;"|12 |- | {{flag|Malaysia}}{{efn|28 passengers and 15 crew}} || style="text-align:center;"|43 |- | {{flag|Netherlands}}{{efn|Including: * 1 dual Dutch-Belgian citizen;
