and * 1 dual British-New Zealand citizen.}} || style="text-align:center;"|10 |- class="sortbottom" | '''Total''' || style="text-align:center;"|'''298''' |}
The incident is the deadliest airliner shootdown incident to date.<ref name=reuters>{{cite news |url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/malaysia-airlines-mh17-shot-down-top-5-deadliest-attacks-on-airliners/1271130 |title=Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17: Top 5 deadliest airliner shootdowns |agency=Reuters |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> All 283 passengers and 15 crew died.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|27}} By 19 July, the airline had determined the nationalities of all 298 passengers and crew.<ref name="Official nationalities"/>
The crew were all Malaysian, while over two-thirds (68%) of the passengers were Dutch. Most of the other passengers were Malaysians and Australians, the remainder were citizens of 7 other countries.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|27}}
Among the passengers were delegates en route to the [[XX International AIDS Conference, 2014|20th International AIDS Conference]] in Melbourne, including [[Joep Lange]], a former president of the [[International AIDS Society]], which organised the conference.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/crash-claims-top-aids-researchers-heading-to-melbourne-20140718-zuaw3.html |title=Crash claims top AIDS researchers heading to Melbourne |last=Lillebuen |first=Steve |date=18 July 2014 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> Many initial reports had erroneously indicated that around 100 delegates to the conference were aboard, but this was later revised to six.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Robin |first1=Myriam |title=100 AIDS researchers on MH17? Why and how the media got it wrong |url=http://www.crikey.com.au/2014/07/23/100-aids-researchers-on-mh17-why-and-how-the-media-got-it-wrong/ |website=[[Crikey]] |accessdate=23 July 2014 |date=23 July 2014}}</ref> Also on board were [[Senate (Netherlands)|Dutch Senator]] [[Willem Witteveen]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2686/Binnenland/article/detail/3691664/2014/07/18/Senator-Witteveen-PvdA-omgekomen-bij-crash.dhtml |title=Senator Witteveen (PvdA) omgekomen bij crash – Binnenland – VK |work=De Volkskrant |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> Australian author [[Liam Davison]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Victorians among those killed in MH17 crash: Premier |url=http://www.bendigoadvertiser.com.au/story/2426085/victorians-among-those-killed-in-mh17-crash-premier/?cs=80 |work=[[Bendigo Advertiser]] |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> and Malaysian actress [[Shuba Jay]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysian actress, Dutch hubby and baby die with MH17 |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/malaysian-actress-dutch-hubby-and-baby-die-with-mh17 |publisher=The Malaysian Insider |accessdate=19 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722064912/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/malaysian-actress-dutch-hubby-and-baby-die-with-mh17 |archivedate=22 July 2014 |df= }}</ref>
At least twenty family groups were on board the aircraft, and eighty of the passengers were under the age of 18.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/asia/south-east-asia/story/malaysia-airlines-mh17-crash-20-families-gone-one-shot-20140721 |title=Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash: 20 families gone in one shot |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |date=21 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RF430C7G?url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/asia/south-east-asia/story/malaysia-airlines-mh17-crash-20-families-gone-one-shot-20140721 |archivedate=21 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Miranda |first1=Charles |first2=Cindy |last2=Wockner |first3=Ian |last3=McPhedran |author-link3=Ian McPhedran|first4=Jacquelin |last4=Magnay |url=http://www.news.com.au/world/mh17-train-in-kharkiv-as-tony-abbott-says-mh17-aftermath-is-evidence-tampering-on-industrial-scale/story-fndir2ev-1226996838429 |title=MH17 train in Kharkiv as Tony Abbott says MH17 aftermath is evidence tampering on industrial scale |publisher=[[News Corp Australia]] |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724092335/http://www.news.com.au/world/mh17-train-in-kharkiv-as-tony-abbott-says-mh17-aftermath-is-evidence-tampering-on-industrial-scale/story-fndir2ev-1226996838429|archivedate=24 July 2015}}</ref>

==Background== {{See also|2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|War in Donbass}}
Some [[airlines]] started to avoid [[Eastern Ukraine|eastern Ukrainian]] airspace in early March 2014 due to safety concerns.<ref name=20140718BBC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-28356745 |title=MH17 crash: Airlines divert flights from eastern Ukraine |publisher=BBC |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/18/airlines-avoid-ukraine-airspace-mh17|title=Many airlines have avoided Ukrainian airspace for months|last=Neate|first=Rupert|last2=Glenza|first2=Jessica|date=18 July 2014|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=12 June 2018}}</ref> In April, the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] warned governments that there was a risk to commercial passenger flights over south-eastern Ukraine.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|217}} The American [[Federal Aviation Administration]] issued restrictions on flights over [[Crimea]], to the south of MH17's route, and advised airlines flying over some other parts of Ukraine to "exercise extreme caution". This warning did not include the MH17 crash region.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/17/us-ukraine-crisis-airplane-warnings-idUSKBN0FM2BV20140717 |title=U.S. air carriers to avoid Russia-Ukraine border airspace |agency=Reuters |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=telegraph-20140717>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10974823/Air-operators-belatedly-avoid-Ukraine-war-zone.html |title=Air operators belatedly avoid Ukraine war zone |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014 |first=Tom |last=Whitehead}}</ref> 37 airlines continued overflying eastern Ukraine and about 900 flights crossed the [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk region]] in the seven days before the Boeing 777 was shot down.<ref name=spiegel-981813>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/malaysia-airlines-mh17-lufthansa-ueberflog-ost-ukraine-56-mal-a-981813.html |title=Absturz von Flug MH17: Lufthansa flog zuletzt 56-mal über Kriegsgebiet |trans-title=Crash of Flight MH17: Lufthansa lately flew 56 times over crisis region |language=German |work=Der Spiegel |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref>
On 14 June 2014, a [[Ukrainian Air Force]] [[Ilyushin Il-76]] aircraft [[Ukrainian Air Force Ilyushin Il-76 shoot-down|was shot down]] on approach to [[Luhansk International Airport]]; all 49 people on board died.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|183}} On 29 June, Russian news agencies reported that insurgents had obtained a [[Buk missile system]] after having taken control of a Ukrainian air defence base (possibly the former location of the 156th Anti-Aircraft Missile Regiment [156 zrp]).<ref name=vor-20140629>{{cite news |url=http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_06_29/Donetsk-militia-takes-control-of-Ukrainian-anti-air-installation-1561/ |title=Donetsk militia takes control of Ukrainian anti-air installation |newspaper=Voice of Russia |date=29 June 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=itar290614>{{cite news |url=http://itar-tass.com/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/1287030 |script-title=ru:Ополченцы ДНР взяли под контроль воинскую часть ПВО с зенитно-ракетными комплексами "Бук" |trans-title=DNR militias seized an air defence base with anti-aircraft missile systems "Buk" |agency=[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia]] |language=Russian |date=29 June 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ntv.ru/novosti/1085256/ |work=NTV News |publisher=[[NTV (Russia)|NTV]] |script-title=ru:Донецкие ополченцы обзавелись зенитно-ракетными комплексами "Бук" |trans-title=Donetsk militias acquired anti-aircraft missile systems "Buk" |language=Russian |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> On the same day, the [[Donetsk People's Republic]] claimed possession of such a system in a since-deleted [[Twitter|tweet]].<ref name=itar290614/><ref name="thediplomat">{{cite news |url=http://thediplomat.com/2014/07/malaysian-airlines-flight-mh17-shot-down-over-donetsk-ukraine/ |title=Malaysian Airlines Flight MH17 Shot Down Over Donetsk, Ukraine |first=Ankit |last=Panda |date=17 July 2014 |work=The Diplomat |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref>
On 14 July 2014, a Ukrainian Air Force [[Antonov-26|An-26]] transport plane flying at {{convert|6500|m|ft|abbr=on}} was shot down.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|183}} The militia reportedly claimed via social media that a Buk missile launcher had been used to bring down the aircraft.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vz.ru/news/2014/7/14/695525.html |title=Ополченцы сообщили, из чего сбили украинский Ан-26 |publisher=Vzglyad |quote=Today the self-defence destroyed An-26 airplane using SAM "9К37М1" (better known as 'Buk') ... said the militia, distributed in social networks [translation after ellipsis from Google translate] |date=14 July 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> American officials later said evidence suggested the aircraft had been shot down from [[Russia|Russian territory]].<ref name="BakerNYT">[[Peter Baker (author)|Peter Baker]] (18 July 2014), [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/19/world/europe/malaysia-airlines-plane-ukraine.html U.S. Sees Evidence of Russian Links to Jet's Downing] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> On 16 July, a [[Sukhoi Su-25]] [[close air support]] aircraft was also shot down. The Ukrainian government said the Russian military had shot down the aircraft with an [[air-to-air missile]] fired by a [[Mikoyan MiG-29|MiG-29]] jet in Russia; a spokesman for the [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian defence ministry]] rejected that report as "absurd".<ref name="bbc">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28345039 |title=Ukraine conflict: Russia accused of shooting down jet |date=17 July 2014 |publisher=BBC News |location=London |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="rfe/rl on rejection of accusation">{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/ukraine-russia-jet-shot-down-blame/25460575.html |title=Russia Rejects 'Absurd' Accusation Over Downed Ukrainian Jet |date=17 July 2014 |work=[[RFE/RL]] |publisher=RFE/RL |location=Prague |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> According to the Dutch newspaper ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', the Ukrainian government also warned the [[government of the Netherlands]] and other European countries about dangers in flying over the [[East Ukraine]] three days prior to the shootdown<ref>[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2015/01/24/7056198/ Netherlands knew about dangers of flying over Donbas prior to the MH17 tragedy]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. 24 January 2015</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150124134504/http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/23592584/___Info_MH17_niet_geheim___.html Vertrouwelijkheid MH17 is onzin]. [[De Telegraaf]]. 23 January 2015</ref> due to the downing of the An-26 transport aircraft on 14 July.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150124134709/http://news.liga.net/news/politics/2526560-na_luganshchine_ischezla_svyaz_s_samoletom_ato_an_26.htm Communication was lost with the plane AN26 of ATO forces in the Luhansk region]. LIGANews. 14 July 2014</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150124135123/http://www.unian.ua/politics/939378-u-luganskiy-oblasti-boyoviki-zbili-ukrajinskiy-litak-lotchik-katapultuvavsya-ochevidtsi.html In Luhansk Oblast militants downed Ukrainian plane, pilot was ejected – witnesses]. [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency]]. 14 July 2014</ref>
On 15 July 2014, following his visit to [[Kiev]], Polish Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Radosław Sikorski]] warned about the dangers posed by the continued Russian military support for pro-Russian separatists, especially [[surface-to-air missile|ground-to-air missiles]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2014/07/polish-politics |title=Polish politics: Where is Radek? |work=[[The Economist]] |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> On 17 July, an [[Associated Press]] journalist saw a Buk launcher in [[Snizhne]], a town in [[Donetsk Oblast]], {{convert|16|km|mi|0}} southeast of the crash site. The reporter also saw seven separatist [[tank]]s near the town.<ref name="leonard">{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/ukraine-air-force-jet-downed-russian-missile-102817809.html |author=Peter Leonard |title=Ukraine: Air Force jet downed by Russian missile |publisher=ABC News |agency=Associated Press |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=17 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113123101/http://news.yahoo.com/ukraine-air-force-jet-downed-russian-missile-102817809.html |archivedate=13 January 2016}}</ref> [[Associated Press]] journalists reported that the Buk M-1 was operated by a man "with unfamiliar fatigues and a distinctive Russian accent" escorted by two civilian vehicles.<ref name=Karmanau>{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/what-happened-day-flight-17-was-downed |title=What happened? The day Flight 17 was downed |author1=Yuras Karmanau |author2=Peter Leonard |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Associated Press |date=25 July 2014 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009123439/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/what-happened-day-flight-17-was-downed |archivedate=9 October 2014}}</ref> The battle around [[Savur-Mohyla]] has been suggested as the possible context within which the missile that brought down MH17 was fired, as separatists deployed increasingly sophisticated [[anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft weaponry]] in this battle, and had brought down several Ukrainian [[jet aircraft|jets]] in July.<ref>Daily Telegraph, 14 November 2014,[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11231333/The-unlikely-pilgrimage-site-of-Saur-Mogila.html the unlikely pilgrimage site of saur mogila]</ref> A Ukrainian [[Antonov-26|An-26]] was scheduled to deliver [[paratrooper]]s to the battle arena on 17 July and, according to Russian expert Vadim Lukashevich, the separatists "might have been waiting just for them".<ref>{{cite web |title=17 июля в зону АТО должен был вылететь транспортный Ан-26 с украинскими десантниками|trans-title=On 17 July an An-26 transport was to fly with Ukrainian paratroopers |language=Russian |url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/inquests/68762.html |accessdate=10 June 2015 |date=10 June 2015}}</ref> According to the final report of the [[Dutch Safety Board]], no An-26 was downed in Eastern Ukraine that day.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|182}}
On 5 June 2014, the airspace above [[Donetsk Oblast]] was closed by Ukraine below {{convert|26000|feet}} and on 14 July that below {{convert|32000|feet}} was closed.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|179–180}} A few hours before the shootdown the Russian [[Air traffic control|ATC]] issued [[NOTAM]] UUUUV6158/14 which closed the Russian [[airspace]] in the adjacent area below {{convert|53000|feet}} ([[Flight level|FL]] 530). The reason given was "armed conflict in Ukraine", but such a high altitude was not justified by previous incidents and was comparable with the {{convert|18000|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} range of the [[Buk missile system|Buk missile]]. The Dutch Safety Board asked Russian ATC for further explanation but "did not receive any clarity on the meaning of the restriction to FL 530"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/uploads/phase-docs/1006/debcd724fe7breport-mh17-crash.pdf|title=MH17 Crash|website=Dutch Safety Board|pages=180|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="NYT Maps">{{cite news |title=Maps of the Crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/07/17/world/europe/maps-of-the-crash-of-malaysian-airlines-flight-mh17.html |date=21 July 2014 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> As with other countries, Ukraine receives [[Freedoms of the air|overflight fees]] for commercial aircraft that fly through their borders and this may have contributed to the continued availability of civilian flight paths through the conflict zone, and so flights were allowed that time over FL 320 in the area (MH17 was at FL 330 at the incident)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/aviation/ukraine-responsible-for-airspace-safety-iata-20140720-zuzmp.html |title=Ukraine responsible for airspace safety: IATA |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |first=Jamie |last=Freed |date=20 July 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=smh-20140718>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/aviation/mh17-disaster-flights-over-war-zones-because-its-cheaper-20140718-zua0y.html |title=MH17 disaster: Flights over war zones 'because it's cheaper |author1=Tom Whitehead |author2=Nick Collins |author3=Martin Evans |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref>
==Crash== [[File:MH17 map-en.svg|thumb|upright=1.364|Route of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] [[File:MH17 Flight Route (en).svg|thumb|upright=1.364|Routes of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17) and Singapore Airlines Flight 351 (SQ351), including airspace restrictions]]
On Thursday, 17 July 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 departed from [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol]] Gate G3 at 12:13 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] (10:13 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|23}} and took off at 12:31 local time (10:31 UTC). It was due to arrive at [[Kuala Lumpur International Airport]] at 06:10 [[Time in Malaysia|MYT]], Friday, 18 July (22:10 UTC, 17 July).<ref name=BBCbothsides/>
According to the original flight plan, MH17 was to fly over Ukraine at [[flight level]] 330 (33,000 feet or 10,060 metres) and then change to FL 350 around the Ukrainian city of [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. When it reached the area as planned, at 15:53 [[Eastern European Summer Time|local time]] (12:53 UTC), [[Dnipropetrovsk]] Air Control (''Dnipro Control'') asked MH17 if they could climb to FL 350 as planned, and also to avoid a potential [[Conflict (air traffic control)|separation conflict]] with another flight, [[Singapore Airlines]] Flight 351 (SQ351), also at FL 330. The crew asked to remain at FL 330 and the air control approved this request, moving the other flight to FL 350. At 16:00 local time (13:00 UTC), the crew asked for a deviation of {{convert|20|nmi|km}} to the left (north) of course, on [[Airway (aviation)|airway]] L980, due to weather conditions. This request was also approved by ''Dnipro Control'' [[Air traffic control|ATC]]. The crew then asked if they could climb to FL 340, which was rejected as this flight level was not available, so MH17 remained at FL 330. At 16:19 local time (13:19 UTC), ''Dnipro Control'' noticed that the flight was {{convert|3.6|nmi|km}} north of the centreline of approved airway and instructed MH17 to return to the track. At 16:19 local time (13:19 UTC), ''Dnipro Control'' contacted Russian ATC in [[Rostov-on-Don]] (''RND Control'') by telephone and requested clearance to transfer the flight to Russian [[airspace]]. After obtaining the permission, ''Dnipro Control'' attempted to contact MH17 for handing them off to ''RND Control'' at 16:20 local time (13:20 UTC), but the aircraft did not respond. When MH17 did not respond to several calls, ''Dnipro Control'' contacted ''RND Control'' again to check if they could see the aircraft on their radar. ''RND Control'' confirmed that the plane had disappeared.<ref name="dsb1"/>
The Dutch Safety Board reported a last flight data recording at 16:20 local time (13:20 UTC), located west of the [[urban-type settlement]] Rozsypne (Розсипне), near [[Hrabove, Donetsk Oblast|Hrabove]] heading [[Points of the compass|east-southeast]] (ESE, 115°) at {{convert|494|kn|km/h mph}}.<ref name="dsb1"/>
At exactly 16:20:03 local time (13:20:03 UTC) a [[Buk missile system|Buk]] [[surface-to-air|ground-to-air missile]], which had been launched from an area east from the aircraft, detonated outside the aircraft just above the cockpit to the left. An [[Uncontrolled decompression|explosive decompression]] occurred, resulting in both the cockpit and tail sections tearing away from the middle portion of the fuselage. All three sections disintegrated as they fell rapidly towards the ground.
The majority of debris landed near [[Hrabove, Donetsk Oblast|Hrabove]], a village located north of [[Torez]] in eastern Ukraine's [[Donetsk Oblast]]. The debris spread over a {{convert|50|km2|mi2}} area to the southwest of Hrabove.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report" />{{rp|53}} The fireball on impact is believed to have been captured on video.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10975094/Malaysia-Airlines-crash-video-believed-to-show-moment-of-planes-impact.html |title=Malaysia Airlines crash: video believed to show moment of plane's impact |work=The Telegraph |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> Photographs from the site of the crash show scattered pieces of broken [[fuselage]] and [[Aircraft engine|engine]] parts, bodies, and passports.<ref name="huffington">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/07/17/malaysia-airlines-mh17-passenger-jet-crashes-ukraine-near-russian-border_n_5595450.html |title=Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 'Shot Down in Ukraine Near Russian Border' |first=Sara C |last=Nelson |date=17 July 2014 |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |location=United Kingdom |accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> Some of the wreckage fell close to houses.<ref name="Telegraaf22866550">{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/22866550/__Vliegtuig_crasht_in_Oekraine__.html |title=Maleisisch passagiersvliegtuig in Oekraïne neergestort |trans-title=Malaysian passenger aircraft shot down in Ukraine |work=[[De Telegraaf]] |language=Dutch |accessdate=17 July 2014 |date=17 July 2014}}</ref> Dozens of bodies fell into crop fields, and some fell into houses.<ref>{{cite news |author=Cahal Milmo |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/malaysia-airlines-mh17-crash-no-forensic-investigators-coordination-or-body-bags-as-locals-are-left-to-scour-the-gruesome-scene-9615895.html |title=Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash: No forensic investigators, co-ordination or body bags as Ukraine locals are left to scour gruesome scene |work=The Independent |date=19 July 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref>
Three other commercial aircraft were in the same area when the Malaysian plane crashed: [[Air India]] Flight 113 (AI113), a [[Boeing 787]] en route from [[Delhi]] to [[Birmingham]], [[EVA Air]] Flight 88 (BR88), a [[Boeing 777]] en route from [[Paris]] to [[Taipei]], and the closest aircraft [[Singapore Airlines]] Flight 351 (SQ351) was {{convert|33|km|mi}} away, a Boeing 777 en route from [[Copenhagen]] to [[Singapore]].<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|41}}
==Recovery of bodies== [[File:Arrival of corpses from MH17 at Eindhoven Airport.jpg|thumb|First arrival of bodies at [[Eindhoven Airport]]]] A Ukraine Foreign Ministry representative said that the bodies found at the crash site would be taken to [[Kharkiv]] for identification, {{convert|270|km|mi}} to the north. By the day after the crash, 181 of the 298 bodies had been found.<ref name=ap-20140718>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/official-181-bodies-found-at-mh17-crash-site/article6225245.ece |title=Official: 181 bodies found at MH17 crash site |agency=Associated Press |work=The Hindu |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> Some were observed being placed in [[body bag]]s and loaded onto lorries.<ref name=APBodies>{{cite news |title=Raw: Crews begin moving bodies at jet crash site |url=https://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/nation/2014/07/19/12883715/ |accessdate=19 July 2014 |work=[[USA Today]] |agency=Associated Press |date=19 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=SMHBodies>{{cite news |last1=Miller |first1=Nick |title=MH17: 'Unknown groups' use body bags |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/mh17-unknown-groups-use-body-bags-20140719-3c8dl.html |accessdate=19 July 2014 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=19 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=GuardianBodies>{{cite news |last1=Grytsenko |first1=Oksana |title=MH17: armed rebels fuel chaos as rotting corpses pile up on the roadside |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/19/mh17-armed-rebels-chaos-corpses-ukraine |accessdate=19 July 2014 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>
Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte complained about the lack of respect shown to the personal belongings of the dead which were reportedly being looted. He initially announced his disgust about the handling of the bodies that were reportedly being "dragged around" and "thrown", but later stated they had been handled with more care than originally thought.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nu.nl/vliegramp-oekraine/3832485/rutte-geschokt-respectloos-gedrag-rampplek.html |title=Rutte geschokt over 'respectloos gedrag' op rampplek |publisher=[[Nu.nl]] |date=19 July 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014 |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/31522/Vliegtuigcrash-in-Oekraine/article/detail/3693688/2014/07/21/Rutte-Zorgvuldiger-met-lichamen-omgegaan-dan-werd-gevreesd.dhtml |title=Rutte: 'Zorgvuldiger met lichamen omgegaan dan werd gevreesd' |author=Laura de Jong |date=21 July 2014 |website=[[de Volkskrant]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> On 20 July, Ukrainian emergency workers, observed by armed separatists, began loading the remains of the passengers of MH17 into [[Refrigerated van|refrigerated railway wagons]] for transport and identification.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/some-bodies-removed-from-mh17-crash-site-1405849163 |title=Bodies Removed From MH17 Crash Site Human Remains Moved to Railcars at Torez Station |last=Sonne |first=Paul |author2=Alexander Kolyandr, Margaret Coker |date=20 July 2014 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=20 July 2014}}</ref>
On 21 July, pro-Russian rebels allowed Dutch investigators to examine the bodies. By this time, 272 bodies had been recovered, according to Ukrainian officials.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28399406 |title=MH17 plane crash: Dutch experts examine bodies |publisher=BBC |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref> Remains left Torez on a train on the evening of 21 July, en route to Kharkiv to be flown to the Netherlands for identification.<ref name=bbc-train>{{cite web |title=MH17 plane crash: Train with bodies leaves Ukraine station |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28411225 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 July 2014 |date=21 July 2014}}</ref> On the same day, Malaysian Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] announced that the Malaysian government had reached a tentative agreement to retrieve the remains of the Malaysians who died in the crash, following any necessary forensic work.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Marlow |first1=Iain |title=MH17: Malaysia reaches 'behind the scenes' deal to recover bodies |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/mh17-malaysia-reaches-deal-to-recover-bodies-in-race-for-muslim-burials/article19692413/ |accessdate=21 July 2014 |work=The Globe and Mail |date=21 July 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Convoy of MH-17 victims on the highway.jpg|thumb|Convoy of 40 hearses heading to [[Hilversum]], while other traffic stopped]] It was reported on 21 July that with 282 bodies and 87 body fragments found, there were still 16 bodies missing.<ref name="AljazeeraObama7-21">{{cite news |title=Obama calls for Russia 'pivot' on Ukraine as MH17 investigation begins |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/7/21/obama-ukraine-russia.html |accessdate=21 July 2014 |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=21 July 2014}}</ref> An agreement had been reached that the Netherlands would co-ordinate the identification effort. A train carrying the bodies arrived at the [[Malyshev Factory]], Kharkiv on 22 July.<ref name=nyt-20140722>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/23/world/europe/malaysia-airlines-jet-ukraine.html |title=Bodies of Crash Victims Safely Moved Out of Combat Area |first=Andrew |last=Higgins |newspaper=The New York Times |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> Dutch authorities stated that they found 200 bodies on the train when it arrived at Kharkhiv, leaving almost 100 unaccounted for.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/mh17-crash-families-worst-fears-realised-as-bodies-go-missing-20140723-zvv9x.html |title=MH17 crash: families' worst fears realised as bodies go missing |work=The Age |first=Paul |last=McGeough |date=23 July 2014 |accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> In late July, the UK [[Metropolitan Police]] sent specialist officers to Ukraine to assist with the recovery, identification and repatriation of bodies.<ref name=hp-20140719 />
The first remains were flown to [[Eindhoven]] in the Netherlands on 23 July,<ref name="bbc-bodies-kharkiv">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-28416973 |title=MH17 bodies leave Ukraine rebel area and reach Kharkiv |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref> moved there with Dutch air force [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130]] and Australian [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III|C-17]] transport aircraft,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/netherlands-to-coordinate-mh17-victim-identification-efforts-114072100077_1.html |title=Netherlands to coordinate MH17 victim identification efforts | Business Standard News |work=Business Standard |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-22/operation-launched-to-recover-and-identify-mh17-victims/5615332 |title=MH17: Tony Abbott announces Operation Bring Them Home to secure and identify victims of Malaysia Airlines disaster – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> which landed at [[Eindhoven Airport]] just before 16:00 local time.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/mh17-crash-social-media--blackout-tribute-continues-as-first-bodies-are-to-be-flown-to-netherlands-from-ukraine-9622288.html |title=MH17 crash victims: First bodies arrive in Netherlands from Ukraine |author=Heather Saul |date=23 July 2014 |website=[[The Independent]]}}</ref> The day after, another 74 bodies arrived.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nos.nl/artikel/679047-weer-74-kisten-naar-hilversum.html |title=Weer 74 kisten naar Hilversum |date=24 July 2014 |website=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]}}</ref> The examination and identification of the bodies was conducted at the [[Royal Netherlands Army#Services|Netherlands Army]] medical regiment training facility in [[Hilversum]] and was coordinated by a Dutch forensic team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140722/hilversum-treft-voorbereidingen-voor-lichamen-mh17/ |title=Hilversum treft voorbereidingen voor lichamen MH17 |work=Nieuws.nl |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140723204451/http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140722/Hilversum-treft-voorbereidingen-voor-lichamen-MH17 |archive-date=23 July 2014 |dead-url=yes }}</ref>
On 1 August it was announced that a search and recovery mission, including about 80 forensic police specialists from the Netherlands, Malaysia and Australia, and led by Colonel Cornelis Kuijs of the [[Royal Marechaussee]], would use [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]], [[Detection dog|sniffer dogs]], [[Underwater search and recovery|divers]] and [[Satellite imagery|satellite mapping]] to search for missing body parts at the crash site.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11005039/Dutch-and-Australian-police-to-use-drones-divers-and-sniffer-dogs-in-perilous-search-for-victims.html |title=Dutch and Australian police to use drones, divers and sniffer dogs in perilous search for victims |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (London) |date=1 August 2014 |accessdate=3 August 2014 |first=Tom |last=Parfitt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/05/mh17-investigators-frustrated-at-limited-access-due-to-fighting |title=MH17 investigators frustrated at limited access due to fighting, |work=The Guardian |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref> Australian officials had believed that as many as 80 bodies were still at the site,<ref name="Guardian AP" /> but after some days of searching the international team had "found remains of only a few victims" and concluded that "the recovery effort undertaken by local authorities immediately after the crash was more thorough than initially thought."<ref name="FortunatelyMoreWasDone">Toby Sterling, [http://bigstory.ap.org/article/dutch-premier-halts-search-ukraine-victims "Dutch premier halts search for Ukraine victims,"] Associated Press, 6 August 2014. Retrieved 6 August 2014. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141118080619/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/dutch-premier-halts-search-ukraine-victims|date=18 November 2014}}</ref>
On 6 August the Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced that the recovery operation would be temporarily halted due to an upsurge in fighting around the crash site threatening the safety of crash investigators and recovery specialists, and that all international investigators and humanitarian forces conducting searches would leave the country leaving behind a small communications and liaison team.<ref>{{cite web |author=Helen Davidson and agencies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/07/mh17-crash-search-for-remains-halted |title=MH17 crash: search for remains halted as Australia begins day of mourning |work=The Guardian |date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref>
On 22 August the bodies of 20 Malaysians (of 43 killed in the incident) arrived in Malaysia.<ref name=MH17Guardian>{{cite news |title=MH17 bodies arrive in Malaysia |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/22/mh17-bodies-arrive-in-malaysia |accessdate=22 August 2014 |agency=Agence France-Presse in Kuala Lumpur |date=21 August 2014}}</ref> The government announced a National Mourning Day, with a ceremony broadcast live on radio and television.<ref>{{cite news |author=TheStar |title=MH17 day of mourning: White hearses arrive at KLIA |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/08/22/MH17-Day-of-mourning-white-hearses-at-KLIA/ |date=22 August 2014}}</ref>
On 9 October a spokesman for the Dutch national prosecutor's office stated that one victim had been found with an oxygen mask around his neck; a forensic investigation of the mask for fingerprints, saliva and DNA did not produce any results and it is therefore not known how or when that mask got around the neck of the victim.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|99}}
By 5 December 2014, the Dutch-led forensic team had identified the bodies of 292 out of 298 victims of the crash.<ref>{{cite news |last=Grindstad |first=Ingrid |title=Six MH17 victims remain unidentified |url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2014/12/05/six-mh17-victims-remain-unidentified/ |date=5 December 2014 |accessdate=6 December 2014 |newspaper=NL Times}}</ref> In February and April 2015 new remains were found on the site,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/02/ukraine-crisis-mh-idUSL6N0VC3GC20150202 |title=Dutch search team recovers remains, MH17 wreckage in Ukraine |author=Anthony Deutsch |agency=Reuters |date=2 February 2015 |accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=Remains2015>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/dutch-investigators-recover-human-remains-mh17-crash-110138676.html |title=Dutch investigators recover human remains from MH17 crash site |date=21 April 2015 |accessdate=23 April 2015 |agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref> after which only 2 victims, both Dutch citizens, had not been identified.<ref name=Remains2015 />
== Reporting in the mass media == ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', a large-circulation Dutch tabloid, published on 19 July a front page photo-collage of pro-Russian rebel leaders, including Igor Girkin, under the one-word headline "Murderers" ("Moordenaars").<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/malaysia-airlines-mh17-crash-dutch-newspapers-respond-with-anger-and-despair-as-wait-for-return-of-bodies-continues-9618753.html|title=Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash: Dutch newspapers respond with anger and despair as wait for return of bodies continues – Europe – World|author=Adam Withnall|date=21 July 2014|accessdate=22 July 2014|publisher=The Independent}}</ref>
It was suggested on other media that credit and debit cards may have been looted from the bodies of the victims, and the Dutch Banking Association said it would take "preventative measures" against any possible fraud.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ukraine-plane-crash/dutch-banks-respond-reports-mh17-victims-looted-credit-cards-n160246|title=Dutch Banks Respond to Reports of MH17 Victims' Looted Credit Cards|date=19 July 2014|accessdate=20 July 2014|publisher=NBC News}}</ref> There were also accusations that other possessions had been removed and that evidence at the crash site had been destroyed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10978577/MH17-Malaysia-Airlines-crash-victims-robbed-of-their-dignity-by-rebels.html|title=MH17: Malaysia Airlines crash victims robbed of their dignity by rebels|last1=Mendick|first1=Robert|date=19 July 2014|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=20 July 2014|last2=Sawer|first2=Patrick|last3=Ross|first3=Time}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/heartless-looters-raid-malaysian-airlines-flight-mh17-crash-site-article-1.1872047|title=Heartless looters raid Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 crash site, swipe victims' luggage, personal items|last1=Wagner|first1=Meg|date=18 July 2014|work=Daily News|accessdate=20 July 2014|location=New York}}</ref> Dutch prime minister [[Mark Rutte]] acknowledged on 6 August that early reports of chaos and criminality around the site may have been exaggerated.<ref name="FortunatelyMoreWasDone" /> One eye-witness observed that valuable items like shoes and bottles of alcohol were untouched in the wreckage.<ref>Shaun Walker with Harriet Salem and Josh Halliday, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/20/mh17-victims-crash-site-anger-russia-grows "MH17: world's anger at Russia grows as bodies pile on to train at crash site,"] ''The Guardian'', 21 July 2014. Retrieved 6 August 2014.</ref>
==Aftermath== About 90 minutes after the incident, Ukraine closed all routes in Eastern Ukrainian airspace, at all altitudes.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|101}} The incident dramatically heightened fears about airliner shootdowns,<ref>{{cite news |title=Air India flight with 126 on board was right behind MH 17 |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Air-India-flight-with-126-on-board-was-right-behind-MH-17/articleshow/38601142.cms |date=18 July 2014 |work=The Times of India |accessdate=12 November 2014 |quote=<!--"But such fears did not exist over Europe, at least till Terrible Thursday."-->}}</ref> leading to some airlines announcing they would avoid overflying conflict zones.
Shortly after the crash, it was announced that Malaysia Airlines would retire [[flight number]] MH17 and change the Amsterdam–Kuala Lumpur route to [[flight number]] MH19 beginning on 25 July 2014, with the outbound flight unchanged.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/07/18/malaysia-flight-17-retired-numbers/12827633/ |title=Malaysia will stop using No. 17 next week |first=Bart |last=Jansen |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014 |work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref><ref name="ABCAust001">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-21/mh17-malaysia-airlines-retires-flight-number-out-of-respect-/5610864 |title=MH17: Malaysia Airlines retires flight number after Ukraine crash |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref> In association with the retirement of the Boeing 777 aircraft type from Malaysia Airlines' fleet, Malaysia Airlines terminated service to Amsterdam, opting to codeshare with [[KLM Royal Dutch Airlines|KLM]] on the KUL-AMS route for service beyond 25 January 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://airlineroute.net/2015/12/03/mh-amscdg-jan16cxld/ |title=Malaysia Airlines Cancels Amsterdam / Paris Routes from late-Jan 2016 |work=Airlineroute.net |date=3 December 2015 |accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> On 18 July 2014, shares in Malaysia Airlines dropped by nearly 16%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/malaysia-airlines-shares-tank-2014-7 |title=Malaysia Airlines Shares Tank |publisher=Business Insider |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref>
On 23 July 2014, two Ukrainian military jets were hit by missiles at the altitude of {{convert|17000|ft}} close to the area of the MH17 crash. According to the [[National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Council]], preliminary information indicated that the missiles came from Russia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trust.org/item/20140723154118-im9dy |title=Ukraine: missiles that brought down jets may have been fired from Russia |accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
In July 2015, Malaysia proposed that the [[United Nations Security Council]] set up an international tribunal to prosecute those deemed responsible for the downing of the plane. The Malaysian resolution gained a majority on the Security Council, but was vetoed by Russia.<ref name="churkin" /> Russia had proposed its own rival draft resolution, which pushed for a greater U.N. role in an investigation into what caused the downing of the aircraft and demanded justice, but their proposal would not have set up a tribunal.<ref name="veto" />
On 9 June 2016, a Russian businessman claimed that the shooting down of the plane put an end to [[Novorossiya (confederation)|hopes of a Russian nation in Ukraine]] and prolonged the War in Donbass.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Loiko|first1=Sergei|title=The Unraveling Of Moscow's 'Novorossia' Dream|url=http://www.rferl.mobi/a/unraveling-moscow-novorossia-dream/27772641.html|website=Radio Free Liberty}}</ref>
==Investigation== Two parallel investigations were led by the Dutch, one into the technical cause of the crash, and a separate criminal inquiry.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/11/us-ukraine-mh17-bodies-idUSKCN0IV1NJ20141111?feedType=RSS&virtualBrandChannel=11563 |title=Where are the bodies, MH17 families ask |author=Anthony Deutsch |agency=Reuters |accessdate=11 November 2014 |date=11 November 2014}}</ref> The technical report was released on 13 October 2015,<ref name="FinalReportDate">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/final-report-on-downing-of-malaysia-airlines-flight-mh17-due-october-1440675525 |title=Final Report on Downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 Due October |last=Wall |first=Robert |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=27 August 2015}}</ref> while the criminal investigation reported some of their findings in September 2016.<ref name="NLTimesJIT"/><ref name="BBC News 28 September 2016"/> According to the [[Convention on International Civil Aviation]], the country in which an aviation incident occurs is responsible for the investigation, but that country may delegate the investigation to another state; Ukraine has delegated the leadership of both investigations to the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite news |title=MH17 investigation – why is Malaysia excluded? |first=Julie |last=Lévesque |newspaper=eTN Global Travel Industry News |date=3 December 2014 |accessdate=21 December 2014 |url=http://www.eturbonews.com/53217/mh17-investigation-why-malaysia-excluded}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Parker |first1=Andrew |last2=Olearchyk |first2=Roman |title=Netherlands to lead MH17 investigation |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/19c29f34-10e1-11e4-b116-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F19c29f34-10e1-11e4-b116-00144feabdc0.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer= |accessdate=22 July 2014 |work=Financial Times |agency=Financial Times Ltd |date=21 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Bewerkt door: redactie |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/31522/Vliegtuigcrash-in-Oekraine/article/detail/3698000/2014/07/24/Nederlandse-leidersrol-krijgt-juridische-basis.dhtml |title=Nederlandse leidersrol krijgt juridische basis −0 Vliegtuigcrash in Oekraïne – VK |work=De Volkskrant |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dutch Safety Board heads investigation: investigation effort in full swing, black boxes currently being read out |url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/uploads/fm/2014_07_23_PB_OVV_neemt_leiding_over_ENG_DEF.pdf |website=onderzoeksraad.nl |publisher=[[Dutch Safety Board]], The Hague |accessdate=24 July 2014 |date=23 July 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ShCuUTie?url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/uploads/fm/2014_07_23_PB_OVV_neemt_leiding_over_ENG_DEF.pdf |archivedate=19 September 2014 |df= }} ()</ref>
===On-site investigation=== <!--{{2013–2014 unrest in Ukraine}} Already covered and more appropriate at bottom of article in a collapsible bar anyway --> In the hours following the crash, a meeting was convened of the [[Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine|Trilateral Contact Group]]. After they had held a video conference with representatives of insurgents affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (who controlled the area where the aircraft crashed), the rebels promised to "provide safe access and security guarantees" to "the national investigation commission" by co-operating with Ukrainian authorities and OSCE ([[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]]) monitors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.osce.org/home/121390 |title=Press statement by the Trilateral Contact Group |publisher=Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=18 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908053442/http://www.osce.org/home/121390 |archivedate=8 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> During the first two days of investigation, the militants prevented the OSCE and the workers of [[State Emergency Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Emergencies Ministry]] from freely working at the crash site. [[Andrei Purgin]], a leader of the Donetsk People's Republic, declared later that "we will guarantee the safety of international experts on the scene as soon as Kiev concludes a ceasefire agreement".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/20/mh17-pro-russia-rebels-crash-site-kiev-ceasefire |title=MH17: pro-Russia rebels will allow access to crash site if ceasefire agreed |author=Shaun Walker |work=The Guardian |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Investigation of the crash site of MH-17.jpg|thumb|Dutch and Australian police at the crash site on 3 August 2014]] By 18 July 2014, the [[flight data recorder]] and the [[cockpit voice recorder]] had been recovered by separatists,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/07/18/malaysia-airlines-mh17-black-boxes-reportedly-recovered-russia-denies-it-will-take-them-from-rebels/ |title=Malaysia Airlines MH17 black boxes reportedly recovered, Russia denies it will take them from rebels |work=National Post |date=22 May 2014 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> and three days later were handed over to Malaysian officials in [[Donetsk]].<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|44}} The voice recorder was damaged but there was no evidence that data had been tampered with.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|45}}
The [[National Bureau of Air Accidents Investigation of Ukraine]], which led investigations, both off-site and on-site, during the first days after the crash,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbaai.gov.ua/news.html?id=6&lang=ua |title=Розслідування катастрофи літака Boeing 777 |publisher=NBAAI |date=18–25 August 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref> had by August 2014 delegated the investigation to the DSB because of the large number of Dutch passengers and the flight having originated in [[Amsterdam]].<ref>"[http://onderzoeksraad.nl/en/onderzoek/2049/investigation-crash-mh17-17-july-2014/onderzoek/1559/questions-and-answers-concerning-the-investigation-into-flight-mh17#fasen Investigation crash MH17, 17 July 2014]." [[Dutch Safety Board]]. Retrieved 22 August 2014. "Ukraine has transferred responsibility for investigating the cause of the crash to the Dutch Safety Board. The request came from Ukraine. This request was made because the flight departed from the Netherlands, and due to the large number of Dutch nationals who died in the crash"</ref><ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/>{{rp|14}}<ref>[http://nos.nl/nieuwsuur/artikel/2139769-mh17-misbruikt-voor-opvoeren-spanning-met-rusland.html 'MH17 misbruikt voor opvoeren spanning met Rusland' ''(in Dutch)''], ''NOS''</ref>
On 22 July 2014, a Malaysian team of 133 officials, search and recovery personnel, and forensics, technical and medical experts arrived in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news |title=MH17 plane crash: Dutch experts examine bodies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-28399406 |accessdate=22 July 2014 |publisher=BBC |date=21 July 2014}}</ref> Also Australia sent a 45-member panel headed by former lead Australia's MH17 probe Panel |url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/07/mh370-search-coordinator-to-lead-australias-mh17-probe-panel/ |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |publisher=news.biharprabha.com |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref> Approximately 200 special forces soldiers from Australia were also deployed to provide support for the JIT investigators.<ref name="smhabbotttroops">{{cite before the full international team could start working at the crash site,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/01/mh17-investigators-reach-crash-site-ukraine-search-bodies |title=MH17 investigators reach crash site two weeks after plane brought down |work=The Guardian |date=1 August 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref> under the leadership of the [[Ministry of |url=http://www.houseofrepresentatives.nl/sites/www.houseofrepresentatives.nl/files/news_items/140728ambtelijke_briefing_mh17_beknopt_engels_1.doc |title=Summary Report of a Briefing at Civil Service Level |publisher=[[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] |date=28 July 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref>
On 30 July 2014, a Ukrainian representative said that pro-Russian rebels had mined approaches to the crash site and moved heavy artillery.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/still-no-safe-passage-to-malaysia-airlines-crash-site-1406714025 |title=Still No Safe Passage to Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Crash Site in Eastern Ukraine |first1=Alexander |last1=Kolyandr |first2=Gabriele |last2=Steinhauser |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=30 July 2014 |accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref>
On 6 August 2014, the experts left the crash site due to concerns about their safety.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=Outlook India |agency=Press Trust of India |title=21 More MH17 Crash Victims Identified, Experts Leave Site |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/news/article/21-More-MH17-Crash-Victims-Identified-Experts-Leave-Site/854102 |date=8 August 2014 |accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> In mid-September they unsuccessfully attempted to regain access to the site.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!-- no author--> |title=Netherlands deploys more experts to probe MH17 crash |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/netherlands-deploys-more-experts-to-probe-mh17-crash/498540-2.html |agency=Press Trust of India |newspaper=CNN-IBNLive |date=13 September 2014 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.oneindia.in/international/additional-mh17-crash-investigators-return-to-netherlands-1525660.html#infinite-scroll-1 |title=Additional MH17 crash investigators return to Netherlands |publisher=[[Oneindia.in]] |date=20 September 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref> On 13 October 2014, a Dutch-Ukrainian team resumed recovery of victims' personal belongings.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/dutch-experts-help-recover-mh17-crash-items-despite-nearby-clashes-277024 |title=Dutch Experts Help Recover MH17 Crash Items Despite Nearby Clashes |work=Newsweek |date=13 October 2014 |accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> In mid-November 2014, work was undertaken to remove part of the wreckage from the crash site. Earlier efforts by the recovery team to salvage the MH17 wreckage had been frustrated by disagreements with the local rebels.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30000967 |title=MH17 crash: Dutch salvage team 'unable to start' |accessdate=2 December 2014 |publisher=BBC |date=11 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |title=Ukraine crisis: Timeline |accessdate=2 December 2014 |publisher=BBC |date=13 November 2014}}</ref> The recovery operation took one week to complete. The debris was transported to the Netherlands where investigators reconstructed parts of the plane.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-24/dutch-complete-mh17-wreckage-recovery-in-ukraine/5912572 |title=MH17: Dutch complete recovery of Malaysia Airlines wreckage in eastern Ukraine |date=24 November 2014 |accessdate=24 November 2014 |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=ABC News}}</ref>
In August 2015, possible [[Buk missile system|Buk missile launcher]] parts were found at the crash site by the Dutch led [[#Criminal investigation|joint investigation team]] (JIT).<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dearden |first1=Lizzie |title=MH17 crash: Investigators find possible parts of Buk missile used to shoot plane down |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/mh17-crash-investigators-find-parts-of-buk-missile-possibly-used-to-shoot-plane-down-10450053.html |accessdate=11 August 2015 |work=The Independent |date=11 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Investigation into possible Buk-missile-parts |url=https://www.om.nl/vaste-onderdelen/zoeken/@90384/investigation-into/ | work=Landelijk Parket |publisher=Openbaar Ministerie (Dutch public prosecution service) |accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref>

|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/01/australia-mh17-bodies-retrieved-from-crash-site-within-days |title=Australia says all MH17 bodies should be retrieved from crash site within days |work=The Guardian |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post Tharoor">Ishaan Tharoor – [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/07/20/the-evidence-that-may-prove-pro-russian-separatists-shot-down-mh17/ The evidence that may prove pro-Russian separatists shot down MH17] – The Washington Post – 20 July 2014. Retrieved 3 August 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Paul McGeough |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/ukraine-war-zone-tempers-federal-police-attempts-to-access-mh17-crash-site-20140801-zzkxy.html |title=Ukraine war zone tempers Federal Police attempts to access MH17 crash site |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=14 June 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
An unnamed American intelligence official stated that Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 may have been shot down in error by pro-Russian separatists, citing evidence that separatists launched an SA-11 surface-to-air missile that blew up the Malaysian airliner. They said it was possible the rebel was a former member of the [[Armed Forces of Ukraine]] who had [[Defection|defected]] to the pro-Russian separatists.<ref name="LAtimes">{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-ukraine-intelligence-us-20140722-story.html |title=U.S. officials believe attack against Malaysian plane was mistake |work=Los Angeles Times |date=22 July 2014}}</ref> The official dismissed Russian allegations that MH17 took evasive action and said the claim that the Ukrainian government had shot down MH17 was not realistic, as Kiev had no such missile systems in that area, which was rebel-controlled.<ref name="Aust-ABC002"/> American intelligence officials also said that Russia was attempting to disguise the flow of weaponry it was delivering to the rebels by sending older weapons that matched Ukraine's inventory.<ref name="WaPoJuly22"/> The British [[Foreign Office]] stated that it was "highly likely" that the missile was fired from an area controlled by Russian-backed separatists.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2014/07/26/ukraine-crisis-britain-mh17-plane-idINKBN0FV0J720140726 |title=Britain says highly likely MH17 shot down by Russian-supplied missile |agency=Reuters |date=26 July 2014 |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
The [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian Ministry of Defence]] has maintained that American claims of separatist responsibility were "unfounded", and said that the American intelligence agencies have not released any of the data on which they based their conclusions.<ref>{{cite news |title=US Claims of Flight MH17 Downing by Militia Remain Unfounded – Russia's Defense Ministry |url=http://en.ria.ru/russia/20140724/191186319/US-Claims-of-Flight-MH17-Downing-by-Militia-Remain-Unfounded-.html |agency=RIA Novosti |date=24 July 2014 |quote=The United States has not yet provided any documented evidence to prove that the rocket that brought down the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 was launched from militia-controlled territory, Russian Deputy Defence Minister Anatoly Antonov said on Thursday.}}</ref> According to the Russian military, in what the ''[[New York Magazine]]'' called "Russia's Conspiracy Theory", MH17 was shot down by the Ukrainians, using either a surface-to-air missile or a fighter plane.<ref name=newyork>{{citation |title=Russia's 'Conspiracy Theory': MH17 Shot Down by Ukrainian Fighter Jet or Missile |work=New York |first=Margaret |last=Hartmann |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/07/russia-mh17-downed-by-ukrainian-jet-missile.html |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Russia Presents Its Account of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Crash |first=Olga |last=Razumovskaya |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/russia-presents-its-account-of-malaysia-airlines-flight-17-crash-1405952441?mod=e2tw}}</ref>
On 21 July 2014, the Russian Ministry of Defence held a press conference and said that while the Boeing 777 was crashing, a Ukrainian Su-25 ground-attack aircraft approached to within {{convert|3|to|5|km|mi}} of the Malaysian airliner. The MoD also claimed that satellite photographs showed that the Ukrainian army moved a Buk SAM battery to the area close to the territory controlled by the rebels on the morning of 17 July, hours before the crash. They said the installation was then moved away again by 18 July.<ref name="wsj russian version">{{cite news |author=Razumovskaya, Olga |title=Russia Presents Its Account of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Crash |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/russia-presents-its-account-of-malaysia-airlines-flight-17-crash-1405952441 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=22 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> Promoted by Russian media, the idea that a Su-25 could have downed the Boeing 777 with an [[air-to-air missile]] was dismissed by chief designer of the Su-25, Vladimir Babak.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uatoday.tv/news/general-designer-of-su-25-says-aircraft-couldn-t-have-shot-down-mh17-414628.html |title=General designer of Su-25 says aircraft couldn't have shot down MH17 |publisher=Ukraine Today |date=11 March 2015 |accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> In 2015 [[Bellingcat]] purchased satellite photos from the same area and time as used by the MoD and demonstrated that they had used older photos (May and June 2014) in their presentation that were edited to make a Ukrainian Buk launcher appear as if it was removed after the attack.<ref>{{cite news |title=MH17-Absturz kontert Kritik mit neuen Satellitenbildern |url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2015-06/bellingcat-russland-mh17-satellitenfotos-manipulation |language=German |date=12 June 2015 |accessdate=17 June 2015 |newspaper=De Zeit}}</ref> In the report published by the Dutch Safety Board, an air-to-air missile strike was ruled out.<ref name="auto"/>
In an interview with [[Reuters]] on 23 July 2014, [[Alexander Khodakovsky]], the commander of the pro-Russian [[Vostok Battalion (Donbass)#Vostok Battalion|Vostok Battalion]], acknowledged that the separatists had an anti-aircraft missile of the type the Americans had said was used to shoot down the aircraft, and said that it could have been sent back to Russia to remove proof of its presence;<ref name="ReutersKho">{{cite news |agency=Reuters |date=23 July 2014 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/23/us-ukraine-crisis-commander-exclusive-idUSKBN0FS1V920140723 |title=Ukraine rebel commander acknowledges fighters had Buk missile |author=Anton Zverev}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Shaun Walker in Donetsk |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/23/mh17-ukraine-separatists-buk-missile-system |title=MH17: Ukraine separatist commander 'admits' rebels had Buk missile system |work=The Guardian |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Buckley |first=Neil |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/26fe789c-126e-11e4-a581-00144feabdc0.html |title=Separatist leader admits Ukraine rebels held Buk missile system |work=Financial Times |date=4 July 2014 |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> he later retracted his comments, saying that he had been misquoted and stating that rebels never had a Buk.<ref name="GuardianKho">{{cite web |last1=Walker |first1=Shaun |title=MH17: Ukraine separatist commander 'admits' rebels had Buk missile system |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/23/mh17-ukraine-separatists-buk-missile-system |work=The Guardian |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> In November 2014 he repeated that the separatists had a Buk launcher at the time, but stated that the vehicle, under control of fighters from Luhansk, had still been on its way to Donetsk when MH17 crashed. It was then withdrawn to avoid being blamed.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lanting |first=Bert |title=Wij hadden raket, maar haalden MH17 niet neer |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/dossier-rampvlucht-mh17/wij-hadden-raket-maar-haalden-mh17-niet-neer~a3782013 |language=Dutch |publisher=de Volkskrant |date=4 November 2014 |accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref>
On 28 July 2014, Ukrainian security official Andriy Lysenko announced, at a press conference, that black box recorder analysis had revealed that the aircraft had been brought down by shrapnel that caused "massive explosive decompression." Dutch officials were reported to be "stunned" by what they saw as a "premature announcement" and said that they had not provided this information.<ref>{{cite news |author=Natasha Culzac |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/mh17-crash-black-boxes-show-plane-suffered-massive-explosive-decompression-following-shrapnel-hit-9632881.html |title=MH17 crash: Black boxes show plane suffered 'massive explosive decompression' following shrapnel hit – Europe – World |work=[[The Independent]] |date=28 July 2014 |accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref>
On 8 September 2014, the [[BBC]] released new material by [[John Sweeney (journalist)|John Sweeney]] who cited three civilian witnesses from Donbass who saw the Buk launcher in the rebel-controlled territory on the day when MH17 crashed. Two witnesses said the crew of the launcher and a military vehicle escorting it did not have local accents and spoke with [[Moscow|Muscovite]] accents.<ref name=bbc29109398>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-29109398 |title=MH17 disaster: Russians 'controlled Buk missile system' |publisher=BBC News |date=8 September 2014 |accessdate=9 September 2014 |author=Sweeney, John}}</ref> On the same day Ignat Ostanin, a Russian journalist, published an analysis of photos and films of Buk units moving in Russia and Ukraine in the days before and after the MH17 crash. According to Ostanin, the markings on the specific launcher suspected of being used to shoot MH17, together with the number plates of the [[large goods vehicle]] that carried the launcher, suggested that it belonged to the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade of the Air Defence Forces of the [[Russian Ground Forces]].<ref name="FBS2APRIL">{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/paulroderickgregory/2015/04/02/is-the-mh17-joint-investigation-team-avoiding-the-question-of-kremlin-guilt/ |title=Is The MH17 Joint Investigation Team Avoiding The Question of Kremlin Guilt? |work=Forbes |date=2 April 2015 |accessdate=3 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="ostanin">{{cite web |url=https://bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2014/09/08/images-show-the-buk-that-downed-flight-mh17-inside-russia-controlled-by-russian-troops/ |title=Images Show the Buk that Downed Flight MH17, Inside Russia, Controlled by Russian Troops |publisher=[[Bellingcat]] |date=8 September 2014 |accessdate=9 September 2014 |last=Ostanin |first=Iggy}}</ref>
On 8 October 2014 the president of the German [[Bundesnachrichtendienst|Federal Intelligence Service]] (BND) gave a presentation about MH17 to a German parliamentary committee overseeing intelligence activities. According to ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', the report contained a detailed analysis which concluded that pro-Russian separatists had used a captured Ukrainian Buk system to shoot down Flight MH17. The report also noted that "Russian claims the missile had been fired by Ukrainian soldiers and that a Ukrainian fighter jet had been flying close to the passenger jet were false" and that Ukraine had published manipulated photographs.<ref name=spiegel-bnd-de>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/mh17-laut-bnd-waren-separatisten-fuer-absturz-verantwortlich-a-997885.html |title=Ostukraine: BND macht Separatisten für MH17-Absturz verantwortlich|trans-title=Eastern Ukraine: BND says separatists are responsible for MH17 crash |work=Der Spiegel |date=19 October 2014 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/10/20/world/germany-says-ukraine-rebels-downed-mh17-seized-missiles-report/ |title=Germany says Ukraine rebels downed MH17 with seized missiles: report |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=20 October 2014 |accessdate=20 October 2014}} "He also said Ukrainian photos had been "manipulated", the magazine reported but did not elaborate on what the pictures showed, who had provided them or altered them."</ref> The [[Attorney General of Germany]] opened an investigation against unknown persons due to a suspected [[war crime]].<ref name=spiegel-bnd>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/german-intelligence-blames-pro-russian-separatists-for-mh17-downing-a-997972.html |title=Deadly Ukraine Crash: German Intelligence Claims Pro-Russian Separatists Downed MH17 |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=19 October 2014 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref>
Between November 2014 and May 2016, UK-based investigative collective [[Bellingcat]] made a series of conclusions, based on their examination of photos in social media and other open-source information. Bellingcat said that the launcher used to shoot down the aircraft was a Buk 332 of the Russian [[53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade]] based in [[Kursk]], Russia, which had been transported from [[Donetsk]] to [[Snizhne]] and was controlled by separatists in Ukraine on the day of the attack.<ref name="Bellingcat">{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Origin-of-the-Separatists-Buk-A-Bellingcat-Investigation1.pdf|title=MH17: Source of the Separatists' Buk|author=Bellingcat MH17 Investigation Team|date=8 November 2014|publisher=Bellingcat|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141109132619/https://www.bellingcat.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Origin-of-the-Separatists-Buk-A-Bellingcat-Investigation1.pdf|archive-date=9 November 2014|deadurl=no|access-date=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/journalists-find-solid-russian-ties-to-missile-that-hit-mh17-371161.html|title=Journalists find 'solid' Russian ties to missile that hit MH17|last=Gorchinskaya|first=Katya|date=9 November 2014|work=Kyiv Post|accessdate=18 June 2015|last2=Lavrov|first2=Vlad}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/meet-eliot-higgins-putins-mh17-nemesis-345485|title=Meet Eliot Higgins, Putin's MH17 Nemesis|last=Tucker|first=Maxim|date=22 June 2015|work=Newsweek|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/bellingcat-new-evidence-against-russian-soldiers-on-mh17/a-18959585|title=Bellingcat: New evidence against Russian soldiers on MH17|work=DW.COM|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2016/05/03/the_lost_digit/|title=bellingcat – The Lost Digit: Buk 3x2 – bellingcat|work=bellingcat|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref>
On 22 December 2014 the Dutch news service [[RTL Nieuws]] published a statement of an unnamed local resident who witnessed the shooting down of MH17, indicating that the plane was shot down by a missile from rebel territory. He took photographs of what appeared to be the vapour trail of a ground-launched missile which he passed to the [[Security Service of Ukraine|SBU]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/nieuws/binnenland/ooggetuige-mh17-mijn-doel-rechtvaardigheid |title=Ooggetuige MH17: 'Mijn doel is rechtvaardigheid' |trans-title=Eyewitness of MH17: "My goal is justice" |newspaper=RTL News |date=22 December 2014 |accessdate=23 December 2014 |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=New Competing Claims on Downing of MH17 |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=24 December 2014 |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/new-competing-claims-on-downing-of-mh17/26760591.html}}</ref> On 24 December Russia's state-operated domestic news agency [[RIA Novosti]] quoted the leader of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic, [[Alexander Zakharchenko]], saying he saw MH17 shot out of the sky by two Ukrainian jets.<ref>{{cite news |title=Глава ДНР о крушении MH17: "Я видел, как это происходило" |trans-title=Head of the DPR about the crash of MH17: "I saw how it happened" |date=25 December 2014 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |language=Russian |newspaper=RIA News |url=http://ria.ru/mh17/20141225/1040130183.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kremlin-backed insurgent leader claims personally witnessing Ukrainian aircraft shooting down MH17 |newspaper=Ukraine Today |date=25 December 2014 |url=http://uatoday.tv/news/kremlin-backed-insurgent-leader-claims-personally-witnessing-ukrainian-aircraft-shooting-down-mh17-399664.html}}</ref>
In January 2015 a report produced by the German investigative team CORRECT!V concluded a Buk surface-to-air missile launcher operated by the [[53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade]] shot down MH17.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv-post-plus/new-report-says-it-proves-russian-forces-downed-flight-mh17-377063.html |title=New report says it proves Russian forces downed flight MH17 |date=10 January 2015 |first=Maxim |last=Tucker |work=Kyiv Post |accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref> Large amounts of other [[circumstantial evidence]] were presented separately by various parties that supports this version, identifying specific launcher vehicle, operator name, truck transporting it and its alleged route through Russia and Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/evidence-mounts-that-russia-supplied-the-missiles-that-shot-down-mh17-in-ukraine-2015-5?IR=T |title=Evidence mounts that Russia supplied the missiles that shot down MH17 in Ukraine |publisher=Business Insider |date=13 May 2015 |accessdate=13 June 2015 |author=Robert Coalson}}</ref>
In March 2015 Reuters published statements from named witnesses from Chervonyi Zhovten ({{lang-uk|[[:uk:Червоний Жовтень|Червоний Жовтень]]}}), a village close to Torez and Snizhne, who said they saw the Buk rocket passing over the village when it was fired from a field around 1.5 km away. It also published a statement from a witness who was said to be a separatist fighter (referred to by first name only) who confirmed that the launcher was placed in that area on the day of the Boeing crash to prevent Ukrainian airstrikes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/12/us-ukraine-crisis-airliner-idUSKBN0M81XF20150312 |title=Exclusive: From 'Red October' village, new evidence on downing of Malaysian plane over Ukraine |agency=Reuters |accessdate=12 March 2015 |author=Anton Zverev}}</ref>
In July 2015, [[News Corp Australia]] published the transcript of a 17-minute video recorded at the scene shortly after the crash. The transcript and published segments of the video indicated that Russian-backed rebels arrived at the crash site in the expectation of finding the wreckage of a military aircraft and of locating crew that had parachuted from the aircraft.<ref name="NC150717">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/full-transcript-russian-backed-rebels-ransack-the-wreckage-of-mh17-in-shocking-17-minute-video/story-e6frfkp9-1227444629703|title=Full transcript: Russian-backed rebels ransack the wreckage of MH17 in shocking 17-minute video|last=|first=|date=17 July 2015|work=|accessdate=17 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717004444/http://www.news.com.au/national/full-transcript-russian-backed-rebels-ransack-the-wreckage-of-mh17-in-shocking-17-minute-video/story-e6frfkp9-1227444629703|archive-date=17 July 2015|dead-url=yes|publisher=[[news.com.au]]}}</ref>
In May 2016, [[Stratfor]] released satellite imagery taken 5 hours before the crash which showed a Russian Buk system travelling on a flatbed truck east through the town of [[Makiivka]], 40 km away from Snizhne. Stratfor's concluded that a Buk system had moved from the Russian border toward Donetsk on 15 July 2014, and then moved back to the east on the afternoon of 17 July 2014, hours before Flight MH17 was shot down.<ref>{{cite news|title=Examining the Evidence of Russia's Involvement in a Malaysia Airlines Crash|url=https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/examining-evidence-russias-involvement-malaysia-airlines-crash|accessdate=16 May 2016|publisher=Stratfor}}</ref>
===Dutch Safety Board reports=== ====Preliminary report==== On 9 September 2014, the preliminary report was released by the Dutch Safety Board (DSB).<ref name="dsb1">{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/09/09/world/europe/netherlands-ukraine-mh17-report/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Report: MH17 hit by burst of 'high-energy objects' from outside |date=9 September 2014 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=25 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="dsbprelim">{{citation |title=Preliminary report – Crash involving Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200 Flight MH17 |format=PDF |work=DSB |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=24 September 2014 |url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/uploads/phase-docs/701/b3923acad0ceprem-rapport-mh-17-en-interactief.pdf}}</ref>{{rp|16}} This preliminary report concluded that there was no evidence of any technical or operational failure in the aircraft or from the crew prior to the ending of the [[Flight recorder|CVR and FDR]] recordings at 13.20:03 hrs (UTC). The report also said that "damage observed on the forward fuselage and cockpit section of the aircraft appears to indicate that there were impacts from a large number of high-energy objects from outside the aircraft". According to the investigators, this damage probably led to a loss of structural integrity that caused an in-flight break-up first of the forward parts of the aircraft and then of the remainder with an expansive geographic spread of the aircraft's pieces.
[[Tjibbe Joustra]], Chairman of the Dutch Safety Board, explained that the investigation thus far pointed "towards an external cause of the MH17 crash", but determining the exact cause required further investigation. They also said that they aimed to publish the final report within a year of the crash date.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Prof. mr. dr. Erwin Muller |title=Investigation crash MH17, 17 July 2014 Donetsk |url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/en/onderzoek/2049/investigation-crash-mh17-17-july-2014/preliminary-report/1562/preliminary-report-points-towards-external-cause-of-mh17-crash#fasen |website=Dutch Safety Board |publisher=Onderzoeksraad voor Veiligheid |accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref>
====Final report==== [[File:MH17 Missile Impact.webm|thumb|thumbtime=43|right|upright=1.273|Narrated reconstruction of the missile impact, produced by the [[Dutch Safety Board]]]] The Dutch Safety Board (DSB) issued its final report on the crash on 13 October 2015. The report concluded that the crash was caused by a [[Buk missile system|Buk 9M38-series surface-to-air missile]] with a 9N314M [[warhead]]. The warhead detonated outside and above the left-hand side of the cockpit. The impact killed the three people in the cockpit and caused structural damage to the airplane leading to an in-flight break-up resulting in a wreckage area of 50 square kilometres and loss of the lives of all 298 occupants.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report"/> Based on evidence they were able to exclude meteor strikes, the plane having technical defects, a bomb, and an air-to-air attack as causes of the crash. The DSB calculated the trajectory of the missile and found it was fired within a {{convert|320|km2|sqmi|adj=on}} area southeast of [[Torez]]. Narrowing down a specific launch site was outside the DSB's mandate.<ref name="DSB_Final_Report">{{cite report|url=https://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/uploads/phase-docs/1006/debcd724fe7breport-mh17-crash.pdf |title=Crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 |publisher=[[Dutch Safety Board]] |date=13 October 2015 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cFSGnsRg?url=http://cdn.onderzoeksraad.nl/documents/report-mh17-crash-en.pdf |archivedate=13 October 2015 |deadurl=yes|df= }}</ref>{{rp|147}} The findings do not specify who launched the Buk missile but according to Al Jazeera, the area identified by the DSB was controlled by separatists at the time of the downing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/10/dutch-board-russian-missile-downed-mh17-151013112210934.html |title=Dutch board says Russian-made missile downed MH17 |date=13 October 2015}}</ref>
In addition to the technical investigation, the selection of the flight route was also investigated by the DSB.<ref>{{cite web|title=Investigation crash MH17, 17 July 2014 |url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/en/onderzoek/2049/investigation-crash-mh17-17-july-2014/onderzoek/1543/dutch-safety-board-heads-investigation-investigation-effort-in-full-swing-black-boxes-currently-being-read-out |website=onderzoeksraad.nl |publisher=[[Dutch Safety Board]] |accessdate=24 July 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ShD1V2ae?url=http://www.onderzoeksraad.nl/en/onderzoek/2049/investigation-crash-mh17-17-july-2014/onderzoek/1543/dutch-safety-board-heads-investigation-investigation-effort-in-full-swing-black-boxes-currently-being-read-out |archivedate=19 September 2014 |df= }} ()</ref> Many airlines had avoided the Eastern Ukrainian airspace for months prior to the MH17 disaster.
